Keeley Hawes looked amazing in Dr Who last night. Very sexy! The glasses were just props with no prescription. Shame that character was only in that episode, but at least she was in it a lot. Seeing that character with glasses was as good as seeing Amy Pond, the Dr's previous companion, wearing reading glasses. Again they were just props for the show but a few months after the actress who played Amy, Karen Gillan, had left the show she got real glasses! There are only a few photos of her wearing her real glasses and I can't tell what sort of prescription she has. I keep hoping that the Dr's current companion, Clara, will wear glasses at some point. I'm sure I've seen a photo of Jenna Coleman who plays her wearing glasses but I can't find it now. Maybe I dreamt it.

Revolver 12 Sep 2014, 11:30

On one of the major network morning shows today Mia Farrow was on and wearing larger wire round classes. With her mousy gray stringy hair she simply looked old. Contrast her with Diane Keaton who is of the same vintage but wears trendy plastic frames and there's a world of difference. That's not necessarily saying that the right frames will make you look young, just saying that the wrong ones will make you look old.

Soundmanpt 14 Jul 2014, 17:00

No one has mentioned the new season of "Big Brother" It has kept my interest this season because of one of the cast members. A very attractive little blonde. her name is Nichol and she she is a nursing student. She wears her glasses full time and I have watched even the after hours show which airs for 2 hours every night and is live. So far she has not taken her glasses off even once. She does fiddle with them from time to time aand has to push them back up quite a bit because they slip down her nose. but she never goes so far as to remove them. Last night they showed some pictures of her back in college and in one she appears to be at a dance and the other she is wearing a basketball jersey and seems to be playing basketball in the pictures she isn't wearing glasses so most likely she was wearing contacts. Now her glasses are far from weak. She appears to be in the area of -3.50 to -4.00.

There was another girl on the show that only wore her glasses part of the time during competions, but she lost and was evicted from the house. There is another girl on the show that also wears her glasses full time but she is not of my liking. Her prescription seems somewhat weaker than Nichol's glasses.

Yoyo 21 May 2014, 18:39

myofan,

Try copying and pasting the addresses into your browser window.

myofan 21 May 2014, 17:33

til -- Can you still view the pictures? If so, then the pictures have not been "pulled down" by anyone. When I click the links (from the US) the server posts a "Forbidden" message, meaning that for whatever reason I am not allowed to view the pictures.

myofan 21 May 2014, 17:29

til -- to "have [one's] pictures pulled down" implies that someone other than the subject removed the pictures or, worse yet, the subject requested that the pictures be removed.

Sorry I didn't clarify this in my previous post.

myofan 21 May 2014, 17:26

til -- to "take one's pictures down" means to remove them from the server where they were displayed. Usually this is done by whoever put them up (on the server) in the first place, but this is not necessarily always true.

EyeTri 05 May 2014, 03:29

Soundmanpt

I'm absolutly sure. I have at least 10 in my collection (different colors,etc). All of them are marked Martin Copeland or M/C. I also have an original Martin Copeland sale flyer for this frame (the model name is Marcia).

Soundmanpt 04 May 2014, 15:30

EyeTri

Are you certain about the 2nd ones not being "Tura"? I came across several Turas that looked just like the one shown. Tura put there name on the inside of the earpiece which I thought was interesting since no one could see it except the owner of the frame.

EyeTri 04 May 2014, 14:55

A.P.

The first frame in that video was made by Victory, the second one was made by Martin Copeland and the third frame was made by ArtCraft. I don't know who made the fourth one. They are all beautiful.

Soundmanpt 04 May 2014, 00:42

A.P.

I'm not sure but like you I really liked those glasses back in the day. I know you didn't ask but the first one was made by "Tura" and they were very well made. The entire frame was made of aluminum. I am sure I misspelled that, but anyway that frame would last forever. It was a very light weight frame. The only problem I ever saw with them was that they were painted in either a copper color or silver color and after a while the paint tended to wear off. Both the first one and second one I came across quite often in the donation boxes back in the 70's. I held on to a good number of the ones that were in very good condition and some years later when an optician friend ask me about vintage glasses I pulled them out and when I showed them to her she really wanted one so she could make them up in her prescription. She had a difficult time picking which one she wanted and finally decided on the frame your referring to. They looked great on her and she often wore them at work even though her manager probably wasn't very happy about. She told me they were the most comfortable glasses she had ever wore.

A. P. 03 May 2014, 17:27

Soundmanpt--- Might the second frames in this video be Art Craft? Whatever they are, I'd love to see ladies today wearing something like that!

http://youtu.be/yUnHeCF1krg

Soundmanpt 03 May 2014, 09:58

I wonder if because Crystal lowe is wearing those retro glasses from the 50's if they may again become popular. I hope so because i actually think they look very nice. I used to come across them in the donated glasses boxes and I was surprised even in the 90's how many of the young female opticians wanted a apir for themselves. I believe they were made by a company called Art Craft.

 16 Feb 2014, 16:06

Last Monday on Days of our Lives, both Jordan and Sami were wearing glasses. Very rare to see 2 characters wearing glasses on the same day. Chloe wore glasses when she was in her teens. Adult Chloe does not wear glasses. Chloe appears off and on. Jordan is definitely a full time glasses wearer. Sami is once in a blue moon.

Soundmanpt 15 Feb 2014, 14:31

Over the years "Days of Our Lives" female stars have been seen quite often wearing glasses. Quite few years ago a very attractive young woman played the role of "Cloe" She was in glasses full time then not sure why she suddenly didn't wear glasses anymore. At the same time a young actress played the daughter I think her real name was Zooey something. But in her case she only rarely appeared wearing glasses. But it was clear that when she did it almost had to be a result of a contact problem and of course those shows don't take time off. Then the role of "Sammi" who is still with the show and she too seems to wear glasses at will. I had lost interest in the show some time ago and only from comments in here i have tried to catch more shows. I have to admit the very attractive young woman playing "Jordan" has peeked my interest From as best I can tell she wears glasses full time on the show and they certainly appear to be her own prescription as well.

It's really great that FINALLY after all these years the people that put these shows on TV have figured out that in real life many people wear glasses so it made so little sense that you rarely ever saw anyone of the main cast wearing glasses. So much more realistic to see someone like Sophia Bush wearing glasses on her show and no doubt most likely her own glasses in her own prescription. Now that the door has been opened I don't see them ever going back. There will probably be more and more shows with the actresses wearing glasses.

Soundmanpt 22 Jan 2014, 17:56

There was a post of Emma doing a radio talk show not that long ago, of course no real idea when the interview was done, but it wasn't that long ago that it was posted. She was wearing glasses but they were much weaker than the glasses she is wearing in these pictures. In that interview she even took her lasses off to look at something on a monitor a few feet away.

Could she have been wearing contacts and she wearing a mild prescription fro reading and in order to see distance better that was why she took off her glasses? It is very clear her glasses are strong enough in these pictures that there is no way she could see a small monitor several feet away without them. She is still quite young, so it could be just like any other young person her eyes are just changing at a rather fast pace? I would guess that her glasses in these pictures look to be at least -7.00. A lot of cut-in.

Soundmanpt 18 Jan 2014, 14:20

By the way watched an episode last night of "Liv and Maddie" on the Disney Channel. The idea of the show is that Liv and Maddie are identical twins except that Maddie wears glasses full time and Liv doesn't wear glasses. both roles are played by Dove Cameron a very pretty 18 year old in real life. Anyway unlike many shows they don't try and make the Maddie character look ugly but make her oddly enough more of a sporty girl that is the captian of her high school basketball teem. The other girl is much more of a girly girl type.

Anyway in this episode the girls need to switch places after they both go for their driver's license and Liv passes but Maddie fails. Sees she has a problem with making left turns. Anyway Liv, the sister that doesn't need glasses, is in the car with the instructor and Liv is in the driver's seat pretending to be her sister. the instructor says to her "Aren't you forgetting something?" She says "Oh yes" and pulls out some lip gloss. The instructor says "No I mean it says here your required to wear glasses" She replies "oh yes, how could I forget?" and pulls out her sisters glasses and puts them on. She quietly comments "OMG" as she struggles to see with them and drives off hitting all kinds of objects along the way.

The show will air again tonigt here in the states.

Disney Studios don't seem to have any problem with some of there you stars wearing glasses in their roles.

Soundmanpt 18 Jan 2014, 14:03

Minus5

The other day at the gym one of the overhead TV's had "Days of Our Lives" on and i couldn't hear what was being said and even though the treadmill I was on has TV mounted on it somehow I didn't feel comfortable turning to that station in case someone saw me watching a soap. You know not too manly. Anyway the next few days i watched from home and your right she is very attractive and i agree looking through her right lens from behind her there did seem to be a slight minification of the wall with the pasliy print on it. So her glasses are likely her own glasses and she has w very weak prescription because she is nearsighted.

I haven't seen the show enough. Do they have her character wearing glasses full time? I remember many years ago there was a young lady on there and if I recall her character was Cloeie, she had dark hair and wore glasses full time and then oddly after a long while she suddenly didn't wear glasses anymore so her character must have gotten contacts as well as in real life maybe. I soon lost interest in the show. I know during the time i was watching that young lady there was 2 other blond girls on the show and every once in a while they would wear glasses, but usually just for that day. The younger one was a daughter on the show and her real last name was Storm and I only saw her wearing glasses once but there was no doubt that they were her real glasses because you could tell they were pretty strong looking minus glasses. There wasn't any mention of why she was wearing glasses written into the show so my guess is she had a problem with her lenses and had no choice but to wear her glasses to do her role. The other girl was a little bit older and she is still on the show and she did wear her glasses more often on the show.

Eyestein 16 Jan 2014, 06:05

Can you believe Katy Manning can only get contacts in half the strength she needs. This is what she said in an interview with peter Garett:

Gareth: Can you not wear contacts?

I can now, but they can only make them half the strength I need. There's this guy in Brisbane who wants to give me the eye operation and he said he'ddo it free. But he sweetly said, "I just have to tell you that you've beenlike this all your life, so you should really think about this". You see, I've never seen anything ugly. Everything looks beautiful, there's no hard edges, just soft, lights go on forever and that's the way it should be, Ithink.Two years later, I'm driving along with a girlfriend and I see thisbeautiful bunch of white flowers alongside the road and I ask her to stop the car. And she's going what? I'm saying, "It's so beautiful" and she's like, "What? Plastic bags?" Whose eyes would you rather live through: Mineor hers? I saw flowers, she saw plastic bags.So I rang him and said, Thankyou very much, Archie, I'm over it, you can give me a facelift instead.

Perhaps she has a lot of astigmatism in addition to myopia?

Tom 14 Jan 2014, 17:52

Myopeinhere

I love Kate Mannings' glasses. I used to date a girl in the early nineties who wore contacts, but in the evenings and when staying at home in the weekends, she just went the easy way and opted for glasses. As she almost never wore them oustide the house, she told me she hadn't bothered paying extra for thinner lenses. She felt most comfortable in a large plastic frames and her lenses were thick and strong.

She confessed to me once that she often felt sexy and aroused in them, because knowing that hinting at allowing me to take them off her face always meant some good fun coming up!

s 05 Dec 2013, 12:47

Last night I watched "The Middle" on ABC It's a sitcom about a family. The episode last night was called "The Kiss" About midway through the show the mom and dad were staying in someone else's home and the dad was trying to figure out how to turn the TV on and couldn't figure out which remote to use. His wife played by Patricia Heaton came in the room and sat down and asked why he wasn't watching TV and he told her he couldn't figure out which remote to use and even which button to push. She said "all you need is a fresh set of eyes" and promptly put on a nice pair of small plastic frame glasses. As she was getting the right remote she started reading the manual on how to use the remotes her husband snatched her glasses off her face and started hitting buttons again. He asked her about something in the manual and she responded that she couldn't see it without her glasses. Anyway this exchange went back and forth for several minutes until she took her glasses turned them around so they could both look through a lens each and she told him he should get his own glasses.

As a side note several weeks ago the cast was making the rounds of many of the morning talk shows promoting the airing of the 100th show. The girl that play the teen daughter on the show was along and she was wearing very real glasses at each of the shows they hit. On the show she doesn't wear glasses but her eyes sure look like she is wearing contacts. The funny thing is she looked really super attractive when she was making the rounds that day, but on the show she appears t be much younger and even though she doesn't wear glasses she wears very noticeable braces on her teeth. When she was making the rounds she didn't have any braces and like I side she looked a bit older and super attractive.

Soundmanpt 29 Nov 2013, 01:24

aviator -00-

Woody Allen has always had a thing about his actresses wearing glasses and even his wife's. "Annie Hall" as well as "Scoop" starring Scarlett Johanson were several that quickly come to mind and i am sure there were others. In real when he married Mia Farrow she wasn't wearing glasses but not long after they married she sudden;y became a full time glasses wearer and not only was she wearing glasses but they were in a style that Woody seemed to like very much like the ones wore in "Scoop" Also I don't recall the name of another actress in one of his films but she was thrilled becasue Woody gifted her with a apir of his own glasses which she admitted she wore regularly and hadn't bothered getting the prescription changed in them. She only comented how thrilled she was to get them. Little doubt that he has a fetish about women wearing glasses.

Maybe we should invite him to join "Eyescene" Who knows he could be here under a fake name and we don't even know it. There is something to think about???

Soundmanpt 02 Nov 2013, 09:24

Lu2cri

It really seems that many of the shows are now not afraid to have their actors wear glasses more and more. Shows like The Middle and Modern Family both have characters that wear glasses full time on their shows. And the Disney show "Liv and Maddie" is yet another show where Maddie wears glasses full time. In an upcoming episode I think tonight or tomorrow she will be playing dodge ball with her sister (really her because she plays both Liv and Maddie), and she be wearing sport glasses to protect her eyes, so they really try and make a point that she can't see very well without her glasses. By the way if you haven't seen the show her character isn't cast as being a geek or nerd at all but more just a about a real girl that is in high school and is into sports but is still very attractive all the while.

I think the popularity of glasses has made a big change in glasses being more excepted on camera.

In last nite's episode she appeared in glasses sitting and apparently studying. As befits her character, one more interested in fashion than nearly anything else, she wore stylish, but not true hipster, frames. And, she looked quite fine.

Soundmanpt 26 Oct 2013, 22:44

Happened to catch a movie that came out back in 2010. It was mentioned at the time it was released but it was such a good movie and for once featured the leading actress wearing her glasses most of the time throughout the movie. The movie is "Chain Letter" and it actress was Nikki Reed. The nicest part is that it was very clear her glasses had very real lenses with a nice minus prescription, no doubt her real prescription.

If you haven't seen t yet be sure to check it out as the movie is actually pretty good as well.

Another new reallity show has also hit the airwaves. Something called "Big Tips Texas" it's on MTV and is about the lives of a bunch of girls working at a sports bar in Texas and the going ons of the girls. One of the girls wears glasses nearly all the time except when they are going swimming.

Willy 22 Oct 2013, 09:00

I was catching up on Modern Family and Claire (Julie Bowen) had a line in an episode before the Gloria needing glasses episode that perked my attention. Claire went to work at her father's business and said she brought "a pair of glasses in case I want to read something or look smart." The direct meaning of the line would seem to indicate a need for reading glasses, though the phrasing "a pair of glasses" rather than "my glasses" seemed odd. And if they wanted Claire to debut glasses with a grudging nod to their necessity, the line would play better as "in case I want to look smart -- or read something."

Later, Claire is seen entering data from a spread sheet into a computer without glasses, so the line was probably just a filler, but perhaps Claire will try on Gloria's glasses in a future epiosde....

Melyssa 22 Oct 2013, 07:35

Some time ago I mentioned that a woman named Terri Gerber would be shown on Match Game '76 around October. She wore huge brown drop-temples, with an amazing resemblance to a Diplomat frame called Joanne (if not actually the frame itself), a frame I purchased in 1984 and still wear. Terri may be on today (between 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. EDT), if not tomorrow or the next day, as the gravelly-voiced grandmother who was her opponent made her first appearance on yesterday's broadcast.

Neil 21 Oct 2013, 14:52

RE Valerie Bertinelli on Iron Chef America: playing the role of a judge, wearing glasses makes sense, as it 'fits' with the task. But lined bifocals?

That's rather odd in 2013. She is not that old that she could not adapt to PALs. It's hard to find even the most bland, bald politicians or corporate executives in lined bifocals when appearing on television, or otherwise!

Seeing Valerie Bertinelli in her glasses on Iron Chef recalled her earlier role in "Touched by an Angel" (I think that's the title). She played a younger angel who interacted with "humans" and wore glasses pretty much 100% of the time in that role. Looked very similar to what I saw on Iron Chef.

Finally, Ariel Winter, who plays the middle daughter in the comedy Modern Family, has new frames, more stylish and attractive imho, as this season begins. Her character who also wears the glasses nearly 100% of the time, is the smart and solid one (v. the ditzy and sexy older sister character).

Soundmanpt 16 Oct 2013, 20:12

Just came across a new Disney show. Well to be honest it has been on since mid July, but I don't watch Disney too much. But I happened to catch a preview of this show and made a point to watch it. It's called "Liv and Maddie" and it stars a young lady by the name of Dove Cameron. She actually plays both leading ladies. It's about twin sisters, one has just come home after starring in a TV series for the past 4 years out in Hollywood but it recently aired its last show. So she is more of a princess type. The other sister is every bit attractive but more down to earth. She is more into sports and is the star player on her basketball team. But unlike her sister she wears glasses full time and unlike so many shows where the glasses soon come off, not so in this show. I watched 4 of the episodes back to back and she kept her glasses on through each show. In the pilot the 2 girls are in their bedroom and Maddie (the glasses wearer) is getting dressed for homecoming and she asks her sister Liv which glasses looks best on her but she does so without taking off her glasses. Then in another episode Maddie's parents are trying to figure out a good punishment for her and consider several including grounding and taking her phone away and even consider taking her glasses away. In the end they decide to not let her play in an upcoming basketball game.

The glasses have lenses in them but so far they haven't had a real close up of her to be able to tell if the glasses have a prescription. Her glasses are not the "hipster" style but rather ordinary. But it's nice not making her a nerd girl for once.

Soundmanpt 07 Oct 2013, 11:30

gwgs

I agree with you. They seem to be basing the idea that Miss Stone's glasses were fake and not needed because she didn't wear them while on Jimmy Kinnel's show. Of course that is a crazy way to assume she doesn't really need glasses. She could of course switched to contacts at the studio, and just because she wears glasses doesn't mean she needs them so bad that she couldn't sit 3 feet away from Kimmel and see just fine without them. I saw the show and she didn't have to read anything or look at a teleprompter so even if she wears glasses full time she would be able to do that without them. I think her prescription is real but likely on the weak side. After all the woman is 55 so it would be more surprising if she didn't need glasses.

gwgs 07 Oct 2013, 04:40

TLA - The Daily Mail often report such obviously incorrect facts on a variety of different articles, so I would ignore what they say, and I often post comments correcting them.

They also seems to have an editorial bias against glasses, with various comments throughout articles making glasses wearers out to be geeky, and if a celebrity is wearing them, then they will probably only be props - as mentioned in this article - despite there being an obvious prescription in the said glasses.

gwgs 07 Oct 2013, 04:39

TLA - The Daily Mail often report such obviously incorrect facts on a variety of different articles, so I would ignore what they say, and I often post comments correcting them.

They also seems to have an editorial bias against glasses, with various comments throughout articles making glasses wearers out to be geeky, and if a celebrity is wearing them, then they will probably only be props - as mentioned in this article - despite there being an obvious prescription in the said glasses.

Well, I'm another of those hyperopic shift people, but this has manifested about ten years earlier for me. An interesting adjustment to be sure...

BTW the linked Daily Mail piece claims that Sharon Stone's glasses were strictly a fashion accessory, and that she had "no use" for them during her interview with Jimmy Kimmel.

Any insights or thoughts?

 01 Oct 2013, 19:47

The dreaded after effect of lasik in the mid-50's. Sharon who used to be significantly myopic pre-lasik has probably had a hyperopic shift in her 50's.

Soundmanpt 21 Sep 2013, 12:23

I asked this question before and never got a reply. So I will ask again and hope someone may be of help.

Back in the late 60's or early 70's there was a private detective show on TV that was called "Peter Gunn" one of the episodes I think it was called "Calendar Girl" or "Miss February" not sure which. Anyway it was about a model, and she was Miss February, she witnessed a murder but she was badly nearsighted and didn't have her glasses on at the moment so her vision was too blurred to make out what the murder looked like. Of course the murder had no idea that she couldn't see him clear enough to ever recognize him so he was after her to kill her.

Anyone remember seeing this show or have any idea how to track down a copy of it now?

Interesting that she seemed very comfortable wearing Barbra's glasses throughout the rest of the show. Since I am pretty sure Barbra's glasses are a plus prescription Jenny must wear plus as well only she needs them for distance as well as close up now. it's interesting because the cabs of her her prescription appears very weak at best.

Melyssa 11 Sep 2013, 06:40

Sometime in the next few weeks, there will be two Match Game '76 episodes on GSN (Game Show Network) featuring contestant Terri Gerber, who wore extremely large brown drop-temples. When I first saw the show, I wanted frames like hers, and -- Viola! -- 8 years later I got them, and they are still part of my vast collection today. The frame is called Joanne, of the late Diplomat brand.

While I do not know the exact date(s) of Terri's forthcoming appearances, I do know that the champion at the time was an old woman with metal frame glasses, very short white hair, and a voice like the late wrestler Freddie Blassie ("You pencil-necked geeks!"). So for those of you who get the channel GSN, be on the alert for Terri's appearances.

I very much remember reading an article about Debra Winger early in her acting career she being a country girl was on the back of a wagon and fell off hitting her head. The fall left her with blurred vision in one eye and she wore glasses from then on off camera.

Bill Shakespehr 30 Aug 2013, 14:08

There's a huge difference between Gli Ochialli, and

Strangers On A Train. In "Gli" the bad guys win, in "Strangers" the Good Guy prevails. Finny, his name was actually Guy.

Patricia Highmore in her book "Strangers On A Train" doesn't create a character who wears glasses; it was Alfred Hitchcock who put glasses on Miriam.

Bill Shakespehr 30 Aug 2013, 14:08

Revolver 25 Aug 2013, 13:15

Been meaning to post something about Mary for awhile, this is a good time. Haven't missed any episodes of The Closer that she was in nor any of Major Crimes. Interesting thing about her glasses isn't the frame style (although I agree that these look very nice) but the lenses.

When she first appeared on The Closer, she was wearing a much higher plus, probably a +1.25 or higher and it's expected she was wearing a progressive add as she's pushing 60 years old. But these new ones are plano or close to it for distance and haven't been able to discern an add which would be possible given the plano top and the number of closeups.

This raises possibilities: refractive or cataract surgery, multi-focal or monovision contact lenses with plano lenses in frames to continue her character's glasses wearing persona, and possibly some other options. Anybody else got any ideas?

Lv2c4i 20 Aug 2013, 18:17

Just watched a rebroadcast of TLC's "Who Do You Think You Are?" featuring Christina Applegate. Since much of the show features the "star du jour" reading genealogical records, many end up wearing glasses for parts of the show. So, it was with Christina Applegate. She wore a handsome pair of stylish dark framed glasses for much of the show though I never recall seeing her in spex before. I think the episode is available online so perhaps someone will eventually post some caps.

Also, on the U.S. version of Big Brother, most of the women contestants have worn their glasses off and on throughout the season.

Slit 29 Jul 2013, 01:21

Thanks for Jen Aniston photos.

In the below video I post she plays nicely with glasses, at one time removing them and putting them back soon as she had to focus on up close activity (picking some magnetic rings in a water bottle).

I guessed an rx of about +2 and add of about +1. From the way the light bends inside the lens at one moment she waves hair you can see it is progressive bifocals.

She is one of my favourites based on looks, charisma, wit and also the acting talent (not an extreme art movie talent, but does well in almost all the roles).

 28 Jul 2013, 21:47

To post here, just find an image site that will let you upload your pix, then click the post to this thread link at top of page. Open your pix storage site, click your pic, copy the address then paste the address into your eyescene post. enter some heading of what you are posting (I think only four pics per post)then enter the name of this web site "eyescene" and click Submit. Now let's see those J-Law pix!

Revolver 23 Jul 2013, 12:38

Lv2's comments on Sarah Jessica Parker remind me of something I've been meaning to post about her hit Sex And The City. Throughout the 6 year run of that show all of the actresses except her character Carrie wore glasses at some point. Charlotte wore hers quite often in her role as art gallery manager, towards the end Samantha wore them to read as her character was well over 40, and Miranda wore them twice: once while poring over papers while buying a home and the other time when she got lasik. She commented to the doctor presurgery that this would be the first time in her life that she'd seen clearly w/o glasses or CL's. But her frames were disappointing as they were round gold metal ones with no lenses in them at all, or possibly plano with damn good AR.

But! In the first movie, fairly early on, she is sitting up in bed with Mr. Big and has a book, she goes to read a passage to him and reaches over and takes his off of him and puts them on, he said "you really need to get glasses" and she smirks and says "no I don't, I have yours". That jibes, as the movie was a few years after the TV series ended so she would have been over 40.

Soundmanpt 24 Jun 2013, 19:18

Carrie & Unknown

The newest pictures of Brigit Mendler arriving at the London airport shows here wearing the same glasses that she seemed to refer to as her first glasses some 6 months before like the "unknown" person pointed out.

That was probably about the time I saw a picture in here somewhere of her wearing glasses.

Disney is not good about letting any of their young stars wear glasses in their respective shows. I remember when Debbie Ryan now of the show "Jessie" was first cast on The Suite Life on Deck" she was being interviewed about getting the part and she was wearing glasses during the whole interview. Sadly she has yet to ever be seen wearing glasses on either of those shows or a made for TV movie that she starred in.

The bad part about that is there are so many youngsters that are in their early teens that watch those shows that it would be a good thing if they actually allowed some these young stars to wear glasses to encourage their fans to wear their glasses. They make it appear that every teen has perfect eyesight and we all know that isn't true.

Soundmanpt 14 May 2013, 18:52

Carrie

If you do a background check on Hilary Duff you will find that around the same time as her "Lizzy McGuire" show was wrapping up she commented that she always wanted glasses but had never gotten around to getting them. It wasn't long after that comment that she started showing up wearing glasses. My first thought was that they were probably plano (non-prescription) but there are so many pictures of her wearing glasses that I am now pretty sure they are prescription. Since most of the pictures of her are either with her just arriving someplace or getting into her car it would tend to indicate that she must be a little nearsighted.

I also agree that she is looking mighty fine these days. Her body seems to have recovered well from having a baby.

Soundmanpt 06 May 2013, 08:31

Philosifer

That was why I questioned the appearance of another pair of glasses in front of her. It could be she was just standing at a table that wasn't hers and the glasses on the table belong to some else.

The fact that she is only 28 has little to do with it these days since progressives and bifocals are not that uncommon anymore for even early 20's.

lentifan 24 Apr 2013, 15:07

It's interesting that Eyestein and I both find the girl very attractive and Clare doesn't. Also interesting, I think, is that of the scores of photos of this girl, many of which are obviously posed, there is not one of her without her glasses. This seems to me to indicate either:

A She herself, or the photographer (spouse/partner/ friend/family member?) thinks she looks better wearing her glasses, or

B They think that, since she probably is never seemn without her glasses, any picture of her bare-eyed would be so untypical, so unrepresentative, as to be almost a different person.

On reflection, I've moved off-topic here. I should post this to 'Seen on the Web', perhaps

Eyestein 24 Apr 2013, 04:43

I don't know that girl's name but she is one of my favorites. She looks so sweet and feminine. Her glasses and her obviously poor vision tend to enchance her appeal. That appeal arises from classical male protective instincts. Her poor eyesight arouses something like compassion in a sensitive male but it is not exactly compassion. It's an emotion linked with all the stuff associated with sex appeal. I guess only those who feel it can understand it.

lentifan 23 Apr 2013, 18:30

I suppose what a young lady like you fancies in a woman, Carrie, is bound to be different from what a middle-aged (he said, optimistically) male fancies. But I always have the impression that Hollywood stars wear these big black frames to look deliberately unglamorous in the hope of escaping unnoticed. And even if they are spotted, the glasses are so dominant that they have the effect of making the wearers all look the same, so perhaps they hope not to be recognised if people can't tell one star from another.

In my opinion, this girl beats them all hands down. Her glasses are real and lovely.

Soundmanpt 20 Mar 2013, 15:13

til

Wow! I haven't seen that style in years. Very vintage looking. I really would like to see that style make a return as they really have a glam look about them. The shape and even that little sparkle at the outside top are appealing. I well remember that style and I even kept several when I came across some of them years ago in the donation boxes. But after a few years I brought them out and as soon as I showed them to my female optician friends they quickly begged me for them. Now I would bet I would get even more reaction.

Soundmanpt 20 Mar 2013, 15:04

til

Not uncommon for photo shoots to remove lenses from glasses so as not to get any reflections or light spots that sometimes happens even with AR coatings. It just saves a lot of time to not have lenses in the glasses, but of course we all would rather see real lenses any day of the week and would not have a problem with reflections and the such. lol

By the way that is what makes the work that Crystal Veil does so impressive. His shoots are with real glasses in various powers and most if not all of them don't have the aid of AR coating. This is why he is truly the master of his craft.

Given her younger sister wear glasses, as well as her mother and father (both only seen occassionly wearing them, maybe cl wearers), then I would've thought there is a hint of a prescription, there is definitely some refraction in a couple of those photos, and in one of them her eyes definitely seem enlarged by her glasses (which would suggest a + prescription).

Soundmanpt 18 Mar 2013, 10:43

Fanboy

I see the picture your referring to and it does appear to show some distortion in her right lens, it could indicate some prescription or just be due to a camera angle.

With those girls it is hard to tell what is real and what isn't. Remember there is no better way to market a product your trying to sell than to wear the product yourself.

The possibilities are all over the place for now. It is possible that she didn't bother to wait for her eyes to be stable when she had the lasik done and her eyes have continued to change. If she was over corrected too much she may now need readers. And being pregnant could have caused her eyes to change as well? And of course thay could just be plano lenses she is wearing. Take your pick.

Happened to watch two old Alfred Hitchcock black and white movies from 1931.

In "Murder" an unknown actress wears noticeably thick plus lenses. In "Rich and Strange" the very same unknown actress wears rather thick minus lenses.

The character study thickens.

A. P. 02 Jan 2013, 19:09

Hello "Q'.

Let me try to explain this to you, not that it's really all that earthshakingly important. The TV commercial actress IS Emily Tarver. You stated in your previous post that the actress was "Christina Pickles". Yes, there is an actress named Christina Pickles, but she's obviously not the lady in the commercials. Now you have posted that the actress is "Cathy Pickles". If you look at the youtube page belonging to Cathy Pickles, you'll see that the posts there look suspiciously like the page belongs to Emily Tarver herself. She was just defending herself when she posted on the youtube comments section as "Cathy Pickles".

By the way, both "Cathy" and Pickles" are names of popular comic strips. Get it?

Emily Tarver is a talented lady. Let's all just enjoy her work, OK? Thanks. A. P.

Euro Traveller 30 Nov 2012, 04:29

I'm not a fan of shows like 'I'm a celebrity get me out of here' but I thought it was curious that Helen Flanagan who is quite myopic (a Google images search will reveal recent pics from the Spectacle Wearer of the Year Awards at which she was about the only 'celeb' wearing real glasses) was never once seen wearing her glasses given the conditions that the contestants apparently have to endure.

I would have thought it quite unlikely that anyone would be able to tolerate wearing 'night and day' lenses in those conditions.

Call me a cynic but I suspect that life may have been rather more comfortable for the 'celebs' than the TV edits suggest...

Soundmanpt 23 Nov 2012, 12:54

Lucas

It could be she may have had it done before her vision was completely stable. So her vision could still be changing slightly. Also it is not unusual for most to have some regression form when they first get it done. that is why most everyone comes out with vision of 20/15 and even 20/10. After a couple of years the vision drops to 20/20. Also some experience some issues with problems with night vision as well. So her glasses could have a very slight prescription in them, but really I am surprised that we haven't seen more of the Kardashian girls wearing glasses since they recently came out with their own line of eyewear.

Carrie 23 Nov 2012, 12:28

Could be an old picture of Kim Kardashian.

Lucas 22 Nov 2012, 20:46

Carrie 22 Nov 2012, 17:38

In the photo of Kim Kardashian I think she is holding her prescription glasses as she tries on new frames which would explain the strange reflection on the ones she's wearing. If you look through the lens of the glasses she's holding it seems to be a shrunken image of the background.

If you click on the left or right of the photo there are photos of other celebrities wearing glasses, most of them have already been seen by regular users of Eyescene I expect. I was happy to see a photo of the very sexy Kristen Stewart with glasses (actually I'm happy to see any photo of her with or without glasses!) - it's the same photo that I linked to last week and that's not a flattering one but it's still her in glasses!

I really like Alexandra Hamkalo, on "Komisarz Rex". It's a pretty bad polish TV-Show, which was mentioned here before (BTW thanks for that). The interesting thing about the show from my perspective is that she wears 2 different frames, which are exactly the same. She got both of them once in the -5 area and once without any prescription. So in some scenes, e.g. when her guy takes of her glasses she wears her contacts and the props, not to be too helpless in front of the camera, i guess. No "regular viewer" would recognize that, but we do, don`t we? She appears in Season 2 Episode 1 for the first time, so don`t bother checking out the first season.

I don`t understand a word of polish, but i watch her scenes every week anyways, because she is sooo sweet.

Revolver 14 Oct 2012, 12:29

I'm pretty sure that's a bifocal, the line is too straight and level on both sides to be a reflection. You're never too young for a multifocal of any kind, I got my first ones at age 27 for aesthenopia caused by a slight accomodative lag. And she's on 3 months away from 41 and presbyopia even a few days past 40 is not uncommon. I could read fine with out them at age 27, but it was just a little more comfortable to have them on for near point tasking and have immediately clear distance vision when looking up even though the distance scrip was very slight. And seg height is definitely a personal thing, I like them high and have no difficulty looking over them and they're great for computer use. On the other hand, my prescription sunwear has a very low seg as about all I use it for is to see a road map etc.

Also, remember, actresses are using glasses of all kinds to make a statement, maybe she's on to something and it will hopefully catch on!

Soundmanpt 14 Oct 2012, 11:00

Slit I see what your seeing but I also think that if they are the add is positioned very high up and I would think make it very hard for her to see distances very well. If she would be looking in the distance with them she would have to look down so her eyes could focus through the the smallish top segment. But being close to 40 doesn't mean a thing as there are many even younger now that require bifocals. But it would seem she would have gone for the much less noticeable progressives. But at any rate they still look very nice on her.

matthewson 14 Oct 2012, 05:37

@slit: sure looks like it, but i think that's more of a reflection. for one, the bifocal line is really way up the lens, secondly Drea DiMatteo is what, about 40 - so a bit young for lined bifocals in public and in general, isn't she?

Slit 14 Oct 2012, 04:56

Soundmanpt 04 Oct 2012, 01:24

Clare

In answer to your question, just as Melyssa said the bigger the glasses the thicker the lenses will appear but more so in your short (near) sighted. Even on your own glasses when you clean them you should be able to feel that your lenses are thicker on the outer edges than they are in the center. In fact in the center is the thinnest part of your lenses. So the bigger the lens is the thicker it will continue to get on the outside edges. All this of course is based on the same type of lens. This is why most often as the prescription gets stronger the opticians will try and have you select a smaller frame or they will suggest a hi index lens option. Your prescription is not nearly any problem for any type frame you may want. Now for Melyssa she has stated that she has a rather large face so that of course means she needs a bigger frame size. But in her case she happens to love big glasses and has no problem with her lenses looking thick as -9.00 with standard lenses will have plenty of edge thickness.

answererer 03 Oct 2012, 16:40

About -3 I'd say. So in answer to your question, no she would not see much in the distance.

Melyssa 03 Oct 2012, 14:53

Clare,

I would say that larger frames make prescriptions look stronger -- definitely with CR39 lenses. I am wearing my very large brown drop-temples, and the lenses are much thicker than those of the glasses I had worn just before these today -- brown cat's-eyes about half the size in both frame and lenses, even in my -9.00s.

Soundmanpt 30 Sep 2012, 01:59

Carrie

Being in the states I have no idea who the guy was doing the interview but he didn't seem to pick up her glasses comments at all. If she had not mentioned her glasses not once but twice he may not have wanted to ask hr anything about her glasses since it was on radio and no one could see her. But if she was not wanting her fans to know she was wearing glasses she wouldn't have commented on them. As soon as she made the first comment he should have right away asked her if the glasses was a new look for her? I have no doubt that she would have answered as to if they were indeed new or if she has been a long time contact wearer and maybe had a problem which wouldn't allow her to wear contacts. But as I already said she certainly appears to be new to glasses. She acted like they just weren't fitting right but yet they looked to be sitting perfectly in place before she adjusted them and didn't change at all after she adjusted them. But she was constantly adjusting them.

We all seem to agree that her glasses appear to be a light plus prescription. I really thin what we are seeing is her adjusting to her glasses. Carrie you should know best because your first glasses were only a weak plus prescription and the easiest thing for you was adjusting to seeing close up with your new glasses. Emma seemed to have no trouble seeing her phone during the interview, which means her eyes have already gotten used to seeing close with them. But like you her eyes are still adjusting for distance vision, so even though it probably isn't clear and sharp she can still see with them. But to look at a small laptop at a medium distance for now it is probably easier to see clearly without her glasses for now. She didn't look to have any trouble seeing the laptop without her glasses from what I could tell. But overall she must be getting comfortable with wearing them as he wasted no time in putting them back on.

Could it be her prescription is a little more complicated than just a simple plus and needs to adjust for close-up, like computer screens? It's clear from the photo that her prescription does have plus in it but if that's all it was she wouldn't have needed to take her glasses off to see the screen at Radio 1. Of course she could be getting used to her glasses and is putting up with the slight blur for general distance vision but can't see fine detail at a distance yet so she might have found that the screen was just a little too far from her to see the photo clearly.

I think she actually looks better with glasses on. Without them she still looks like Hermione (spelling?) aged about 13. With her glasses she looks older than she actually is.

I get the impression she is very happy with her glasses and they are probably very new. She mentions them twice during her chat with Grimmy. It's like she was thinking to herself "He hasn't mentioned my glasses yet, how annoying! I'll have to somehow casually mention them!"

Soundmanpt 28 Sep 2012, 11:32

It is a bit curious that she takes her glasses off not once but even a 2nd time while looking at the laptop a short distance away. The only thought I have is that her glasses have a plus prescription and her eyes have yet to adjust to them for distance. But the screen wasn't far enough away that it should have caused her any problem seeing it with her glasses. But she didn't appear to have any trouble seeing the laptop without her glasses. But if notice she seems very fidgity with her glasses and is constantly adjusting them throughout the interview. This is very common for someone that is wearing glasses for the first time as they get used to them. At first I thought maybe it was because of the headset, but I don't think that was it. her glasses hadn't slipped at all so more like she isn't yet used to wearing them. At any rate her prescription looks very weak and I appears to be plus and maybe some astigmatism as well but that is hard to tell.

Yes and the third picture also shows a slight glare in Kaley's left lens. With the new and improved AR coatings it can sometimes be very hard to see lens in pictures and even harder when the prescription is a very weak one which I think is the case here. YoYo is probably correct that her glasses a weak minus. Those other pictures she was wearing glasses at a basketball game where her glasses would make things a little clearer and sharper for her.

One thing would be great in introducing her as a glasses wearer would be what so many come in saying all the time. The getting and wearing glasses for the first time around friends, family and co-workers. This would be easy to relate for everyone that remembers getting glasses for the first time.

Soundmanpt 27 Aug 2012, 11:50

I have never shot a gun so I don't know for sure, but it is common for people doing target practice to wear some eye protection. But they usually look more like wrap-around goggles. The glasses he is wearing looks much more like prescription glasses and it would make sense that if she doesn't have perfect vision she probably would need to either wear contacts or prescription glasses to see the target clearly. I also read the same where her mother was feuding with her about not wearing her glasses like she should. Anyway I am not sure if they would consider regular prescription glasses okay for shooting or if they need to be made of safety glass?

Lv2c4i 18 Aug 2012, 07:03

Fashion and styles are always dynamic, ever evolving. The frames styles being now offered by the Kardashians and Victoria Beckham both seem to be more stylish variations on the original "nerd" (or wayfarer) frames.

The frames shown in the articles about Beckham (but not the ones she was wearing) while still very dark and "out-front", were a more stylish shape and the earpieces were very different.

Likewise with the shapes of the Kardashian collection--or at least the 3 styles modeled. And I did find Kim, who I don't much admire at all, to be looking good in "her glasses." Tho I fully understand others may have different opinions and tastes. So, vive'la difference!

Chloë 16 Jul 2012, 05:48

Forgot the reference (so why I talked about glasses and braces):

Chloë 16 Jul 2012, 05:46

And of course, I'm still surprised that glasses and braces are still being used as signifiers of female ugliness in cinematographic media. The problem here really is the relativity of aesthetic judgements, which means viewers would not recognize that someone is presented as 'ugly' if she was just 'plain' because 'plain' is mostly 'normal' and for some probably better than that. And drawing upon obvious 'disfigurement' (however problematic this term might be) as a sign of 'ugliness' will probably be seen as discriminatory (and I guess I agree). Besides, permanent features do not offer the chance of the aesthetic transformation often found in stereotypical plots. So glasses and braces indicate that a person is supposed to be 'ugly' even though probably viewers will not see them as 'ugly' themselves, especially considering the variety of glasses being used and being seen as attractive these days and considering the fact that there are so many (adult) people wearing braces today.

OK, a short excursion into the semiotics of 'ugliness' in filmic representations.

Chloë 16 Jul 2012, 04:28

"Ugly Betty" is a reference to a TV-series, I guess rather than an aesthetic judgement.

http://i.wp.pl/a/f/jpeg/22936/julia_627.jpeg

No, definitely not ugly :-)

(even though I hate the use of the 'absolutist' use of the term around ES)

Crystal Veil 13 Jul 2012, 22:45

Recommended article: "Spectacles with spectacles: The Representation of Woman in "Strangers on a train" ", about the psychology of glasses in early films. When first seeing "Strangers on a train" on television in the early 1960's I was disappointed by the unsympathetic role played by Laura Elliott and even more so by her short role. Even as a schoolboy, I thought that Hitchcock did not do justice to "real" GWG. I clearly remember another moment of disappointment when seeing Patricia Hitchcock wearing glasses with plano lenses.

Revolver 13 Jul 2012, 19:05

I think I saw the same interview Soundman did, she said Hitchcock insisted she wear the real high minus glasses and she had an awful time doing it. They did play a significant part in the movie when she got murdered, no question from all the scenes they were a high minus with a plano front. Even when I was young couldn't accomodate enough to handle that.

Soundmanpt 13 Jul 2012, 10:09

JJ

I am not sure which young lady is which as if I recall there were 2 women that wore glasses in the movie. The one that worked at the record shop gave an interview a few years later and she referred to the glasses she wore and said that they were so strong she could hardly see anything through them and in one scene she actually had to hold onto the counter as she walked because she couldn't see. Mr Hitchcock seemed to have a thing for his leading ladies wearing glasses as there were several movies that had the female lead actress wearing glasses.

SoCal 05 Jul 2012, 19:49

Soundmanpt

Yea, I have those same exact pair, color and everything. I got them from a boutique named l.a. Eyeworks on Melrose Ave in Los Angeles. When I bought them, the store only had 5 pairs available for the upcoming months (different colors) because they had just come out for their new collection last year. Anyway, I am sad to see them on another face but they really are pretty amazing (when I actually wear them). Another great thing about them are the lenses that are in them. The lab that the store has on premise produces a nice lens, distortion free and everything, my vision is excellent with them on.

Wonderful English actress Jean Marsh's appearance in the 1972 Alfred Hitchcock film "Frenzy". Her scenes here are from the 14:40 mark to 18:20. Enjoy! Carrie 26 Jun 2012, 15:49

Mark

Yes, very sad that she won't be wearing glasses anymore. She's gorgeous with or without glasses. I was amazed how quickly she put a contact lens in. I suppose with years of practice it's easy to put them in. When I wear the contacts my friend gave me (her prescription is very close to mine) it takes me ages to put them in. I sometimes wonder why I bother and I realise why my friend gave up wearing them and wears her glasses instead. I do find them useful when I go to the gym as my glasses slip down my nose. I love my glasses so I don't wear the contacts much.

lentifan 17 Jun 2012, 19:19

Oh dear, not again!

John S, on a point of fact, the lady you refer to in your last paragraph was not subjected to 'vicious attacks'. You are exaggerating.

This website exists for people who have a common interest. They will naturally use terminology and vocabulary which they understand. Any new users will soon pick it up. If you wish to change the vocabulary we use, then good luck to you, but don't be surprised if you are unsuccessful. The terms used don't bother me. However,your continued use of 'cutesey' is beginning to irritate me, but I'm sure I'll get over it.

John S 17 Jun 2012, 18:55

Val, I think you are taking this too personally. I don't think you have anything but the kindest feelings for people, and I feel the same.

I'm just referring to the activities of the "clique" as opposed to the rest of us here. They're the only ones using the cutesy words and have basically driven everyone else out turning Eyescene into an insider club with their very own vocabulary and secret handshakes. Not exactly a welcoming atmosphere. I'll go on record and say I'm willing to bet that almost every woman who suddenly appears needing glasses and posting here in the past couple of years has been a fake by one of the regular "clique."

If we want to be accepted legitimately, then we should act legitimate and use real clinical terms. Throwing around cutesy little words just makes us sound like this is all a school ground trading "guess what I saw" stories, and coming up with impersonal names to label people. Not unlike Fatso, tubby, boney, etc that we hear in school.

I forgot who the woman was who mentioned something about the same several people posting over and over again here, but I do remember the vicious attacks against her for calling things as she seen them. I see it too. But while I guess she was scared away, I'm sticking around to see if we can broaden our appeal, bring us into mainstream. Somethings got to be wrong if we're still hidden after fifteen years and no one even bothers to come here except fake accounts.

Val 17 Jun 2012, 08:50

John S, I must ask you to read the posts with more attention.

I am only trying to help. If you consider my posts as attacks on anybody, I must stand down and excuse myself.

And I also would ask Moonshiner to delete the posts if he considers necessary.

Thank you for your attention,

Val,

http://www.vision-and-spex.com/

John S 17 Jun 2012, 08:29

Ha ha, the second part of my note was to Val, not myself. I need more coffee this early.

John S 17 Jun 2012, 08:24

Yoyo, hate to tell you but Mr. Anon who doesn't like plussie isn't me. So it looks like you are up against more than one person here. But I do agree with their assessment about plussie being a bit childish and cutesy too.

John S, don't forget that "obsessive" is definitely a psychological term, perhaps even more so than fetish. At least the term "fetish" focuses on the sexual aspects of the issue, while "obsessive" sounds like every breath you take has to be about glasses and you think 24/7 about nothing else. Is that what you really mean by an OOO? So take that into consideration.

Val 17 Jun 2012, 07:20

John S, I am sorry but it's not my dictionary. I only reposted a link from Bobby's site. The text has been written long before by All4Eyes (aka Marie).

My knowledge of english language is not that vast to write such an article.

If you say "glasses fetish" so be it. You may be correct. But there are people who like "optic obsessive" maybe because they don't like to be considered fetishists. But we have to ask some psychologists and my expertise is only technical.

Yoyo 16 Jun 2012, 14:28

John S,

Every community of people (even a small one like Eye Scene) will build up some number of terms that are well understood amongst themselves but not to anyone else. If you want to be a part of said community, it's useful to educate yourself about the terminology.

However, if you're just here to criticize the community and not be a part of it, then you will of course not want to learn. In such a scenario, you are also perfectly free to leave.

Julian 16 Jun 2012, 13:37

As someone who has been here for around 15 years, and used to post a lot more than I do these days, I don't know how often I actually use the term 'OO', but I regard it as common currency on EyeScene. And fetish is an abstract term where as obsessive is actually an adjective given a substantive meaning in this case. WTF is cutesy about it?

John S 16 Jun 2012, 07:21

Since we are speaking in such wide generalities, I will say that many of "us" (the crowd outside the clique) prefer "glasses fetish" and words like this that have commonplace in the real world. Sorry, but those other words sound like things you make up in a kindergarten recess.

Lv2c4i 15 Jun 2012, 07:08

On ivillage(.com) there is a set of 30-35 pictures of stars wearing glasses. It is a poll offering readers an opportunity to "vote" on whether they prefer the bare-eyed or the bespectacled look. The pictures include both male and female stars. In many cases, the readers have chosen the glasses as their favorite of the two pix. Many are photos (and stars) we've seen wearing their glasses before, but some are new.

visitor 15 Jun 2012, 07:07

Playboy: What areas of expertise do people think you have that you really don't have at all?

Dern: A lot of people think I speak many languages, and I don't. They start speaking to me in Spanish, Italian, sometimes even Japanese. I speak some French, but I'm not fluent. People also think I wear contact lenses - which I consider an area of expertise, one that I have not acquired at this point in my life. And people don't know that I do wear glasses - I'm Miss Coke Bottles.

http://barksmatt.tripod.com/Playboy.html

Val 15 Jun 2012, 02:15

Anon, if you want to learn more about the terms we use, you can read this text: http://bobbygoc.sweb.cz/all4eyes/terms.htm#optical posted on Bobby's site.

Extract: "Optic-obsessive/OO, term coined by Lenslover, Eye Scene website, Poll 22 (Other peoples glasses), 28 September, 1997: Person with a passion for eyeglasses/vision defects, also called Specs-, Glass- or Lens-aholic/Lenshound/Glassophile."

Yoyo 13 May 2012, 17:14

I think film and TV directors tend to prefer the plano lenses (or no lenses) because they don't have to deal with reflections from the lights. I know they have anti-reflective lenses these days, but real prescription lenses will still reflect something.

Lucas 13 May 2012, 15:39

I still do not understand why actresses who wear glasses in real life end up wearing plano glasses in movies. Also, even more frustrating, in New Girl, Zoey Deschannels seems to wear glasses with no lenses.

Val 13 May 2012, 15:07

These glasses seem to have plano lenses. I don't see any kind of distorsion through the lenses. But the frames suit her well.

As I recall Reese had a plus prescription, no more than +2 D.

In this movie she wore them coming into her office and giving the impression that she maybe needed them for driving as she soon took them off while looking at her computer. But after that she never ware them again for driving or seeing close up. I guess we are to assume she also wore contacts? But who knows?

 07 May 2012, 08:54

"Don't you have Google? - Sorry, but I had to ask. It took me 1,5 seconds to find that out."

Reasons why the post was an obvious insult, let's break it down simple:

- "Don't have Google?" :: Everyone has Google and the author knows that already.

- "Sorry but I had to ask" :: Realizing he was just being a smartass, the author said sorry.

- Took me 1,5 seconds :: Complaint that it took less time than to ask in the forum.

Please break down how this post could not be meant as an insult. I'd love to see your analysis.

Lv2c4i 07 May 2012, 08:44

Rashida Jones was featured on the "Who Do You Think You Are?" TV show this past Friday. The show has a celebrity explore her/his "family tree". Rashida appeared in 2 nearly identical frames--one all black and the other clear plastic--akin to what Dakota Fanning and Katherine Heigl wore in the posts below.

This TV show is a good place for celebrity sightings as the featured star is often seen reading records of births, deaths, etc.

An indian movie from a while back What's Your Rashee has my future wife (lol) Priyanka Chopra portraying a different girl from every sign of the zodiac. The reason being is that a guy is looking for a wife to marry within a month or something like that and decides try every sign, of course they all look like her ;) Anyhow she is a GWG for two of them.

Lv2c4i 14 Mar 2012, 11:42

On primetime TV in the USA, there are two more actresses who have been wearing glasses.

On "Harry's Law", actress Karen Olivo plays lawyer Cassie Reynolds and wears a very nice pair of spex for some of her courtroom scenes. This attractive woman is enhanced by these glasses.

On "Are you there, Chelsea", actress Ali Wong plays one of the girl buddies of the title character, and her character,a waitress in the bar where the show is set, wears her glasses all the time.

Both of these women wear contemporary glasses with very heavy brow rims, and no lower rims.

Soundmanpt 12 Mar 2012, 22:23

chrisb

So far it seems they have left her alone about wearing her glasses when she wants. As you say one can only hope some executive doesn't decide she shouldn't wear glasses on the show. But since the cat, so to say, has been out of the bag and she has been seen more than once wearing glasses it would now seem pointless to change now. Maybe this will lead to other shows letting their stars wear glasses as well. Really it sends a positive message to the many teens and pre-teens that watch her show that you can be beautiful and wear glasses if you need them. Actually she deserves an award for being a role model to youngsters that need glasses.

Revolver 16 Jan 2012, 16:48

I never watched the TV series Sex And The City originally because it was on HBO and I don't have that, but now it's on E! channel for free and is rerun a lot. They also showed the movie based on the series this weekend, and I realized the movie completed the GWG episodes as now all 4 of the ladies have worn glasses at least once.

Charlotte wears them quite often in the series, a very stylish small black rectangular frame and she looks great, but unfortunately they are plano.

Miranda wore them in only one episode, just before she got lasik and she was delighted because she couldn't function without contacts (she said) and the episode in the series was a lighthearted look at lasik. The frames were perfectly round gold metal, right out of the hippie 70's, but they too were plano.

Samantha fessed up to being 45 years old, and after surviving breast cancer was asked to speak to a group of survivors and both practicing her speech and delivering it she was wearing black half eye readers. Again, in the series.

And rounding it out, but not until the movie, was the only one who'd never been seen in glasses, Carrie. About 25 minutes in she brings a book of poetry to bed with Mr. Big who was now her husband, where he was reading with his glasses on. As the movie is set 10 years later than the series and is about where the ladies were at that time, she would be in her mid to late 40's. She gets in bed, reaches over and takes Mr. Big's black plastic men's frames (with a real plus rx)and puts them on to read. He said "young lady, you need to get your own glasses" and she replied "no I don't I have yours".

Any one of us would loved to have served as technical consultant to the series, we would have had all of them wearing real glasses...a lot!

Watching TV the other day I happened across the TV series "Victorious" starring Victoria Justice. Someone put a link on here a month or so ago of her wearing the same glasses in another episode. Good that they are not afraid to let an already attractive young lady wear glasses. It does make sense more than 65 % of the population wears correction of some kind now. hats off to whoever is allowing her to be seen as a real person that wears glasses.

Soundmanpt 20 Dec 2011, 11:32

Jan

I'm sure the reason they didn't want her to use her own real glasses was because they were much too cute. They were going for a dorky not attractive look and they probably only went into their prop room to find those glasses. Even though they spend millions to make a movie they didn't want to spend the money to have her real rx put into her glasses. We must remember that 99.9% of of the people seeing that movie would ever notice that her glasses were fakes. Her real glasses didn't appear to be very strong so she either did her scenes uncorrected or wore contacts. It seems that some of the few movies where a character wears glasses throughout they will sometimes spend the extra money to get the actors real rx made into the glasses to make it easier for her to do her scenes.

lv2c4i 22 Oct 2011, 07:49

Last Monday two actresses had an interesting conversation about glasses--men in glasses. It occurred on Regis and Kelly (think you tube may have a vid of it).

Actor Simon Baker (the Mentalist) had been the first guest and appeared wearing his glasses.

Then Jessica Capshaw came out (unfortunately bare-eyed) and noted that she'd run into Simon Baker backstage and that he was extremely attractive, especially with his glasses.

She went on to say that her husband had worn glasses when they first met but had then gotten lasik. Recently, she continued, he'd come home with glasses and she'd been all a-twitter saying she'd flirted like a schoolgirl.

Kelly Ripa quickly and emphatically agreed, saying her husband had recently gotten glasses and that she was finding him newly attractive as well. They both agreed that glasses made men very attractive.

Too bad they don't realize that that door "swings both ways" and so choose to wear their glasses more regularly.

I am not defending her because drinking or drugs may have played a part as well. But I would fell bad for her if this ruins her acting career and it is only because she needed glasses.

Melyssa 20 Sep 2011, 07:11

Re: Helena Bonham Carter and her two pairs of glasses:

When I was in the hospital early in the previous decade, there was a nursing assistant around my age who wore oval metal frames all the time. Hanging from a chain around her neck was a pair of very large, pink, plastic square frames. The metal frames had minus lenses, while the plastic frames had plus lenses. When doing close work, which was the norm with patients, she wore both pairs, with the plastic glasses in front of the metal ones, saying that it was the only way she could see what she was doing with me (and others) properly, and that she could not afford bifocals, so this was her way of compensating.

Tom 16 Jun 2011, 03:44

Smudgeur:

what I mean is that the glasses are real but Ornella don't actually need them in her real life, neither they fit her behaviour (the character is that of a strongly nearsighted woman, while glasses are mildly positive, I mean). In this sense I wrote they are not real.

I'd have preferred a GOC actress wearing strong minus lenses when requested by the story and forced to play as a REAL shortsighted when not wearing them.

I saw the whole movie years ago and there are several scenes of her having troubles to see or wearing glasses. I remember one in which she put on a pair of glasses that are not her own and actually see for the first time the face of the man she is dating with! It recalls the other great movie "How to marry a millionaire".

Katja Rieman in "Die RelativitÃ¤tdtheorie der Liebe":

She plays all the five characters and one of them "Peggy" is supposed to be quite a wallflower. She said in the interview: Since I got -6 diopters myself, I only had to ask the optician for the cheapest and worst lenses. I don`t find her very attractive in that role, but at least that's the proper way to do it; instead of wearing contacts, props on top and play "blind", like so many other examples in movie history.

Lv2c4i 26 Apr 2011, 08:56

It seems that the moving has begun--with respect to fashion and frame styles. Moving from the basic (and bold) wayfarer frame, bit by bit, to more fashioned variations of the bold and black styles.

Anne Hathaway's spex are rounded, Jennifer Aniston's are also more sculpted, as are Emily Blount's.

Seems the boldness previously morphed both with respect to shape and color...will everything old be new again?

Jan, re: Anne Hathaway, if her left lens is stronger than her right then a photo I have found of her which is a side profile revealing some protuding lens thickness from her right lens, will be all the more obvious, and thicker in her left lens. http://www.flickr.com/photos/sexygirlswithglasses/

It certainly doesn't seem very Hollywood to be revealing lens thickness where everyone is obsessed with their looks, but what a joy for us seasoned 0-0 watchers to see a young mainstream actress wearing large prescription glasses like these. Hopefully others will follow suit.

And that's why most optical stores--online and otherwise--have dozens and hundreds of frames ranging, as we know, from the darkest, nerdiest frames to rimless styles.

Folks have different and varied tastes: viva la difference'.

I think Lucy Lui's glasses look very nice, maybe not her best choice of all, but a fine choice nonetheless.

And, with my preferences, I'm glad they are not the nerdiest style that many celebs are choosing these days.

still 11 Feb 2011, 13:12

Thanks! Since my Latin is very weak anyway, I'll wait for your next version.

Pseldonymov 10 Feb 2011, 13:00

The original of this text is in Latin:

Hospita in Gallia

nunc me vocant studia.

Vadam ergo,

flens a tergo

socios relinquo.

Plangite, discipuli!

lugubris discidii

tempore propinquo.

O consortes studii,

deprecor, valete!

Quos benigne colui,

filii, dolete!

Classem solvo litore,

remigo, videte:

proficisco peregre,

socium deflete!

Versibus elegicis

coetum discipulorum

commendo cum lacrimis

iam Deo deorum:

foveat et protegat

magnos cum pusillis,

custodiat et maneat

perenniter cum illis!

Rorate, mea lumina,

super gregem meum;

si concedent numina,

revisitabo eum,

et, sicut a principio,

super hunc regnabo,

si non in exilio

miser expirabo.

Vale, dulcis patria,

suavis Suevorum Suevia!

Salve dilecta Francia,

philosophorum curia!

Suscipe discipulum

in te peregrinum;

quem post dierum circulum

remittes Socratinum.

In manus eius animam

et spiritum commendo,

qui se dedit in victimam

pro me redimendo

et verus innotuit

Deus resurgendo,

de Bosra tinctis vestibus

coelos ascendendo.

Duplex est divisio:

una substantiarum,

quae fit in hoc discidio,

sed non animarum.

Vobiscum sum, dum vixero,

spiritu praesente,

licet absens abero

corpore, non mente.

Ad urbem sapientiae

denuo festino;

spiritus scientiae

assit peregrino;

visitet, illuminet

mentem imperitam,

ut mysticam sufficiam

mercari margaritam.

But the Russian translation is so far of the literal one.

Soon I will translate the Russian text into English.

still 08 Feb 2011, 21:20

Slit 06 Jan 2011, 00:29

Whoo bollywood!

Well,

I am half proud and half ashamed. Jacqueline Fernandez used to be Miss Sri Lanka (I am proud of this, as a Sri Lankan)and now she tried to blend in to Indian community saying "now i feel like native Mumbaikar!" - (which I am not proud of...any person should not forget thy roots!)

Anyways, about her glasses. Before she became miss Sri lanka, she used to be a presenter on Lanka Business Online program, where she wore low minus glasses apparently. She seem to have the "specs appeal" and she is one of those girls with open mind to accept specs.

However, I must add (after travelling all over india), she does not have that much place in hearts of Indians, whereas true Sri Lankan cricket players such as Sanath Jayasooriya, Kumar Sangakkara and Aravinda De Silva has left pleasant memories in hearts of Indians.

Melyssa 03 Jan 2011, 06:48

For lack of a better category, I'm entering it here. Last week I was watching Match Game '75, and I'm paraphrasing what Brett Somers said (to the best of my knowledge from what I could hear), "The second tier is a walking advertisement for people who look pretty in glasses." Well, the three people she referred to were all on the upper deck there -- herself, Charles Nelson Reilly, and Allen Ludden. With those ravaging beauties, that was not exactly a ringing endorsement for wearing glasses, that's for sure.

Soundmanpt 13 Nov 2010, 11:15

I have found watching "Ghost Hunters" more entertaining than ever. There are 2 attractive young ladies on the show and both wear glasses in most episodes. Last week they did a marathone of all the past shows up to the most recent. The one young lady Chris never wore glasses for the first season even when driving, but the second season she was wearing glasses full time. It could be she had contacts the first year or maybe got glasses during the break in the show? The other girl wears hers about 75% of the time, but always for seeing close and most of the time for distance as well.

Soundmanpt 13 Nov 2010, 11:06

Melyssa

You are really an expert on that show. You got me beat. I know I remember seeing several pictures of Christine Applegate out and about wearing glasses on several occasions.But nothing in recent years.

Melyssa 13 Nov 2010, 09:58

Soundmanpt,

That episode, in the spring of 1995, was the one in which Al and Kelly made a "shoe-cumentary" called "Sheos." There were 4 women (Vena being one of them) in bikinis in the shoe store in the latter part of the show while Al was filming them. (And the producers never called me to appear in it, probably because I wear glasses! LOL)

As for Kelly, she wore metal frames a couple of times when trying to appear intelligent or scientific.

Lv2c4i 12 Nov 2010, 08:03

As it always seems to happen, the frame designers seem to be finding ways to "dress up" the basic "nerd glasses" that are appearing more and more frequently on celebrities. Shenae's glasses have a little metallic detail over the bridge, Sandra Bullock's have added shape and color, and the very wide temples seem to also be appearing more and more.

And I find the embellished styles more attractive than the basic old style frames. Keep 'em coming.

Adalle 30 Oct 2010, 07:07

2 weeks ago the new TV movie of Scooby Doo was released. A new actress, Hayley Kiyoko, plays Velma in this. There is only one scene where Velma drops her glasses and starts cleaning them thoroughly. In this scene I noticed the glasses must have been prescription. And so it is. It appears Hayley Kiyoko has a mild prescription and the producers decided she should wear real glasses instead of contacts over plano glasses.

Here are two behind the scenes clips. In one she wears her real glasses.

Lv2c4i 02 Oct 2010, 07:37

Yesterday (October 1), "Live with Regis and Kelly" had one of the occasional "choosing the right glasses" segments. Kelly Ripa wore a pair of glasses for part of the segment. It was unclear whether she was wearing her own, but she made several comments regarding her experience as a glasses wearer. And they had several models to whom they gave an "eyewear make-over", improving their appearance by giving them frame styles/shapes appropriate to their face shape.

pete 23 Sep 2010, 11:38

I just saw a recent indie film called (UNTITLED) featuring the young attractive blonde Marley Shelton as a highbrow art gallery owner. Her character wears a variety of glasses to help define her 'look'. In one scene her lover (alone in her flat) is intrigued by a carousel-like display of her glasses- maybe a dozen pairs. He picks up a pair and looks through the lenses only to discover that they are plano. That aspect was a bit disappointing but I was intrigued that the wearing of glasses played a significant part in the film.
