ehpc 31 Jul 2010, 21:15

Make sure you are not dependent on 'Social Security' Melyssa !!!

Melyssa 31 Jul 2010, 08:55

Soundmanpt,

In 12+ years it's my turn to cash in on a fabulous $3.50-per-month Social Security check -- $4.00 if you include the work pension. :) I guess I should have posted that it was the women of the advanced ages that were snatching up all of the good frames, leaving us 20-somethings with less selections, all the while flooding the banks on the 3rd day of every month, even after 3:00. "What's that, sonny?"

Soundmanpt 31 Jul 2010, 08:49

Melyssa

Hey go easy on us Social Security people. I promise to leave you have all the big frames you want.

Melyssa 31 Jul 2010, 08:30

While the place I deal with sometimes gets large enough frames, it's still rare. Every other optical place in my area has frames half the size (height, width, depth) of what would fit me comfortably. And even if major actresses and TV newswomen were to start wearing large frames, leave it to the Social Security Set to buy up all of the good frames and make the younger women shy away from them, just like with the drop-temples in the 1980s. Sure I would not wish for that to happen, but reality bites.

Soundmanpt 31 Jul 2010, 08:18

Daffy you are soooo right. I go into many optical shops each week and I have looked and asked about bigger style frames for women and at least here in the middle of the USA not one store carries anything like Miss Lucas is wearing. All seem to be rectangle frames. Even the younger women that work in the stores wish they would become available.

Yes and I think it is great that more and more TV and movie stars are being photographed wearing glasses. Not too many years ago stars would go out of their way to avoid being pictured wearing glasses. Seeing stars wearing glasses will make it cool for many young people to not be so shy about needing glasses.

nickweymouth 31 Jul 2010, 07:57

 05 Jul 2010, 08:26

i think you are imagining/fantasizing the redness; it isn't there when i click on zoom.

btw, redness can indicate any number of things that have nothing to do with glasses.

Soundmanpt 04 Jul 2010, 10:43

If you double click on her pictures, there is clearly a redness under her eyes. This sometimes happens to someone getting and adjusting to wearing glasses. Her glasses seem to fit very well on the nose and overall. Prop glasses often don't fit that well. I think she's wearing a mild rx and they may be new.

Clare 12 Jun 2010, 08:54

Emma - I think if someone finds a look that really suits them then it can make a huge difference. Emma 12 Jun 2010, 06:08

Soundmanpt - with your posts to Hollie and Clare.........I think some people just aren't too comfortable wearing glasses. Sometimes that's physically uncomfortable not just cosmetically. Yes, contacts can get uncomfortable but glasses just don't feel right on some people and they can't get used to wearing them FT no matter how much they might want to. With me it's not liking the feeling of them on my face and also the sense that you're looking at the world through a window, being able to see the edge of the frames. It's just how it is, no matter how attractive find they glasses ;-) And that includes me, I'm no glasses hater lol!! I think there's something going on with the desire to wear glasses v. not liking wearing glasses that makes the obsession stronger..........

Hollie 10 Jun 2010, 13:47

I've been wearing lenses most of the time recently but doesn't mean I can't appreciate glasses- I think they look brilliant on some people but not on me sadly. Plus I broke my current glasses and am wearing an old pair- actually black plastic!- that I'm not as confident in. If I were to ever make the jump to wearing glasses most of the time, would have to find that amazing pair, much like cheryls I think! A girl at work has lovely brown and black plastic designer statement frames and suits them perfectly- she's not quite a full time wearer but enough of a prescription that they are usually on her face or desk at work rather than in her handbag.

Clare 10 Jun 2010, 12:18

I think Cheryl's really suit her.

Soundmanpt 09 Jun 2010, 20:51

Hollie - Sorry i'm not sure how we got in the "Actress" thread.

Have you found any glasses that you like yet? When you have a minute go back and look at "Seen on the Web" find Crystal Veil May 31 23:16 scroll down and you will see many glasses he has used on his models all from zenni. There is also a lot of vintage glasses as well.

Soundmanpt 09 Jun 2010, 20:43

Clare - Yes of course I agree with you. The thing to remember the easiest things to do to change ones looks is either adding glasses or taking them away. They are not likely to put glasses on someone that didn't wear glasses, but the other way makes more sense to them. Think about it, your a blonde with long hair and glasses. You would look different very quickly if they colored your hair to brown and cut it short with a different style and removed your glasses. People you work with may not recognize you. It is true that glasses do change ones look, it's just that I don't think they make anyone more or less attractive. These shows go for dramatic changes. I have seen a few of these shows where they actually did just upgrade the glasses on someone. But most of the time they do seem to go away rather quickly.

By the way I am surprised your on the same side of the fence as us guys that want you ladies to wear your glasses. I would have thought you would be the one leading the charge for them to rip those glasses off those ladies and stick them contacts in. How did that happen??? Are you feeling OK???

Luv ya Clare!!

Melyssa 09 Jun 2010, 12:54

Clare,

Naturally I agree. If it were up to me, these so-called makeover shows would be made over with everyone with less-than-stellar vision wearing glasses. Of course, the women's frames would be big, bold, and beautiful plastic frames, 1980s-style. :)

Clare 09 Jun 2010, 11:57

Good to see attractive females like Cheryl wearing glasses, no matter what the strength. I'm always irked when the TV makeover shows (Gok's Fashion Fix last night was classic) always 'improve' someone's look by removing their glasses. I never know whether they just get them to go without them or if they convert them to contacts, whatever they do I wish they wouldn't - if they're a glasses wearer they should just get them to invest in a new style. Does anyone else agree?

kisal 18 Apr 2010, 18:37

Not really an "actress," since it's only a cartoon, but I just loved the scene in the movie "Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs" where the cute young woman _puts on_ her glasses for the first time and the man tells her something like "you were nice looking before, but nothing like the amazing way you look now." And the character wears her glasses for the rest of the movie. The woman is a newscaster and the anchor makes fun of the way she looks in glasses, but he's the one made out to be a buffoon for his attitude. If only there were ever a live actress film with a similar scenario, it would be one for the ages...

gwgs 15 Apr 2010, 07:57

Aubrac 14 Mar 2010, 12:11

dave

The photo is not best quality and on blowing it up could not tell.

Very ofter glasses seen from front view don't seem to be prescription but from behind there is often a +1 or +2 with cylinder that is easily noticeable.

Could be the case here as more and more girls with low plus scrips are now wearing glasses.

On Jewelry Television (JTV), Misty Mills is on most weekend afternoons (at least noon to 4:00 EST) and some weekday afternoons. James 20 Feb 2010, 02:59

Friday night on BBC 3 there was a special programme called EastEnders Live The Aftermath. All about the special live episode of EastEnders that was shown on BBC 1 earlier. Most of the Aftermath programme was live with some recorded interviews with cast and crew. 2 of the female cast were wearing glasses in their recorded interviews (have not seen either of them wear glasses before either in the show or in real life). One was 17 year old Melissa Suffield who plays Lucy Beale and the other was 32 year old Rita Simons who plays Roxy Mitchell. the programme can be seen again only in the UK via the BBC iPlayer http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00qym8y/EastEnders_Live_The_Aftermath/

Melissa can be seen at 7mins 32secs. Rita is at 19mins 6secs.

Can't work out what sort of prescription Melissa has but Rita's looks like a minus.

avaitor -oo- 31 Dec 2009, 17:04

First, a very happy 2010 to everyone here.

I've just watched the Woody Allen film 'Annie Hall' on DVD. There has been discussion here before about whether Allen is a gwg fan. Looking at the run-down of characters in 'Annie Hall' there is some evidence of this; whilst most of the girls in glasses appear with plano lenses, there is a notable exception close to the end of the film. This is Robin Mary Paris. There is a picture of her here, as seen in the film, but sadly it is only a very small image. Have a look at the film, and you'll see a lovely girl wearing large clear-plastic aviators, with a script of at least -3.

http://images.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://cineclap.free.fr/annie-hall/robin-mary-paris.jpg&imgrefurl;=http://cineclap.free.fr/%3Ffilm%3Dannie-hall%26page%3Dpersonnages&usg;=__Y69KSCvLxqkZObt_JqTEJK2qVuA=&h;=100&w;=100&sz;=3&hl;=en&start;=2&um;=1&tbnid;=bO6VSgl4IbrQZM:&tbnh;=82&tbnw;=82&prev;=/images%3Fq%3D%2522robin%2Bmary%2Bparis%2522%26ndsp%3D20%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Doff%26sa%3DN%26um%3D1

chrisb 25 Dec 2009, 15:36

Just watched night at the museum 2. The love interest is the actress Amy Adams playing a very sexy Amelia Earhart, with a very tight bum in jodphurs. At the end of film, the actress /character re-appears as a visitor to the museum but this time with glasses that look like they have a real RX. A nice inversion of the glasses/no glasses transition.

In Amy Adams' previous film Julie and Julia she appears with 2 different frames for close work. IMDB has clips of these sections of the film.

Maybe a GWG in real life?

Anyway, Amy Adams bears a striking resemblance to my 20 year old Son's current GF so, I'm off for a cold shower.

Speximann 24 Nov 2009, 14:44

Sorry Mike, one BIG draw back to free image linking is the ads. Image Venue (& maybe Image Shack) throw that Adult Friend Finder window up there. I just let it load then X it out, but you can still hear the chic talking after. Once the ad is closed out you can just click on the Enter of the opaque image and you can view it along with others. Also, sorry again, the first image you open will also open an Amature Sex Webcam ad. I just close these out and they usualy don't come back for the remainder of the visit.

kisal 10 Nov 2009, 05:50

Yesterday I went to see the new film "(Unitled)"

http://www.untitled-themovie.com/

Beautiful actress Marley Shelton plays Madeleine Gray, the female lead, and she is bespectacled for >90% of the film, while kissing, while starting to undress, while wearing the most incredibly sexy outfits. She has a "glasses tree" in her apartment, and wears at least four different pairs at various times, all either black or white frames, constituting an important part of her "look". Also the male lead (played by handsome Adam Goldberg also wears black-rimmed specs at times as do several minor characters. And it's a well-done film about art as well. I would HIGHLY recommend it!

Two warnings though: (1), the film is an independent American film, so unlikely to show outside a major city -- many of you will probably have to wait for DVD, (2) the glasses are definitely plano -- there is even one scene which makes that quite clear. So those who like only thickness will be disappointed, but those like me, who are excited mostly by frames will be in heaven. Although the glasses are not specifically part of the plot, I think the characters choice to wear them is symbolic of her choosing to make her face a framed work of art.

I think Kaho's glasses was her first pair with prescriptions. She does not wear glasses earlier that year, but later had an eye check figured out she was nearsighted, according to her blog.

Anyway, she could still barely pass off as wearing plano at such angle. Tilted glasses! and she was too excited.

http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h282/dasneravo/face/mkk_frame_0027.gif

http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h282/dasneravo/face/mkk_frame_0028.gif

the distortion of her right lens is now clearly seen, clearly not plano. Not too low for a first prescription. She must be struggling to see the board in class before.

http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h282/dasneravo/face/mkk_frame_0029.gif

Lv2c41 25 Sep 2009, 04:49

The start of a new TV season always offers new opportunities for sightings of characters/actresses wearing glasses or updated styles.

The ABC show, Eastwick, features Lindsay Price as a reporter who wears her glasses much of the time. She could use a more stylish frame choice.

Also interesting is that in her former show, NBC's Lipstick Jungle, Price never wore spex, but her two co stars did. Kim Raver often wore stylish glasses and very occasionally Brooke Shields was shown wearing spex for desk work and reading.

Adalle 22 Sep 2009, 15:50

That scene from the Emmy awards was a joke. All the nominees except Vanessa Williams wore some kind of funny eyewear (monocle, reading glasses, etc.)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Atb0dJcNy98

tv 22 Sep 2009, 14:26

During the Emmys on Sunday Sept 20, Elizabeth Perkins was one of the best actress nominees. As the nominees were announced and shown in the audience, Elizabeth was wearing what appeared to be myodiscs. Very strong minus prescription in any case. Once the winner (not her) was announced, she took them off.

Melyssa 28 Jul 2009, 09:57

Having just seen the pictures of those actresses, I would say that the vast majority of them need lessons in choosing frames -- that is, if any of them besides Lisa Loeb really do wear prescription glasses.

Dieter 28 Jul 2009, 06:27

Fans of plus lenses should check out new episodes of "The Closer" on TNT in the US. As she has for years, Kyra Sedgwick wears sharp-looking black plastic frames which she uses as a presbyope. New this season is a character played by Mary McDonnell in a recurring role about every other episode. She switches between pairs of glasses depicting a presbyopic hyperope occasionally having one pair hanging on her shirt while wearing the others. Both use their glasses in realistic ways, their lenses are obviously real, and they are fun to watch.

Jan 17 Mar 2009, 11:41

Rockville, ca. Full episodes:

http://www.thewb.com/shows/rockville-ca

Link will only work inside the US. I had to fool it with a proxy. Worked for me, since I´m in europe.

Strange format for a series: It`s basically promotion for a lot of mediocre emo and mainstream rockbands, but the director is suspected to be one of us. Cute Deb is quite nearsighted (in the -5 area i guess) and the makers of the show seem to enjoy that. Huge geek-girl/emo scene stereotype, but this time no props and no stupid use of specs. I didn't like the show itself, but the OO-factor is as high and as realistic as it gets- imho. Let´s hope it`ll take a couple of webisodes till they decide, she has to get contacts.

Andy 11 Mar 2009, 05:33

And.. towards the end of the 2nd third of the movie, after Martha (Debra Winger) stabbed this guy, dying he grabs her glasses. They are broken at the bridge. Later in the movie when Martha is at the police station her sister has a big argument with the officers to get matha's glasses back. When she has them back, they are fixed with a tape. Later in the movie she wears wire rimmed glasses which look a lot thicker. There is one shot during the movie with a good shot through her glasses. I liked the movie quite a lot because it is very consistent glasses wise.

Speximann 08 Mar 2009, 08:27

Hey everybody, I have been following this site for a long time as with most of you. This discussion has merit from both sides. While I understand the fetish attraction of glasses, I also equaly understand the concerns about minors & posting of pictures on this site. Sometimes it is a hard judgement call as there are alot of pix of young girls (presumably collage age) that are constantly poping up. Are they improper? If I had a kid that age with their pic posted here how would I feel? All viable concerns. Maybe we all should ask ourselves these Questions when we get here. I took the post of the SJP/young lady pic pretty much as the poster said he intended & still thought she might be a little young to be thrown here. I may have done the same in the past not really thinking from all sides. Bottom line, we all should just spend a little time to think as we share, but please don't stop sharing, that's what this site is. that's my dime, nuff said. Thanks

Therouteur 08 Mar 2009, 01:10

On your side Daffy. And last time I saw Sarah Jessica PArker was of age. Ugly as sin but well of age.

daffy 06 Mar 2009, 16:10

When i posted 'the link' my intension was to show that big glasses from the 80's style are coming back. What intrigued me even more was the fact that younger people were not embarassed but rather 'flaunting' the choice in their frame selection.

Without making further comment to flame the situation further...nuf said.

Traveller 06 Mar 2009, 11:33

Let us consider the facts here.

An eyescene user has chosen to post a link to a website that has highlighted the style choice of the 12 year old daughter of a celebrity. The 'Who' magazine article seems to be perfectly responsible in its content and I have no doubt that it may have been of some help to a few parents who have had to deal with their own children being prescribed glasses recently.

I understand the concerns expressed below however this site is very broad in scope. People come here for all sorts of reasons - because they are curious about glasses, because they have been prescribed glasses, because their parents, partners, children, work colleagues etc. wear glasses, because they want glasses and in some cases because they are 'turned on' by glasses.

I would like to think that the vast majority of users of this site are mature enough to consider the material and links that are posted in a mature, sensible way and to consider the context in which they appear.

I would also like to think that even in these dangerous times the majority of us are capable of making sensible judgements without needing others to make the judgements for us.

Moonshiner 06 Mar 2009, 10:05

FaNaTiKX 25 Feb 2009, 13:04

If you're not able to save the pic with Firefox

Click on Tools, Page Info, Media tab and you will have all pictures from the page, just select the one you want in the list and save it.

til 25 Feb 2009, 12:02

I'm using firefox. Just tried it with the IE but doesn't work either. Maybe my computer just refuses me these pleasures ;)

thanks anyway

gwgs 25 Feb 2009, 08:54

Which browser are you using (Internet Explorer, Firefox?).

I'm using Internet Explorer and it works for me - this is the standard way of saving an image although some website insert some 'javascript' to disable this function.

If they have simply press the "print scrn" or "print screen" button on your keyboard. This will copy the print off of the page to your computers clipboard/memory and you can then open your designated photo editing/image viewing programme and trim the image down to size and save it.

Let me know if you have any more trouble and I can post them on one of my websites;

http://www.flickr.com/spexyissexy

http://www.flickr.com/gwg_fan

til 25 Feb 2009, 08:05

gwgs - didn't work for me apart from the first one

FaNaTiKX - thank you

gwgs 25 Feb 2009, 03:33

til - simply right click with your mouse select "save picture as"!

DWV 16 Feb 2009, 00:51

Actresses may not be strictly correct, since this film is a documentary. "Sherman's March" (1986) was filmed in the early to mid-80s, and is a must-see for anyone who likes big '80s frames with strong prescriptions. Winnie, a cute linguist gets a lot of screen time about one hour into the film, but there's a briefer close-up of a young mother with equally big and thick glasses nearer the end (when the filmmaker catches up with Burt Reynolds on the set of Stroker Ace).

Karen X 05 Jan 2009, 20:59

Felicity Jones is wearing prescription glasses in "The Diary of Anne Frank" on BBC1 all this week. She is playing Anne's sister Margot. See a picture here http://www.bbc.co.uk/annefrank/biogs/margotfrank.shtml (bottom half of the page) The frames definitely look 1940s with lowish minus lenses.

I didn't know Felicity wore glasses as there don't seem to be any photos of her wearing them. She is very attractive, although the 1940s clothes and hairstyle in the series are not very flattering.

The series is on at 7:00pm every day this week on BBC1 and on the BBC HD channel. Each episode will also be available on the BBC IPlayer within a few hours of broadcast. Here is a link to episode 1 which has several good shots of Felicity in the glasses (she wears them full time in the series, just as Margot Frank did in real life) http://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00gndt1/The_Diary_of_Anne_Frank_Episode_1/ Unfortunately the BBC IPlayer will only work in the UK. Maybe a UK Eyescene reader will be able to get some still pictures and video clips of Felicity in glasses that are available internationally.

ilovepretzels 05 Dec 2008, 16:51

The actor that plays Danny on CSI:NY just did an interview and the interviewers very first question was "Where did the glasses go?!" and he said that it was part of 'evolving' the character and it was time for a change. He said that it may or may not be permanent and they were giving it a whirl to see what would happen.

He is very aware though that the fans are not happy about the absence of his glasses. In fact, he finds it almost humorous how attached some are to them being part of his character.

VFL 05 Dec 2008, 14:03

That's it. I'm officially in mourning and wearing black eyeglass frames along with my widow's weeds. Danny from CSI: NY appears to have ditched his glasses for good. Why? Why? Why?

Darn it to heck anyway.

pelegrino 05 Dec 2008, 12:15

I think Penelopé Cruz is one of us...recently she was talking about her upcoming movie (directed by Woody Allen) and said in an interview: "He is one of the most respected directors, yet not everybody likes him. Woody Allens movies have this sophisticated humor with the edge of darkness that mostly reflects into one of the movies characters.

Penelope Cruz who starts in his latest movie Vicky Cristina Barcelona, is that persona and she likes Woody, as she says:

Everyone loves him in that crew and I got his glasses as a present the last day and I will treasure them. He only had two and he gave me one."

She also said that she would replace the lenses so that she could see with her own rx...fantastic!!!!

Filthy McNasty 03 Dec 2008, 07:32

Wurm and Galileo are right. I have seem non-Rx sunglasses that distort similarly when viewed from the wrong (or right) angle. These glasses are pure prop. I think the director wanted the impression of serious vision problems, but didn't want the actor's eyes to be distorted as they would be with high plus or minus (see, for example, that little no-neck gnome in "Everything is Illuminated").

Wurm 02 Dec 2008, 19:36

Yes, those appear to be props. Far better than most prop glasses we've seen in the movies, though.

Apparently her eyesight figures into the plot.

Huge photo here:

http://www.allmoviephoto.com/photo/2008_henry_poole_is_here_002_big.html

Galileo 02 Dec 2008, 18:22

I agree she looks pretty. If you check out some of the other U-tube clips it gives a flavour of the story and where her glasses fit in.

I think they contain no power at all. Her eyes look the same size to me glasses on or off. Any thick piece of glass/plastic will show distortion when viewed from an angle, even if it is plano.

lazysiow 02 Dec 2008, 13:03

I think she's very pretty in those :)

til 02 Dec 2008, 11:40

I think it's just another example of the glasses wearing girl from hollywood. The director may have wanted thick glasses for her so an optician made thick lenses without prescription. Because of the thickness of the lenses it appears to be light to moderate plus from the front but if you look closely at 0:59 in the video you see the distotion which might be possible for light minus or non prescription, but definitely not for plus.

Another thing is that she handles the stuff he wants to buy too easy for a heavy plus prescription, she'd see nothing but the colours if she had normal eyesight.

Slit 02 Dec 2008, 10:42

re: the thick glasses of girl in henry pool.

I am ptretty sure they are + prescription, thought from sides it looks minus.

What i believe is that lense is constructed in a way that effective power is plus.

The distortion on ceiling is much to plus side.

And IMPORTANT:

there isnt any cut in which should definitely be there in these glasses if they are minus!

Linuxer 02 Dec 2008, 08:31

Very thick but doesn't contain any power.

Correction 02 Dec 2008, 07:22

Her glasses clearly are NOT fake. Take a look at the scene again and when they show her from behind while she is talking, you can see the distortion of the ceiling lights through her glasses.

gwgs 02 Dec 2008, 07:20

I actually would disagree with the last posters comments as you can see the lenses are plus and her eyes are magnified, the thickness of them is extremely "interesting"!

Dieter 23 Sep 2008, 05:52

I read an article about Tina Fey when she was first "discovered" on SNL. She was then the head writer when she was cast to read the "news". They did screen tests with and without her glasses and it was agreed that she fit the part best when wearing. She has a very week prescription for myopia and seldom wore glasses in public back then which worked great because nobody reconized her in those days without without her "trademark" when out and about.

I watched the movie "Definitely, Maybe" today and I must say i was surprised. The main character Will Hayes (Ryan Reynolds) admits he "loves long-haired brunettes

with horn-rimmed glasses". Later on he first meets with Summer Hartley (Rachel Weisz) a long-haired brunette but without glasses.

After a couple of years he meets her again and this time she wears horn-rimmed glasses which obviously intrigues him and he comments on her glasses.

There are quite a few scenes of her with glasses on. Here is a photo I found

http://www.imdb.com/media/rm2519111680/nm0001838

Tried them. I don't like! Makes you feel like your lenses melted!

Curt 20 May 2008, 12:55

gwgs: Some people just cannot deal with the distortion on the edges of no-line/progressive lenses. Some folks get totally nauseated when they turn their head and get the "swim" effect in there peripheral vision. The stronger the add, the more pronounced the distortion. Vanity has a price...

lazysiow 17 Apr 2008, 08:45

Born in malaysia, grew up in australia (lots of Indians), now live in the US and work in software (even more Indians) lol

I've never had much of an interest in Indian girls and in general when meeting Indians and some other Western Europeans, intially there is a bit of a common "studious immigrant" ground between us. After a few weeks getting to know me though, I'm usually too "wild" and "american" for most in their eyes so I would think my compatibility with Indian girls is already pretty low though.

Hence why I've gravitated to latinas. Actually there is quite a myth about them being "loose". Maybe the ones that were born and grew up in the US but actual latinas are more conservative than Asians, in Brazil etc. I.e. several dates chaperoned by mother, approval from family, friends, coworkers and the whole time, no holding hands, snuggling, kissing etc of any sort. Real latinas are like good girl/sexy girl in one :D

On the other hand I am looking forward to letting the few Indian friends that I still have know of my new attraction. I imagine there'll be quite some ribbing at my expense ;)

Slit 17 Apr 2008, 06:08

Lazyisow,

Well, I am not fully qualified to talk about the glasses wearing habits of indian girls because i have not been to india.

But i have been to Bangladesh in 2005.

What i can say is that traditionally, the girls with glasses were looked down upon and many rural girls still hate glasses.

But in the city, i am seeing that many girls are adopting glasses as a fashion accessory.

However, there is a boom in the contact lense market. But in my case, i always spot the contact lenses in the eyes of a girl. So if you want to date an indian/sri lankan girl with glasses, you still have the opportunity.

But the difficulty about dating here is the negative attitude towards one night stands or quick fix dates. Best thing is approaching to professional relationship and later moving in to her comfort zone.

Its interesting that you are somewhat aware about south asian region. may i ask where you live?

Slit 17 Apr 2008, 06:08

But in the city, i am seeing that many girls are adopting glasses as a fashion accessory.

All4Eyes 16 Apr 2008, 16:45

Aside from this movie, all I know about Bjork is the time she showed up at one of the awards shows in a dress that had a swan's (?) head over her shoulder. Very bizarre. If she was looking to "make a statement" (read: do something unusual and attention-getting) she should have just worn her thick glasses. Then the fashion vultures would have spent the next day just questioning her eyesight, instead of her sanity (the former's the lesser of the 2 "evils", if you ask me, even from a non-OO POV, which I admit I find hard to attain, esp. where thick lenses in black plastic are involved 8;-) ). BTW, does anyone know whether Bjork wears glasses (thick or not) or contacts in real life?

I ALWAYS make passes at guys (and maybe the occasional girl in thick black plastics *sighs and shudders*) who wear glasses, Marie

All4Eyes 16 Apr 2008, 16:45

Does anyone else remember a movie called "Dancing in the dark", starring singer Bjork? She played a Czech girl who worked in a factory, even though she was very myopic and going blind and really shouldn't have been, but who wanted to be a dancer and was taking dancing lessons. I didn't quite understand all of the storyline (I only saw portions of it, which I'm sure did not help), but I think part of it was she had a son who also had eye problems and needed an operation, which she was working to earn money for, but she wound up stealing from the family she and her son lived with and got caught and...well, I did grasp this much, it doesn't end well. There were also some rather surrealistic song-and-dance numbers, I guess the idea was to portray Bjork's character as somewhat daydream prone and give us a glimpse into her fantasy life? Anyway, I really do have to give Bjork props for her acting as it related to her character being partially sighted. She didn't do the cheesy, obvious, "arms stretched out in front of me to feel where I'm going" kind of portrayal of blindness. I've known a few people who were either partially or totally blind, and I can assure you, they do not behave this way! It was good that she did it in such a subtle, classy way because 1. She remembered she was only partially blind and still had some sight and 2. Even people who are totally blind aren't usually very obvious about it, if they have been blind for some time, anyway, and had a chance to adjust. There was one scene where she is sitting at a table having coffee and as she pours herself a cup, you can see if you're observant that she has one of her fingers inside the rim of the cup to feel when to stop pouring. But she does it in such an easy, casual way, that you would hardly notice if you weren't paying very close attention. The other thing is, her glasses in this movie are thick, the edges come out of their black plastic frame (MMMM! I know, I'm straight, but I don't care, thick lenses in a black plastic frame, MMMM! *sighs and shudders*), but I can't quite figure out the rx on them. There does definitely appear to be some minus power, you can see some minification, but I didn't really notice any power rings or much cut-in (though I realize certain camera angles don't show these effects). They certainly don't look as strong as you'd expect lenses of that thickness to be, but then this was (I think) the pre-high-index era and since the lens edges were "frosted" (not polished) they probably looked a little thicker than they really were.

aviator -oo- 16 Apr 2008, 12:06

Marisa Petroro wearing glasses (planoes?) Article states: Many people complain that Priyanka Chopra has an attitude problem and refuses to acknowledge people in parties! However the actress dismisses this and even has an explanation for her so called attitude. Actually her excuse mmm I mean defense is that she is short-sighted and doesn't like wearing contacts or glasses.

lazysiow 07 Apr 2008, 06:41

I just watched Snake Eyes after a mad fiending for Carla Gugino that just came out of the blue. I remember her vividly because of this movie and how much it tickled my OO-ness back when I was a teen.

For those that haven't seen it, she plays a highly shortsighted girl who gets embroiled in a conspiracy, her glasses get crushed in the beginning of the movie and throughout the rest of the movie, a lot of time is spent on how little she sees and how she copes squinting and groping her way through. There are some great out of focus nearsighted from her POV shots as well as some very convincing and amazing squinting on her part.

However the best came for last, during the ending she has finally got a new pair of glasses but amazingly, they look like a myopic prescription as well and similar to the strength that would be required for what was shown in the movie. You can see it here. http://img144.imageshack.us/my.php?image=vlcsnap2300154gl8.png

Now my question is, does she wear glasses irl (ive not seen her in them anywhere else) or is De Palma a real stickler for the OO details similar to De Niro

til 21 Jan 2008, 12:05

some little information:

"The secretary tells Earl that his daughter arrived in a taxi, and has her belongings with her. As he enters his office, the anxious man tries to get his attention but the secretary tells him to sit back down. Earl hugs his daughter Jane (Danielle Panabaker), who has some interesting news for him  she has decided to drop out of college. Earl wants to discuss this as a family, but Jane wants to talk about it now. She wants to come work for him, so that if anything happens to him the company will stay in the family. Jane takes off Earls glasses and wears them, which agitates him a little."

I'm just downloading the movie, I hope they didn't cut it.

til 21 Jan 2008, 11:43

no pic, but at least a hint:

"PANABAKER: I left high school when I was 14 and started to go to community college, because that was easier for me to work as an actress and study at the same time. I am going to start a degree this fall. I actually didnt like high school much because I was not popular and had very few friends. I always got picked on and teased because I used to wear very big glasses. I was the epitome of a nerd. I was very shy and introverted."

http://www.phase9.tv/moviefeatures/skyhighq&a-michaelangarano;&daniellepanabaker2.shtml;

Adalle 11 Dec 2007, 15:19

Julie Delpy directs, writes and stars in the movie "2 Days In Paris". Also she wears a pair of "Woody Allen"-style glasses almost for the whole movie. Of course they are not prescription lenses...

There is one scene where she is at bed, starting to have sex with Adam Goldberg and she is wearing her glasses. As he is on top of her, he removes her glasses and she says "Please, I can't see you. I could be having sex with Gregory Peck or something".

Later on she is getting dressed and he comments on her not wearing glasses and she says she finally found her contacts. But fortunately she keeps wearing glasses later in the movie.

Julian 04 Dec 2007, 00:55

gwgs: Yes, but there is a tendency to use 'short sighted' as a catchall term for not seeing well. A while back I was looking in a shop window with a young friend; the price ticket on one item was concealed by something else, and I asked Jason, who's a lot taller than me, if he could tell me what it was. His reply: "Sorry, I can't read it, I'm short sighted; well, actually I'm long sighted." My case rests.

gwgs 04 Dec 2007, 00:37

Glasses for everyone - I saw this episode last night, it was quite funny...I can't remember all the script but there were a few puns that other characters were saying, one them in particular who is trying to date her said "I see you've got glasses, you look smart" she replied "I've always been smart", he then replied saying "Maybe we can see more of each other now". The response wasn't favourable!! hahaha

Where Eastenders hadn't done her research is the character said she was shortsighted yet she picking the frames from a market stall, the first ones she tried on she bought and that was that. Clearly (sorry about the pun!) these would be reading glasses though!!!

Despite buying these glasses, in the next scene she isn't wearing and only puts them on to read a menu in a nightclub. Again, this indicates she is the opposite of short sighted. Sort it out Eastenders!

Melyssa 12 Sep 2007, 12:57

Mamamia,

I love wearing large frames. One reason is for a better fit, another is for better peripheral vision, and last but not least, because the frames are bold and beautiful, like myself. And it's nice to have glasses in different colors, not boring metal or a brown/black combination, as everything seems to be.

Bob 30 Aug 2007, 08:51

While the movie was not great overall, Proof starring Scarlet Johanson is a must see for gwg fans. She wears glasses pretty much the whole time, only taking them off at times a person would normally take glasses off. And when the guy suggests she would be prettier without her glasses, she simply shrugged it off as a silly suggestion and kept the glasses on her face. Even if you don't like mediocre Woody Allen movies, you might check this one out.

Andy 30 Aug 2007, 05:08

GwGs not so much a mystery to me. Let's say she has had lasik correcting a mild myopia of about -3D. As she got older now nature strikes back. Before lasik she simply could have taken her glasses off. Now she requires plus lenses instead. It's similar with Sharon Stone. She has never had lasik, but went from a mild minus prescription to a very low plus as she became older. My mother experienced the same thing. She went from a very mild -1D at age 40 to a+1.75D for distance vision and for reading to a +3.0D now at age 78. This process went very slow.

gwgs 30 Aug 2007, 01:17

That's what I've been wondering!!

I can't complain though!

Tod 14 Aug 2007, 21:28

Curt, Michelle Pfeiffer glasses are not "reading glasses". she is a hyperope who has to wear glasses full time. Though her lenses may be progressives which includes a reading add most likely in that she is over 40 as well most hyperopes require a reading add at a much younger age than 40.

lazysiow 09 Aug 2007, 23:26

lazysiow 09 Aug 2007, 23:26

Thanks for the link to the show. Looks like I have something new to watch :) show is a nice bit of escapism even if it has that "Canadian, but trying to be as American as possible on a lower budget" vibe to the show. Vicki's frames are exceptionally well chosen and feminising, since she still has a very masculine face even for an attractive woman. Definitely from 8 to 10 material :D

One thing that irks me though is how ill developed the whole RP angle is. To me it seems like a fatal writer's goof. It's only being used as subject for bad goofs and Vicki definitely doesnt act like she's going blind. No one seems to be in any hurry to take best advantage of the time she has left with her sight, male suitors included. I know I would. The whole thing is so barely touched on that I suspect the network execs and everyone involved just wants the whole thing written out by season 2, which I suspect it will be via dark arts powers or what not.

Im enjoying the show for what it is though, catching up download by download ;) shes fantastic in glasses.

kisal 27 Jun 2007, 06:09

It turns out Jan had nothing over Marcia in the glasses wearing department. Presenting the fabulous Maureen McCormick:

http://tv.yahoo.com/maureen-mccormick/contributor/699718/photos/3

[Anyone of my generation in America will know instantly what I am talking about. For foreigners and youth, there was a very popular American TV show in the 60's and 70's called "The Brady Bunch" that featured a large family including two sisters Jan, who wore glasses at least part time and wasn't happy about that, and her prettier older sister Marcia. Most males who were teenage or younger during the time had crushes on one or the other of the sisters, GWG fans can now have their pick!]

gwgs 27 Jun 2007, 01:16

I bought the DVD Zoom a week or two ago with Courteney Cox and whilst the movie is appalling, Courteney looks absolutely scintallating with her large rectangular rimless frames which are holding a not too substantial plus prescription!!

It's odd that she's still wearing a prescription in this movie, and 'November' as there were reports a couple of years ago of her having lasik and I read a report somewhere saying her prescription before that was something like -8!! So to go from a high myopic prescription to a + is something admirable for a gwg fan.

Yoyo 07 May 2007, 09:57

Great sighting on this week's episode of "The Riches", a show on the FX network about a family of con artists. Saw the girl who plays the daughter (Shannon Marie Woodward) wearing fairly strong minus lenses for much of the show, strong enough to require flat fronts anyway. A quick search reveals that the episode was called "Cinderella".

She's a regular cast member, but I don't think her character is actually meant to need glasses; she used them as part of her "costume" for the episode, posing as (I think) the father's secretary. Still, they were almost certainly the actress's real prescription.

Certainly one to watch in the future for more sightings. Her IMDb page has one picture in glasses:

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0940990/

All4Eyes 20 Apr 2007, 13:46

Just had to put in my 2 cents on the new Lifetime TV series "Blood Ties". I like the show, with it's vampire theme (I sometimes wonder if my "glasses thing" is my weirdest weird thing or my "normal weird thing" compared to some of my other odd fancies) and references to the main characters gradually dimming sight from retinitis pigmentosa "and to top it all off, I'm nearsighted!" as she said. Not that you could tell by looking at her glasses, yet another pair of " 'scriptless wonder" prop glasses. Good grief, people, is your production budget so small you can't afford to shell out a couple hundred extra bucks for a pair of REAL glasses, of the sort that an actual nearsighted person would actually wear? I mean, they don't even have to be strong, just please give us something that isn't so laughably obviously fake! And, for heaven's sake, have her use them in a manner consistent with how real myopes use their glasses-don't have her put them on every time she has to read something up close, then have scenes where she recognizes someone from across a large room without them and with nary a squint. You'd think surely someone on the production team would be a nearsighted person who might point out some of these things, maybe even offer to lend the actress a pair of his/her spare specs if the prop budget really was a problem (at least that's what I would do if I was on the production team of a show with a "nearsighted" character). At least they did have enough respect for realism not to tell us she was going blind and then show scenes with her driving! I'm actually thinking of writing the producer of the program and explaining all this, I wonder if any of us lens-aware people have ever done this? Who knows, maybe if we wrote to the producers of movies/TV shows that feature fake four-eyes we'd actually see an increase in appropriately attired eyes? Anyway, it's a good program if you're into vampires/other paranormal creatures and P.I.s who are slowly going blind, but as a "glasses show" it's a disappointment. I give it two thumbs up, but specs slid wayyyy down on the nose...oh, no, there they go...CRACK! Ohhhh, hit the concrete! Oh well, maybe now we can get her some real ones.

I ALWAYS make passes at guys who wear glasses, Marie

ChrisB 18 Apr 2007, 15:34

Jessica Biel is very appealing, even in what seem quite ordinary frames in some pics.

I have sometimes been thankful that close GWG colleagues did not 'hit the spot', so I didnt have to think about them as GWGs. On the other hand, I am driven mad, almost daily by a GWG colleague who always returns my smile ..... ( perhaps this should have gone in 'sightings'.

missing in action 26 Mar 2007, 08:35

kisal 26 Mar 2007, 07:38

Yet another GWG film disappointment! And this is only place I can rant. Will movies ever get glasses right. I went to see "The Namesake" this weekend (by the way it is a great movie and worth seeing despite what I am about to say) and was really looking forward to seeing the main character's (Gogol's) wife in glasses, since her glasses were mentioned several times in the book. When she first shows up she is wearing sexy black frames (although she mostly peers over them which I found rather annoying) and they are clearly not a turn-off to Gogol. Then she wears them briefly in one more scene before he takes them off before they go have sex. I don't object to that in itself (it's in the book) but then after that the glasses never appear again. Once again glasses are simply a prop, like a hat, to be used, removed and then forgotten about. It would have been much better and more realistic if she had continued to be bespectacled throughout. Except for Scarlett Johansson in "Scooped," I can't think of the last woman in film whose glasses were portrayed as anything more than a prop or affectation.

lazysiow 26 Mar 2007, 02:29

There was like one shot of her in glasses lol

Adalle 22 Feb 2007, 07:29

Unfortunately you don't remember it well. At the start she doesn't wear glasses. When she gets infected by the alien parasite (although we don't know it yet in the movie), she starts wearing her glasses. The others are quite suspicious at some point why she put her glasses that day.

Later on we find out that she had put her glasses because the aliens are obsessive with water and the contacts made her eyes dry. Of course this would mean that the alien parasite didn't improve her vision and she still would depend by her glasses, but after the others have found out she is infected, she ditches the glasses and we no longer see her with them on. Hollywood...

Alas the frames were of beautiful design...

darkglassesfan - unfortunately a Google image search on Ms Manning brings up NO results of her in spex, i went through eight pages of thumbnail images of her - including some of her nude! - and found not one :(

darkglassesfan 01 Feb 2007, 07:58

Katy Manning appeared on a show called "Going for a Song" sometime in the late Sixties, maybe 1970. It was a precursor to the "Antiques Roadshow". They used to have a couple of experts and a couple of guest collectors. Katy was one of the latter. I don't think Katy's glasses had myodisks, but her lenses were very thick with lots of power rings and cut-in. I bet they must've been at least -20 and probably not high-indexed. The lenses were also tinted dark brown, probably to try to disguise the power rings. They also had large tortoiseshell frames. The cameraman kept zooming in on whatever objects she was looking at, which gave a wonderful view of her lenses. I think it's still the best view of a high myope on TV I've ever seen.

Does anyone remember a backing group called "The Ladybirds" that were around at about that time. They used to be on the Simon Dee show every Saturday on the BBC? One of the girls always wore dark glasses with thick prescription lenses. She was a real treat!

cut-in UK 20 Jan 2007, 00:20

Therouter, I think you miss the point with Jade. We recognise her as displaying racist characteristics because we are now conditioned to. She isn't a racist because the doesn't really understand true racism. She is a woman without education and totally devoid of social skills. She saw the very prescence of Ms. Shetty as a threat. The latter is polished and sophisticated having been some time in the toughest business in the world. Her 'race' is incidental as poor Jade is just using the crude weapons of the street, and instincts inherited from her upbringing. The glasses, (the only relevant point in this forum) are probably an idea from her publicist, to enhance, an otherwise coarse and unrefined appearance. She is only there as a notorious figure of fun and I doubt that her eyesight is in need of correction. You can see a million 'Jades' who live their lives in permanent conflict because they don't understand how the world works. Ms. Shetty outclasses her without even opening her mouth and this is the true nature of the conflict. She clearly is 'different' and her only crime was not 'dumbing down' to Jade's level. She would have received the same treatment had she been Anglo-Saxon or a natural blonde Swede. Thank god she wasn't wearing glasses as well; Jade would have probably pulled them off her nose and snapped them ! Funny old world isn't it.

Therouteur 19 Jan 2007, 19:50

A philosophically interesting event on so many levels. Racism is such a grievous secular sin for many of us that it cancels the effect of the glasses.

Fascinating.

What else would have that effect? Any thoughts?

It's an interesting point you raise about Claire (Julia Haworth from Coronation Street) as I only started this poor excuse for a show when she started wearing spex and the first time she wore them everyone commented on them and in fact they all went out for a drink to the pub to celebrate her new eyewear!!!

How many girls do that!? She fiddled with them a lot then and seemed very proud to be wearing them, since them she has changed her frames once but I got a bit bored of watching Corrie and therefore didn't she'd stopped wearing them.

It's a shame as the soap world needs more gwgs, I still miss Lisa Kay who played Anna in Hollyoaks - she was my dream girl.

cut-in UK 06 Jan 2007, 15:12

Maverick, in the matter of Clare, she didn't have a high degree of myopia; probably no more than -2.5. She has , in fact that almost archetypal English prettiness, 'pale and interesting'. Although the character she plays is a little old-fashioned, I can't believe a girl with -2.5 would risk 'Lasik' Is it worth an e-mail to Granada TV on the off-chance she might confirm/deny the suggestion?

You obviously rate the lady too !

Just as an aside, don't you think that the actors/actresses in soaps generally play 'themselves' rather than portray characters where they need to exercise serious acting talent. (Not getting at anyone in particular; just an observation)

Vic 02 Dec 2006, 16:07

Tod 02 Dec 2006, 15:26

GWG film: 'Katherine' a made for TV movie (1975) stars Sissy Spacek and Henry Winkler.

She is a rich heiress who turns college radical and switches from wearing contact lenses to glasses. At one point she is involved in a riot at her school and her glasses get knocked off. Camera then shows her seeing an extreme blur. First she feels about the ground trying without luck to find her glasses. Then she tries to flee as do the others before the cops arrive. But due to her poor eyesight she can't see where she is going and is caught.

If you can find it rent it . Its a gem!

Philosifer 02 Dec 2006, 12:21

I was watching one of my Wonder Woman DVD's and saw a sequence of Diana in prescription glasses! Wow, I played it over and over. The episode was called "Screaming Javelin".

They were big (80's style, odd looking now) and quite strong, I think about minus 4, maybe minus 5.

I was quite a Wonder Woman nut as a young teenager, but now it's something extra! :-)

Wurm 19 Nov 2006, 11:29

The character "Rosie" in the musical Mamma Mia is usually costumed with glasses. Judging from photos on the web, in some productions they are only worn in certain scenes, but in others the actress leaves them on for the singing/dancing numbers.

The character is middle-aged (to save some of you the click-through).

Tod 16 Nov 2006, 18:54

Tod 16 Nov 2006, 18:52

A good GWG movie is one called 'Student Exchange' a 1987 ABC movie of the week. It may be on DVD/video now a days. The protaganist is a nerdy high school girl with glasses who dyes her hair and puts in contact lenses to imposter a French foreign exchange student at her own high school (one who is sexy and popular). But she has problems wearing the contacts and at one point is seen rubbing her eye to keep them in while being confronted by the stuck up popular girls. When at home as her real self, she wears her glasses in front of her parents and her little sister.

Tod 14 Nov 2006, 19:32

I have seen several recent pics of Ms. Murphy. In each she seems to only be wearing her right lens. Maybe she is doing the monovision thing. Often myopes will remove their glasses or look over the top of them in order to read. So maybe this is what she is doing contact lens style?

Wonderful pictures (pun) of Lynda Carter. I never saw her on television, except in re-runs of the Muppets, I think I was out having a life during then.

She still looks pretty hot nowadays (dukes of hazzard) but with no glasses unfortunately. The prescription in those shots is strange, in some shots The left lens looks hi minus but but in other shots particularly the drop temples the rx could be +. I also remember that my wife had frames at that time that were tortishell and nearly as big. So seeing these Pix is quite nostalgic as my wife gave up wearing hers (for mild hyperopia) much to my sadness.

gwgs 09 Nov 2006, 01:34

I've capped a couple of new pics of Lynda Carter from Wonder Woman, mainly because she is evidently squinting, and wearing plano frames.

There have been various articles on the net about how she has worn contact lenses underneath the plano glasses she sometimes wore on set and how they had to use sandbags as markers for her as she was so myopic so I just thought she caps would add to this.

Enjoy

http://uk.pg.photos.yahoo.com/ph/gwgs1/detail?.dir=/92a2&.dnm=d388re2.jpg&.src=ph

Yoyo 07 Nov 2006, 19:19

Trust is one of the few films in which the lead actress is actually judged to be MORE attractive in glasses by the leading man. Midway through, he asks her if she wears glasses. She says, "They make me look like a librarian." He replies, "I like librarians . . ."

She puts them on and wears them for the rest of the film! Very nice.

Maverick 04 Sep 2006, 05:51

There is no question in my opinion that Lynda Carter is quite myopic and the lenses in the WW clips are her own . There are interviews where she refers to her poor eyesight - eg on the WW Series 1 DVD where she comments on needing floor markers to find her way around the set. I also recall a magazine interview some ago where the interviewer commented on her 'coke bottle' glasses (and Lynda added that her hearing was poor as well......) She of course does the Lens Crafters CL's advertising.

As far as WW goes in Series 2 and Series 3 whenever she is required to drive off come the planos and on with the prescription which is logical for saftey reasons. There are also pics around of her wearing her prescription specs when playing tennis.

gwgs 04 Sep 2006, 00:49

kisal 03 Aug 2006, 19:17

Yes, "Scoop" is absolutely magnificent! It is the kind of movie that is almost (but fortunately not quite) non-existent-- where an attractive woman wears glasses from start to finish in a movie, where she doesn't take them off when she gets romantic and where other characters aren't continually drawing attention to them. Scarlett's character Sondra (or Jade) just wears them and that't that. Kate Winslett's character in "Enigma" came close to this ideal, but she ruined it by showing up non-bespectacled in the last scene. Scarlett only takes them off to swim and sleep.

gwgs 14 Jul 2006, 01:11

Great pics Spexi, they demonstrate that not all actresses wear planos :)

gwgs 14 Jul 2006, 01:00

Amanda Donohoe made her debut in the new series of Bad Girls on ITV last night (9pm). She plays the deputy governor of the prison and wears heavy framed hexi spex.

I was intrigued to see whether these were prescription as I have seen her wearing spex before and this would be a good test. I am pleased to comment that there is a substantial + prescription and cut in was evident on numerous occasions. On one occasion the camera zoomed in on her walking into the room and as she moved her head to the side you could clearly see the magnification!

The part I found annoying was she took her glasses off and didn't have them back on for 1/4 of the show but when there was some close up work to be done she put them back on :)

oscar 11 Jun 2006, 04:26

I don't know if anyone's mentioned the movie "High School Musical" (Disney, 2006) before. The composer in it is a character called Kelsi (played by the extremely cute Olesya Rulin) and she wears low minus glasses throughout the movie. It's difficult to tell from this clip, but there's a shot about 48 secs in which shows a little bit of cut-in. In other words, they are real glasses. Obviously on the DVD the lenses show up much better, and there are quite lot of shots of her. Even in the number that's the grand finale of the movie she wears her specs.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bYK_SLZRgns&search;=high%20school%20musical

1) Anonymous. Many thanks. That's good news about Scoop.

2) gwgs. In fact I've just finished rewatching Match Point on wide screen dvd. Not my choice but la Therouteuse loves a chick flick and, like me, thinkd Scarlett J is hot. Had a bit of trouble calming her down at certain points.

However.

On the bigger screen you can quite clearly see her contacts in close ups.

Unfortunately none of this changes the basic point that it's a shit flick, at least as I see it. La T who is a sensitive soul when it comes to these things (when she's not overcome with excitement at scenes of passion involving SJ) said; "What's weird is that it's a snobby upper class New York view of what the English upper classes are all about but actually they're quite different. Not nearly as class obsessed as the New Yorkers"

She may well think that. I couldn't possibly comment. But SJ is still HOT.

 31 May 2006, 16:39

Therouteur,

I think you are thinking of Match Point and not Scoop (she is in two Woody Allen film's back to back). Scoop has Scarlett wearing glasses, and it doesn't come out until the end of July whereas Match Point just came out on DVD and she isn't wearing glasses in that.

Therouteur 31 May 2006, 15:19

I checked out the new Woodie Allen movie with the luscious Scarlett Johanssen on a plane yesterday and, as far as I could see (before I fell asleep out of utter boredom - it's definitely a chick flick) there's good news and bad news. The bad news is that there's not even a slight g-sighting (new technical term) anywhere in the movie. The good news is that this seems to suggest that the glasses we saw in all those pictures with her and the ageing degenerate are probably her own and not just props to satisfy the Woodster's optic obsessions.

If anyone's managed to stay awake through the whole thing and actually sighterd some glasses I'd be fascinated to hear.

glasses4ever 31 May 2006, 03:20

Since I saw a couple of episodes of the Gilmore Girls series 4 in which Lorelai Gilmore (Lauren Graham) is wearing real prescritpion eyeglasses, I'm fascinating about what a TV fiction can say you about the real life of actors/actresses.

In fact, since glasses are real, but are not so relevant to the story (so no need to add them to the Lorelai character, I think), the only explanation for their use is that the real Lauren needs them to play, and have to wear them when she cannot wear contacts for some reason.

Is it also true that with a prescription like that (I guess low nearsightedness, less than -3), Lauren should be more than able to play on the set without any correction. Why, instead, she appears with glasses? Perhaps she forgot to remove them once and they began part of the story from then on? Which is your intepretation?

Here is a screenshots, many others available on the same WEB site.

http://www.lauren-graham.net/displayimage.php?album=5&pos;=127

 30 May 2006, 00:23

Check out several glimpses of Uma Thurman wearing glasses in the upcoming My Super-EX Girlfriend. Trailer is available here: www.mysuperex.com

pete 29 May 2006, 12:28

A few new movies out on DVD with actresses in speaking roles wearing significant minus glasses:

June Bug: The gallery assistant in two scenes - quite strong lenses

I Love Your Work: The friend (Shalom Harlow) of the Actor's wife in a long scene near the beginning. Pretty strong rimless. She puts them on to read aloud a fan letter.

also, an oldie: Bamboozled (Spike Lee): Attractive blonde with strong horned rim glasses in 2 conference room scenes.

Guido 27 Apr 2006, 13:11

By accident cought a film playing on cable, "Trust", for you IMDB afficianados, it's the 1990 version. Adrienne Shelley was the female lead, and wore specs throughout the film. The Specs actually had a little minus power, probably less than -2.00. None the less very many glasses shots. Frames were a large eye size reminiscent of the '80s. Horn rim temples and above the eye, appeared to use a metal band to capture the rest of the lens.

I want to add something as well.

I really oppose to the fact that calling the wearing eyeglasses is a disability.

Some people have shoter noses while other have longer noses, same way some people have shorter eyeballs and some people have longer eyeballs! that makes all the difference!

Slit 23 Mar 2006, 04:10

Since the discussion about attraction to a disablity is getting intense here, i thought of posting this.

Just think about a situation where a guy prefers a girl with a low cut neckline which shows the cleavage and turns on the guy sexually. It is a sexual feeling aroused by a something worn by the girl, which she was not born with.

Such is the situation with the girls with glasses! Some girls have the ability to arouse men when they wear glasses.

In the same time there are men who preferentially get sexually turned on when seeing a beauty in glasses. It is very much analogical to the fact that some people get turned on by the way some girls dress!

So my friends, we should understand that its the diversity that makes this world colourful. Some prefer chocolate ice cream, some prefer vanilla ice cream! We have to live with it.

Let us not make argument on Justifying the rightness or wrongness of being a glasses fetishist!

Filthy McNasty 22 Mar 2006, 16:31

ehpc: Not that I care, and I certainly don't want to pick a fight with anyone, but the following proposition is demonstrably incorrect: "Nobody could ever find any form of 'disability' sexy, quite obviously."

There are scores of fetish sites for those with a thing for blind people, visually impaired people, amputees, people with deformities, and on and on. Some people clearly DO find certain types of disbility, in and of themselves, sexy.

ehpc 22 Mar 2006, 16:22

Glasses 'fetish' is the reverse of a disability thing, obviously.Nobody could ever find any form of 'disability' sexy, quite obviously.The whole point about glasses is that when the woman is wearing her glasses she can see perfectly,and therefore acquires an attractive, positive, 'I'm going to conquer the world and all the men in it' sort of look. That's the sex appeal of glasses. I am very much a frames man....................whilst the lenses must be minus to give that 'focussed' intellectual look, the same woman would be totally unsexy wearing naff studenty gold metal ovals as opposed to confident business woman black rectangular plastic frames with wide sides. But that's because I like bold, confident, intellectual women.But although lenses must be minus, frames are where it's at. The difference between naff studenty gold metal ovals and sexy business woman black rectangular plastics is like the difference between a woman wearing bedroom slippers and shiny stilettos.

 22 Mar 2006, 14:24

Hey ChrisB... Actually, that's Kristin Chenowith in Bewitched (not Heather Graham...who does wear glasses in Sidewalks of New York and Killing me Softly, to name a few). Chenowith also typically wears glasses on The West Wing (Sunday @8 on NBC).

Katy 22 Mar 2006, 14:16

I agree with that Yoyo - it is different for everyone. I have to say that I understand what MPHC is talking about - planos have no effect on me either - and neither do glasses which are not the person's own prescription. If a gorgeous guy tried on someone else's -10s, that would be slightly interesting.. if they were his own, it would be incredible. But I think there are plenty of people on here that don't care what someone's rx is, as long as they have glasses. That can be either a preference or a fetish, but most people with a 'preference' wouldn't bother reading this site. I would love to understand how low rxs can be sexy - I think that fetish is rooted in something completely different to mine, which is all about the person _needing_ the glasses. Anyway, nothing to do with Actresses :-)

Yoyo 22 Mar 2006, 13:44

Glasses fetish isn't just paraphilic in nature, though certainly the whole "disability" aspect is a big factor. But some folks here have talked about being interested in choice of frames, how they enhance a person's face, or in the bold fashion statement that may be made by wearing specs.

I certainly find it interesting (and a bit arousing) when a girl wears weak prescription glasses all the time; she is clearly making a choice to wear them, which is very sexy and cool.

Anon 21 Mar 2006, 20:06

Yes of course it's a glasses fetish site. I don't deny that. But when you look at the remark in context he says planos don't belong because this is a glasses fetish site. He goes on to explain what real lenses are. Who's he to say that planos have no part in a glasses fetish? I found that amusing. I just didn't explain myself as well as I should have.

I also believe this site has something to offer to non-fetishists as some threads pertain to non-fetish subjects such as low vision, refractive surgery etc. Not EVERYONE who arrives here has such a fetish, although most of those who stay probably do.

MPHC 21 Mar 2006, 15:20

Anon,

This is most certainly a Glasses Fetish Site. Any attempt to claim otherwise is clearly ridiculous. Also I think you'll find that every thread on here relates to a Glasses fetish either directly or indirectly.

Now about planos. I'm all for being inclusive and of course folks are entitled to their preferences. I just think you are missing the point somewhat if you get excited looking at a girl (or man) wearing fake glasses. Would plano contact lenses have the same effect? This is more a "preference" than a fetish, like preferring tall people, blond people, skinny people etc. Planos say nothing about the wearer (other than a. they are an actor wearing a prop for a film or b. they have no style and think that wearing a fake medical appliance somehow enhances their appearance) in the same way that being tall says nothing about a pperson other than that they are tall. Would these same people consider wearing a hearing aid for the same reason? I think probably not. A true glasses fetish I believe is paraphilic in nature and it is this with which I am afflicted. The bottom line is I find planos no more interesting than no glasses at all. I'm not trying to antagonise people, just trying to generate a little discussion. This has gone off topic somewhat but I would be genuinely interested in what people find exciting about planos or low prescriptions. Maybe you can educate me. The psychology thread is probably the most suitable in which to continue this discussion.

Planos are not lenses in the true sense of the word in that they do not refract visible light (or any other elctromagnetic radiation for that matter). When are you plano posters going to get that into your heads?

Soapman 16 Feb 2006, 07:21

Could be that I agree Julian.I always figured that it was something like that in Wonder Woman when Lynda Carter would in one shot be in proper RX and the next in planos.

However with Corrie a lot of the older cast members wear their own RX glasses seemingly without problem on set so I am not sure. The sudden switch to planos for Claire just seemed a bit odd.

Cactus Jack 16 Feb 2006, 05:13

gwgs: The problem is reflections of the many lights on a typical set in the glasses. The lights are everywhere and reflections are very hard to control if the glasses have anything other than plano surfaces.

Really good antireflective coatings and maybe polarizing filters would probably help significantly but I don't think the typical director or cinematographer is concernted with our sensibilities. So they just use plano lenses, carefull camera angles and re-shoot the scene if they get a flash.

Maybe they need sensitivity training!

C.

gwgs 16 Feb 2006, 04:32

How can it cause the camera man less trouble? Do we think he is an 0-0!?

Claire will probably be doing a bit of GOC :)

Julian 16 Feb 2006, 04:20

Soapman: I have read somewhere that planos cause the cameramen less trouble than proper Rx lenses, so they tend to insist on them. Makes you sick, doesn't it?

Alexfan 04 Feb 2006, 17:22

Slit,

It's true, about 70% of the USA are hyperopes. One of the main reason, is that Americans are more into reading novels, newspapers, watching TV, and other harmless addictions.

Therefore, it causes the high rate of hyperopes in US. There are a lot of myopes in Europe, UK and Asia.

Europeans are freely admitting thier weakness, while Asians hides them. It's just thier lifestyles.

But, with lasik and contact lenses on the rise. Americans are also increasingly becoming myopes by 10% compared to last year, which was 5%. So, basically, we see 5% more myopes each year.

Technology is to blame for the "boom" of myopes.

Even, the Emmy Award and Oscar have posted rules for celebs not to wear glasses on the stage (which I think, it's retarded)

There's nothing wrong with men/women with glasses. It's like wearing stylish dresses, having ears pierced up. So, if they can do that, why can't thier wear glasses too?

You see, this is one of the many reasons why I'm doing research on myopes, because they're often repressed for thier strong prescription.

Stephanie March is a perfect example to begin with.

Any thoughts?

Alexfan.

Slit 04 Feb 2006, 08:03

Keep it up!

Well, it should be more than -2.5 because a frind of mine with -2.5 have less cut-in than that of in the pic.

Can you start study about celebrity gwgs who wear + glasses too?

I have seen that according to statistics, there are more Hyperopes in Western world that myopes...but hyperopia is hidden.

The second scene is interesting. Denise comes out of a phone booth in the office in Daily Planet, where she had taken off her superhero suit. Then she puts her bag on the table and takes out of it a box of acuvue contact lenses and her glasses case. Chloe tells her, "I thought the glasses were fake", and Denise replies to her as she slowly puts on her glasses, "Are you kidding? I am blind as a bat. Besides the glasses don't look so good with the mask over it". And then Chloe comments, "Acuvue to rescue."

Alexfan 02 Feb 2006, 23:27

As I mentioned earlier, that I needed facts to prove the eyeglasses prescription for a research project due this March/April.

Here's what I have collected:

http://community.livejournal.com/alexliveson/8709.html#cutid1

The last photo is a close-up, and it shows a real glasses rather than a prop that most actress wear during shooting.

Now, I want all of you to post your estimate/guess what the prescription looks like. It's evident enough that it's not around -2.50D. It could be more, as it looks more nearsighted, unless you have any justification for that evidence.

Alexfan 29 Jan 2006, 23:10

Perhaps, a prescription of -2.50D is a good estimate. Again, it's all estimage and guesses. I needed to see the fact. Here's the thing. I'm a graphic designer doing a huge research project on glasses vs. contact lenses, and lasik vs. glasses

I'm also conducting a survey on several specs wearers, and some "glasses" obsessions like this one here.

Basically, my point is being whether it's important for glasses wearers to still wear glasses, or balance them with contact lenses, or how much/should they wear in regard to thier prescription.

In that case, at this moment...my focus is on Stephanie March. Next is Julia Roberts, and gradually Sandra Bullock. (it's rather a long project, a 5 mths. project...definately, I needed detials)

I've been told that since they are actresses, I do not have any direct access to gain thier valid facts, but I could "open-research" meaning finding clues from anywhere, like talking or responding with you...etc

and from there, I'll see where the fact information comes from.

On a personal note, I, too wear glasses and have a moderate to severe astigmatism. My prescription is higher than Stephanie March, given the estimates here. So, I imagine that when I was younger, I had her prescription. And I could tell, it wasn't bad either, but yes, it would be better to see with it clearly.

Mmmm...I'll have to do more "fact" checking. It's important these days, I believe on the rise since the James Frey controversy with Oprah.

Alright, I would appreciate anymore support or help if you have any lead on Stephanie March or how I could find true/fact information from. It could be a website, a link to magazine, or etc...

Thanks,

Alexfan.

Ree 29 Jan 2006, 09:44

I agree with Specs4ever. She has that perfect prescription where she dosent always need her glasses to see clearly. People with that sort of prescription have the liberty of wearing and taking off their glasses when ever they want without facing much difficulty, and maybe some like Stephanie there can also use them like accessories to enhance their looks or play with them to get the desired effect.

specs4ever 29 Jan 2006, 07:16

I would suggest that she is no more than a -2.50D. This is really a perfect prescription, as she does not need glasses to read, but yet she gets to wear them to accent her beauty. She is a great looking gal wearing glasses.

specs4ever 29 Jan 2006, 07:15

I would suggest that she is no more than a -2.50D. This is really a perfect prescription, as she does not need glasses to read, but yet she gets to wear them to accent her beauty. She is a great looking gal wearing glasses.

Ree 29 Jan 2006, 02:01

Alexfan, I agree that Stephanie is really one cool GWG. But her Rx is nowhere near the point where she is blind without them, or has to have them as must to see anything.

My estimate is that she has a decent moderate to low Rx which shows a bit of cut in, but she is definitely not highly myopic. She is still at a stage where she can very well manage with her glasses on top of her head, but definitely sees much clearly with them on.

Guest 12 Jan 2006, 03:22

Celebrity BB last night focused on Jodie taking out her contacts before going to bed. They were obviously not disposables as she spent time rinsing them with a bottle of lens cleaner & then held the lens holder close to her face as she stored them away.

She then picked up her glasses (which she wore for hours yesterday), wiped them on her skirt, held them up & then put them on.

She then got into bed & lay there with her glasses on until the camera switched to another subject.

Her glasses look around minus 5 to me - she obviously needs some kind of correction at all times.

Adalle 19 Dec 2005, 17:23

I just saw the movie "November" where Courtney Cox wears glasses. The movie doesn't have much to offer. For a low budget thriller it's adequate. If you don't like movies that need thinking, then don't watch it. Now, concerning Courtney Cox, she wears glasses for the whole movie. She takes them off and puts them back on about two or three times. In some scenes they seem to be without prescription and in some others they seem to be very low minus. The frames are a bit old, but with the lighting that was used in the movie, they seem pretty cool. Anyway, the glasses were totally worth watching the movie.

 19 Dec 2005, 11:50

Adalle 06 Dec 2005, 03:37

It is illegal to download for free any episode of any series or any movie from the internet. That's why you will not find this episode in any site.

However if you want to break the law, you could use a Peer-to-peer program-protocol like emule, or bittorrent. Google these words and you will find plenty of links of how to make these programs work.

gwgs 04 Nov 2005, 09:23

Just thought I'd point out something I hadn't noticed before;

I was watching Absolutely Fabulous the other night, the g/f remarked "something for both of us on this show" (she knows I like 0-0's).

I was watching Saffy closely, who is played by Julia Sawalia, who wears glasses full time on the show, nice gold rimmed bookish spex and saw a decent bit of cut in.

I originally thought they were just props but it is now evident that her props are prescription glasses! In all the scenes on this particular episode I paused the shots of her and I was very pleased to see a notable prescription.

The strange thing is in all of her of other shows shes never worn glasses.

Now either she was doing GOC (this was back in the 90's though) or she's another one who's had Lasik.
