gwgs 03 Nov 2005, 00:25

Just did a search for Katy Manning and unfortunately didn't find any pix but it is heavily documented that she had/has appaling eyesight and I'm dying to see some photos of her with these THICK spex;

"As the Master leads Jo by the hand across the rock-strewn ground of the Ogrons' planet, he can be heard quietly saying various un-Master-esque things like, "Be careful down here."

[This is not so much the Master helping Jo as Roger Delgado helping out Katy Manning, whose poor eyesight (without her glasses) left her prone to tripping up on uneven terrain.]"

Another one;

"Katy is very nearly blind, even with contact lenses in, so it took a minute or two to arrange the materials so that she could see the constellations and houses on the main chart. She did pop on her reading specs for the first part of the discussion, just to see some of the finer points of the chart. It was engaging to see the spritely face of the woman we all associate with Jo Grant, reading glasses perched down on her nose, trying to see me over the tops of them to talk to me."

gwgs 03 Nov 2005, 00:17

RE: Billie Piper, it might be worth mentioning that she doesn't wear spex in Dr Who, in fact, I haven't seen her wearing them for some years.

oscar 02 Nov 2005, 17:37

Ah, the very, very lovely Katy Manning. She was indeed blind as a bat. I did find a picture or two of her from much more recent years with her wearing reading glasses over her contact. Her prescription was/is amazingly high and she once (just once) appeared on TV on an antiques programme in the 1970s wearing large frames with myodiscs in them (only the second time I had ever seen them on anyone). She kept taking them off as well, but they were seriously strong. I doubt if there are any photos of her wearing them, but I remember a feature in the Radio Times around 1970 where she talked about how difficult it was for her on the set because she was so severely myopic.

Myopeinhere 02 Nov 2005, 15:54

And another thing,Katy Manning who played Jo grant in the 1970's in the dodgy series was an amazing myope,blind as a bat but cannot find pictures of her anywhere in glasses.

perhaps there's an OO on the production staff?

Karen X 02 Nov 2005, 13:52

Billie Piper is a former teen pop star and is now an actress. Her acting is actually quite good (much better than her singing). She is currently playing Rose in "Dr Who". Dr Who is a British Sci-Fi/Family Drama about a 'Timelord' (only known as The Dr) who travels through time and space saving various planets and their inhabitants from their enemies. Dr Who first appeared on BBC TV in the early 1960s and ran until the late 1980s with several different actors playing the Dr over the years. It was well known for it's low budget special effects and dodgy looking sets. In the mid 1990s a fairly average quality US/UK co-production tv movie was made. Then, in Spring this year, the BBC showed its new series. This series had a big budget and amazing special effects. Carrying on the tradition of all previous series Billie Piper was cast as the human assistant to the Dr (The Dr is actually an alien who looks human). Most of the Assistants over the years have been female (some cute, some sexy). The new series attracted more viewers than any other programme on any other UK channel at the same time. There is going to be a Christmas Special in late December and another series next year. Billie remains as the assistant. Even though "Dr Who" is aimed at families there are regular more adult suggestive comments and jokes that children don't notice. It's very good drama worth watching! By the way I am NOT a sci-fi geek and do Not work for the BBC!

Philosifer 18 Oct 2005, 14:54

Spent a pleasant couple of hours last night watching the 'new' Nicole Kidman movie - The Interpreter (finally out on DVD). Not a great flick, though quite entertaining for an OO. She wore her glasses for perhaps half the time, and there was no doubt about the fact that they were real. Not strong; but enough cut-in for maybe -2 or -3 on the right eye and a bit less on the left. I believe I heard she has done the Lasik thing since; can anyone confirm that ? The irritating thing, though was that they had her taking them off and putting them on at all the wrong moments - as if the only reason the Director could imagine anyone needing glasses was to read. So she was always putting them on for near work, and taking them off for distance vision !

gwgs 17 Oct 2005, 00:29

Well said Mav.

One thing i have noticed on WW is that every single driving scene shows her wearing drop temple tinted spex that clearly show a myopic prescription, and at certain times, a great cut in.

My question to add to Philosifers is why did she change to the planos? Why not keep these on all the time?

Maverick 14 Oct 2005, 14:51

The answer to 2, Philosofer, is apparently that 'no' she did not wear CL's on set.

In her commentary on the WW series DVD currently available Lynda Carter makes reference to the fact that her vision was so bad without glasses that she needed sandbags placed round the set as 'marks'.

In many ways it seems bizarre that she mostly wore planos when in character as Diana Prince when she obviously needed RX specs and looked great in them. I can only assume that there was some problem in indoor scenes with lighting reflections that made planos a technically better option.

For me noone even comes close to Ms Carter as my all time favourit GWG.

Philosifer 14 Oct 2005, 14:29

I keep going back to that set of Diana Prince, aka Wonder Woman, pictures.

They are spectacular, in their own right, showing as they do a beautiful, intelligent , woman with clearly significant Rx. There are a couple of pics, #34 and 35, I think, that highlight far better than even maximum cut-in on an standard face shot, the fascinating distortional effects of a medium myopic lens; I just love those. But the really intriguing questions, and I know they been asked before (but not satisfactorily answered) , are:

1) why an actress who evidently needs to wear 'proper' glasses with a significant prescription would, much of the time, wear clearly plano theatrical specs ? and;

2) when she was wearing that slightly dumb-looking theatre prop pair, did she have contacts in, so she could actually see where she was going ?

http://albums.photo.epson.com/j/ViewPhoto?u=4231226&a;=31664795&p;=72537267&f;=0

 11 Oct 2005, 15:58

I have just watched the first episode of a new comedy on BBC2 (UK) called "Supernova". The first scene had the main character (played by Rob Brydon) being interviewed by a 30 something woman wearing a business suit. She was wearing glasses with thick black frames and I'm pretty sure they had a minus prescription in the lenses. This women is very sexy and is played by Australian actress Kat Stewart.

Unfortunately the next time we see her character she is not wearing glasses but she is wearing some casual close fitting clothes that show off her great figure. The character is a Dr in science working in an observatory in the Australian outback. She didn't wear her glasses for the rest of the episode.

I'm hoping she will wear her glasses in future episodes.

If anyone knows of this actress (she has done quite a bit of tv & theatre in Australia) and has any photos of her please post a link to them.

She is on the right in this picture (no glasses though) http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/supernova/gallery/gallery5.shtml

I am a maker of hand carved wooden glasses, each being specific in design and construction to the desires of the customer. I personally pick all my woods to ensure uniqueness and quality.  29 Sep 2005, 21:56

I actually find Elisabeth more attractive with her glasses on than off. That black square plastic frame suits her perfectly and looks stunning with her blond hair.

I don't know if these are new glasses but they appear to be of slightly different shape to her others (see here http://us.f3.yahoofs.com/users/427cef54z4776b03/acef/__sr_/b1f6.jpg?phLgMPDB0QhGgTkI )

Her "old" ones seem to be a bit deeper and thus slightly too large for her face IMO.

Elisabeth's frames also have some great sidearms on them. They are the really fat kind and she often pulls her hair back to expose this feature.

In regards to her lenses, I'd have a guess that they are around -4. A close look at the edges appear to give off a decent amount of minus and reflectivity. I think she's been a GWG for some time. Anyone else care to guess.

If anyone can find some more pics of Elisabeth I'm sure they would be well received on this site!

The following is a comment I picked up off the web from someone referring to LC's commentary on the currently available WW full series DVD's.

"I am surprised they didn't give her real glasses, because Carter says in the commentary that her vision was so bad without glasses that she had to have sand bags as "marks" in some scenes."

Tod 17 Aug 2005, 16:47

Linda Carter! I haven't heard about her in over 20 years. As TV's Wonder Woman / Daina Prince she wore glasses in that show. Linda has to wear Rx glasses in real life. Sometimes her charactor had on plano glasses and Linda had on her contact lenses. At other times she wore her Rx glasses, often both pairs in the same episode as both pairs were of the same frame style. So the only way to tell is to look carefully at her lenses. Linda also did TV commercials for B&L; softlens contacts in the 1970's when they first came on the market. I wonder if she got LASIK?

CARTER

Speximann 16 Aug 2005, 20:00

We have discussed Lynda Cater from Wonder Woman several times here. We know she wears glasses. We also know alot of the glasses she wore on the show either wasn't her correct RX or they didn't have any at all. BUT, later in the second season & third season when she was driving, she wore a different pair. These glasses were presumably her own avaitor style frames with noticable lens deflection.

I have an album of pix "Dianna Prince" http://albums.photo.epson.com/j/AlbumIndex?u=4231226&a;=31664795&f;=

http://albums.photo.epson.com/j/AlbumIndex?u=4231226&a;=31664795&sp;=25

where there are currently 43 images showing these different glasses along with Lynda as a maid wearing wire rims.

Below are a few examples.

 14 Aug 2005, 11:07

Does anyone know Jessica Alba's Rx? How can she function without correction? If she doesn't want to wear glasses why did she also stop wearing contacts? What is behind her refusal to wear correction? Does she think she shouldn't have to wear correction now that she is "JESSICA ALBA", I am to sexy for my skirt? Or does she just want to piss off her mum. Squinting causes eye fatigue, tripping over or walking into things and always asking the person next to you to read something or asking them "who's that standing over there" makes you a pain to be around. I once knew a girl who would not wear her glasess and was always asking someone to see for her. She stopped this when we would say back to her "were is your white cane". She still would not wear her glasses but she would carry them with her and would put them on for a second to see then she was quick to take them off again.

gwgs 04 Aug 2005, 06:05

Got these off Coronation Street a couple of nights ago, Claire wears spex full time and has done for a few months. In these couple of months she has already changed her glasses twice, and in this episode she gets into a fight with another girl who proceeds to stamp on her spex!

For those who think they are plano - which i guessed there would be a few - i deliberately did some shots showing cut in and magnification.

I loved the moment before this as you see her spex falling off and she goes to grab them and put them back on but the other girl squashes them with her handbag. I think her reaching for the spex was a real reaction considering they her glasses weren't props. Great :)

Guest 27 Jun 2005, 23:23

I must respectfully disagree with Noodles regarding Elisabeth Hasselbeck. Having seen her in glasses a number of times on The View as well as in episodes of Survivor there is a very obvious Rx in her lenses. I'm no expert but I would conservatively estimate it to be at least -3 to -4. Anybody else care to guess?

noodles 27 Jun 2005, 18:55

...Glasses on women these days are perceived to give an added sense of sophistication and sexiness to the wearer. So cool are they that some women (including celebrities) have confessed to wearing specs as a fashion statement despite their vision being perfect.

I think Elisabeth is one of these fashion conscious women. She is a beautiful woman who looks stunning in a heavy frame. She probably thinks so too, or why else would she wear them! She wants to be able to say "I wear glasses", but, more than likely, an eye exam revealed she has no requirement for corrective lenses (or a very weak Rx). Not to be out done, she reveals a very noticeable frame, possibly to hide the fact she focuses through plano lenses.

My opinion is she only appears four-eyed where most people see her on the TV show, The View. Perhaps the show's producers have even told her to wear specs in an attempt to boost ratings and/or her appeal.

Maybe she does need the "fashion frames" to read the teleprompter, but if this is the case what does she use to correct her vision when not bespectacled?? I find it hard to believe she would choose contacts over specs in the morning!

I think you'll find her vision does not require the glasses. Having said all that, she is one of the best examples of a celebrity in glasses and should be encouraged to wear them more often.

noodles 27 Jun 2005, 18:43

There are a few (literally 2) photos of Elisabeth Hasselbeck wearing a pair of thick black specs which give her a sophisticated image. A very bold frame selection which she obviously likes the look of, even exposing the heavy sidearms by pulling back her hair.

The fact that she looks so great in glasses and wears them so infrequently, got me wondering weather they are real. Does Elisabeth REQUIRE glasses?

I've been searching the web trying to find any details about her vision and have found nothing. It's hard to tell weather there is any correction in those lenses of hers. As a result I have come to my own conclusion....

Speximann 17 Jun 2005, 21:09

ABC, If there looking into the machine,will we still be able to see their faces? Suggestions on plastic frames..... I have a fairly nice selection of modern,(last 2 yrs.) frames to choose from. Do you have a frame style, or someone in mind? You can send them to speximann426@yahoo.com if you like.

Julian 16 Jun 2005, 23:51

Yes abc, but some optometrists use trial frames rather than a phoropter.

abc 16 Jun 2005, 23:35

Don't care what other people say, I am a big fan of your work and always look at your updates!

If I could suggest a few plastic frames on the upcoming pics - they are coming into fashion again and really show off a woman (i think)

Anyone who has had an eye exam would have used a phoropter. A phoropter is used to determine your level of farsightedness, nearsightedness, astigmatism and presbyopia and therefore strength of corrective lenses It is a large "mask like" instrument that houses all possible corrective lenses. It is positioned in front of your eyes (like a big set of binoculars) and you view through a series of different lens choices. The doctor will ask which lens selection is better. Based on your answers, the doctor will continue to fine-tune your power until reaching a final prescription that provides you with the clearest vision.

Look familiar

http://www.optometrists.asn.au/freestyler/gui/files/phoropter-sample.jpg

http://www.laserforyou.com/images/PtatPhoropter.jpg

So Speximann, any chance of some actresses gazing through the phoropter or trial frame??

Therouteur 15 Jun 2005, 16:51

 15 Jun 2005, 13:09

Speximann 15 Jun 2005, 13:06

"abc" , Thanks, I'm glad you like. I had a gallery of Fake GWGs up & recently took them down because there wasn't alot of hits. In the past, there were several people who seemed a little pissed because they were posted here. They weren't intended to fool anyone, & I didn't know where else to post this type of thing. I will be happy to make another gallery of fakes if anyone would like, as this has turned into a fun little hobby inside a very infatuating subject line. Also see the earlier post of Dianne Krugger Fakes posted a few weeks back as someone requested. Requests are fine,all it takes are a few good quality pix of the actress looking into the camera.

Wurm 08 Jun 2005, 10:59

While checking out Google's print search, I came across this excerpt from the book _Hitchcock and Selznick_:

"Hitchcock would periodically have an optician bring a large selection of frames to the studio and insist that secretary-business manager Carol Stevens choose 4 or 5 pair. 'And if I came on the set without my glasses on, it irritated the devil out of Hitch. He had a fetish about glasses.'"

 07 Jun 2005, 10:03

Speximann 06 Jun 2005, 19:49

Great Post!!!!!!!!!!

 05 Jun 2005, 22:10

The lovely leggy Penny Lancaster oozes specs appeal as she launches Specsavers Opticians' annual search for the nation's sexiest specs wearer.

A photographer and model, Penny is fronting the campaign for the UK's largest optical retailer, which is scouring the country to find Miss or Mr Sexy Specs 2005.

Penny confesses that while she doesn't yet need to wear glasses, popping on a pair makes her feel super sexy and sophisticated.

She says: 'I love to accessorise my outfits with a nice pair of specs. They can make a real fashion statement or transform an understated outfit to create a really striking look.'

Penny also thinks men look great in specs, one in particular, boyfriend Rod Stewart. The veteran rocker often parades around at home in a pair of glasses - to enhance his girlfriend's desires for him. 'I like to see Rod in a nice pair of glasses, he really suits them. They add a sense of mystery and sex appeal.'

Check out some photos of this hot blonde in some specs for the cameras. Too bad there is no strength in those lenses, but at least she's a fan! Just hope her eyes get worse... and fast!

http://www.superiorpics.com/ubbthreads/showflat.php/Cat/0/Number/943110/an/0/page/0

My choice is the 6th photo!

pelegrino 01 Jun 2005, 05:47

I couldn't figure out her RX, but I think she's slightly hyperopic. I just say that, because on some fotos from the side one couldn't see any rings typical for myopics, therefor I'd say she's hyperopic. Also on some fotos with the white background, one could see the reflection of the glasses, which you don't find with myopic glasses. That's just my guess. Correct me if I'm wrong (I don't hope so though, for I prefere hyperopics ;-)

greetings

Optics 26 May 2005, 23:21

Has anyone ever heard of Erica Durance?

I had never until I found these photos of THE sexiest spec wearer on the planet. Without glasses she's an absolute knockout, but when she put on those frames for the Jules Verne Festival she was an absolute bombshell.

Erica owns a very striking pair of glasses. Her frame selection of an all acetate design with thick sidearms is particularly bold. While the slimline rectangular lenses and slight catseye shape add a sophisticated feminine touch. She obviously likes the stylish angularities on the edges and chunky sidearms, choosing to expose these features by pulling back her hair.

It's quite rare to see a female celebrity reveal such noticeable eyewear, but Erica appears so confident in the photos, knowing that she looks so hot!

Does anyone know anything about this four-eyed beauty? Do you think there's any Rx in those lenses?

Speximann,

Bo Derek wears a decent plus prescription, around +4? She is wearing them in "Ghosts Can't Do It" (1990) in a short scene at a lawyers office. It's not available on DVD or I would try to get a decent screen cap, although it is available on VHS.

Speximann 08 May 2005, 20:05

Tod was nice enough to pass on a pic of Katie Holmes wearing her glasses. Unfortunetly, for some strange reason she allowed herself to be photographed with a very bad fever blister/virus infection on her otherwise beautiful face. Photoshop-healing brush to the rescue. It also occured to me someone, for whatever reason took this photo and manipulated it to look like the above mentioned defect. Either way this is one I haven't seen & thought everyone would enjoy it.

* In the past a few members felt computer enhancements(Fakes} were bogus & tring to fool someone,never, but trust me if you like beautiful Girls wearing glasses, this time it was needed.enjoy.

I remember having seen Connie Selleca on one epsiode of P.S.I. Luv U (the 1991 TV series), wearing what must have been her real glasses. The prescription looked similar to those on the 1977 photo.

big ES fan 19 Apr 2005, 07:27

The day I picked up the brochure with the photo of Connie, was in the spring of 1977, at a Pearl Vision Center. My wife and I had gone in to pick up an almost identical pair for her with -4.25 in each eye with some mild cylinder, under -1. I did'nt know who the girl was then, but I commented to my wife about the similarity of the glasses. I thought Connies looked a little stronger, slightly more cut in, but you have to take into account they are setting down on her nose a little too far. They obviously did that on purpose to sell contact lenses. I've always thought they were between -4.25 and -5.00. I looked up Connie on imdb.com and they give her birthday as May 25, 1955, which would have made her 21 or 22 years old. Just guessing I think it would be reasonable to assume that after wearing soft lenses for the last 26 or 27 years, her prescription could have easily more than doubled. This is all guess work but I thought some of you might find it interesting. Guessing and talking about these things is what makes Eye Scene so enjoyable.

Maverick 19 Apr 2005, 05:58

Re Lynda Carter here is a close up of here wearing her real prescription aviators in a Wonder Woman episode. She is not -8.0, probably around -3.5 I'd say.

The vidoe clip of her putting on her glasses is on Alains site under 'movies'. This still is from the same scene in WW. (I provided the clip to Alain a while back_)

http://img254.echo.cx/img254/5797/lyndaww11mj.th.jpg

big ES fan 18 Apr 2005, 12:09

I found the brochure of Connie Selleca from about 1977. It's an advertisement promoting Bausch & Lomb polymacon contact lenses. This was before she became a well known actress and was doing ads. I scanned it in jpeg format, file size about 325kb. I would be glad to e-mail the photo to one person who could post it somewhere. I don't use any of the online photo services. Just guessing I would say the time I saw her on TV, probably 4 or 5 years ago, that her precription had doubled, maybe even more. After it was too late, I wished I had recorded the show. If anyone wants it just post an e-mail address and I will gladly send it.

Specs4Me 18 Apr 2005, 11:27

Linda Carter is very myopic, I've seen her with her real glasses and they are very strong. I would agree with the -8 or more. In the "Wonder Woman" series, she normally wore planos in varying large frame styles, but occasionally she would wear her own. Not often enough for my liking.

Guido 18 Apr 2005, 11:15

Lynda Carter is not a -8. There is a video clip of her on the net where she is starting a car, I think from a Wonder Woman episode. She puts on the glasses in the clip and they are minus, but I do not think -8. The lens size likely makes them appear stronger.

No, what I recall is that the young woman (also wearing glasses with a mild Rx) who appears later in the film is the one who was supposed to be Hitchcock's daughter. I had always heard that Laura Elliott was the myopic woman who gets into the big argument in the record store, and had never heard that the specs she wore weren't hers.

Sigh...another cherished myth shattered.

big ES fan 17 Apr 2005, 20:00

Don,

Connie Selleca was on a TV show where her husband played a trick on her at home, with cameras waiting outside. I can't remember the name of the show but they caught her outside with her glasses on. High index, plano, unbievable power rings and cutin. I would say at least -12 or better. I will try to find a photo of her that I picked up at a vision center in 1977 on a contact lens brochure. Her lenses were strong, but 20 years later they had progressed quite abit. If I find the brochure I will mail it to someone that can post it. The girl in, Stranger On A Train, said in an interview that Hitch made her wear the strongest glasses that they had and she could'nt see a thing. I think Hitch was probably an OO.

() 17 Apr 2005, 19:20

Oscar 17 Apr 2005, 19:10

Two come to mind Don.

1. The girl who plays the murder victim in the original Hitchcock Strangers on a Train. I think the glasses were her own (very strong minus) ones for that - though others may know better.

2. Katy Manning - the Doctor Who assistant when Jon Pertwee was the Doctor. She is extremely myopic and appeared a long time ago (about 20 years at least) on a TV antiques programme wearing her lovely myodisc glasses. She wears contacts all the time otherwise - so no pics I'm afraid.

Interesting storyline in the current Coronation Street UK soap where young Clare - Ashleys wife - finds she is short-sighted and in tonights episode got glasses and goes full time straight off. Not planos either, proper prescription.Dodgy frames though, large plastic.

There was a scene in the pub where Ashley is saying he finds her glasses very attractive and Tyrone says to girlfriend Maria (Samia Ghadie) who is with them 'you should get some glasses' . Oh I wish !!

I posted here a while back that a dream storyline for Corrie would be for Maria who is a real babe, to get glasses - perhaps the producers read this board !!

Curt 23 Feb 2005, 13:33

forever oo: The story still exists. Go to the link "Those Girls with Glasses". From that page, click on the link for "Smudge Report". Now it gets a little tricky...About 2/3 of the way down on the Smudge Report page, you will see a black button that says "menu". When you put your pointer over that, it will open to a series of buttons. Click on the one marked "Essays", and the stories can be found there. I believe they are spread across two volumes in this area.

Happy hunting!!!

Karen X 17 Feb 2005, 14:34

Jo Guest was featured on last nights edition of "Extreme Celebrity Detox" on Channel 4. She is one of a small group of 'celebrities' on a detox course in a very remote rainforest. She was wearing metal frame glasses with what appeared to be a minus prescription. Not a very strong prescription but obviously strong enough for her to want to wear her glasses full-time.

One of the other celebs was comedienne/actress Mina Anwar ("Goodness Gracious Me", "The Kumars..") who also wore glasses most of the time.

The final part of the programme is on tonight at 11:05pm and should feature Jo and Mina again. The programme also featured other groups of celebs in other part of the world on their detox courses. Be warned - this programme is likely to show clips from the first 3 programmes. Some of the detox activities included cleansing the stomach by drinking 3litres of warm water and vomitting it back up, and nasal cavity flossing - sticking a narrow rubber tube town the throat via the nose and out of the mouth to floss like you would floss your teeth. It sounds bad but looks much worse (just how many times do we need to see somone sticking their fingers down their throat and vomit up water?)

Andy 01 Feb 2005, 13:43

Guido I got the trailer from the Apple Quicktime Trailerpage. I use Quicktime pro on my Mac and can save the trailers on my HDD. I bring the window of the movie to the desired seize and do a screenshot of the still picture and elaborate them in Photoshop 7.0 . This procedure works with all DVD or DV-tapes I tranfer to my Mac via firewire.

gwgs 01 Feb 2005, 04:21

Guido, for that i used Irfan View - http://www.irfanview.com

This is a free programme that is very simple to use but i prefer to it Adobe Photoshop. Once you've downloaded this, press "C", and this should bring up the capture window, follow the steps from here.

I have used a couple of programmes in the past but haven't capped anything off tape or DVD for a while but when i did, i used "MGI Videowave 5", and also Dazzle (can't remember the product name.)

One of these wasn't very good, i think it was Videowave (which was more expensive)

Check a couple of these below that i did;

http://img187.exs.cx/my.php?loc=img187ℑ=bridgetfonda006.jpg

http://img187.exs.cx/my.php?loc=img187ℑ=bridgetfonda012.jpg

http://img187.exs.cx/img187/8233/east05.jpg

http://img187.exs.cx/img187/6597/EX-DC5.jpg

http://img187.exs.cx/img187/5407/EX-HC3.jpg

Any more questions, please ask

D-W-V 23 Jan 2005, 03:04

"Foxes" from 1980 - girls in big plastic frames, and with real prescriptions:

Laura Dern wearing plus; she's only in a couple of scenes. Marilyn Kagan wears minus glasses throughout the film.

contemporary review:

http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C02E7D91339E432A2575AC2A9649C94619FD6CF

I generally agree with that review, but the GWG content and the cool '57 Ford pickup makes it well worth owning on DVD.

I read in a article that Tina Fey wears glasses to correct astigmatism. She also wears her glasses on SNL Update to be able to read the teleprompter. Mark 03 Nov 2004, 10:52

Found this via Google...apparently a transcript of an interview:

"Lady from InStyle: When Lauren was growing up, she said that she didn't consider herself one of the pretty girls. In fact, there was one point where she was taller than every boy in her class, had glasses, braces, and a cast. At that time, her strength was being able to tell really great jokes, and giving a running commentary on everything that was happening in the school."

Doesn't mean, for sure, that she still needs glasses...but it's pretty likely.

Andy 05 Sep 2004, 22:53

Wurm I don't think the story behind these famous glasses Laura Elliott aka Kasey Rogers wore in "Strangers on a train" is true. I remember coming across a page on the Internet where in an Interview Mrs. Elliott/Rogers reported, that Mr. Hitchkock had several pairs of glasses made for the movie. Mrs. Elliott/Rogers stated that she couldn't see a thing when she wore those glasses. She described the scene in the musicstore when she followed her husband out of the store after their big argument. She stated that she had her hand on the counter, using it as a guideline and that it had invisible marks she could feel with her fingers so that she wouldn't run out of focus of the camera. She gave another example. It is the scene where she jumps off the bus with her two friends. It is clearly visible how they lead her, because she can't see with her stong glasses.

I remember that when I read this intervies I looked on the scenes she described on the DVD of this film. I was somewhat disappointed to learn that she didn't need those strong glasses. I hope I could find this page again.

Wurm 05 Sep 2004, 22:22

Yesterday I went to see the recent additions to the cinema memorabilia collection of a local video store (Movie Madness in Portland, Oregon) and there they were -- the famous glasses Laura Elliot wore in Strangers on a Train!

They were in quite poor shape. The damage was characteristic of reaction with makeup and/or skin oils. Most likely she wore them for many more years after the film.

The exhibit stated that Movie Madness purchased the glasses directly from Ms. Elliot.

Here's a grab from the film:

http://web.archive.org/web/19991118052649/people.delphi.com/eyescene/images/strange1.jpg

Tod 07 Aug 2004, 12:21

BRITTANY'S ODD BABYSITTING JOB FOR CONTACT LENSES

Short-sighted actress BRITTANY MURPHY became a teenage guardian for a neighbour's three kids in a bid to save up for her first contact lenses.

The JUST MARRIED star had the oddest babysitting job growing up in New Jersey - she had to look after, and not lose, three kids for 10 hours every day.

She explains, "The mother would ask me to take the children out for 10 hours a day and not return them until the 10 hours were up, and I got paid

25 cents a kid. And if one was missing that day I would only make 50 cents.

"I would walk the kids around and bring them back. Sometimes, even if they had a fever, I'd take them out.

"I was trying to earn $250 (GBP 139) to buy coloured contacts, which just came out on the market... My mother has these big, beautiful blue eyes...

I've always wanted blue eyes.

"I saved up $250, got the contacts wore them twice, they flopped out of my eyes the second time I wore them and my mum found them like crusty little dimes.

"Now I wear contact lenses all the time, I'm very nearsighted."

MinusMan 06 Aug 2004, 20:29

Last week Brittney Murphey was a guest on David Letterman. She told him how when she was a tenager she worked to save up money to get blue contact lenses. She then told him she wears clear ones now because she is "very nearsighted".

And being a Lynda Carter fan, I purchased the season 1 set of Wonder Woman. In the commentary she goes on about what a difficult time she had because she could not keep hard contacts in her eye and was blind as a bat. She says they used to put sandbags down where she was supposed to stand because she couldn't se the chalk mark the other actors used.

Unfortunatly- no glasses to be seen in either case...

AS SLIM PICKINS WOULD SAY: 20 Jul 2004, 15:55

JUST WHAT IN THE WIDE, WIDE WORLD OF SPORTS IS GOING ON HERE??

http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/programmes/restoration/help/

Karen X 20 Jul 2004, 15:16

Not exactly an actress this one. She's an architectural expert on this British tv show which helps raise money to restore historic buildings. The tv show is called "Restoration" and it's on BBC2 at 9:00pm on Sundays and Tuesdays. The lady in question is a rather cute, petite brunette called Marianne Suhr (aged about late 20s to early 30s). She often wears glasses with a + prescription as she looks around these old (often decaying) buildings.

I can't find any photos of her so you'll have to watch the tv show to see her and see if she's wearing her glasses. (There is a mini biography about her here http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/programmes/restoration/help/ )

 10 Jul 2004, 18:37

C_R_A_P :

What exactly you didn't understand and you are shouting? We didn't tell you to create a nuclear bomb! Just how to download the file!

Step 1: Download a client program from the ones i said or the one there is in D-W-V's first link.

Step 2: Install that program.

Step 3: Download the torrent file in D-W-V's second link.

Step 4: Open the client program.

Step 5: From that program, open the torrent file.

Step 6: Then, the download of the video file should start and sometime end.

And something else:

ALL OF THIS SHIT WORKS!!!!!

P.S.: Try to be more friendly when someone gives you instructions on how to do something... It helps a bit...

 10 Jul 2004, 15:46

whether not weather

D-W-V 10 Jul 2004, 15:46

Just to make things a little clearer: torrents aren't like normal downloads where you click on a link and save it directly to disk. Torrent links require special client software which basically joins you to a peer-to-peer network dedicated to that one file. As your client downloads the file referenced by the torrent link, it also shares out the portions you've downloaded. So, rather than hammering one download source as is the case with FTP transfers, the bandwidth is shared across many servers.

As to weather reality show participants aren't acting... well, would YOU really be yourself if the camera was on you?

? 10 Jul 2004, 14:45

jessica simpson is not an actress. soooo what gives?

!!!!! 10 Jul 2004, 12:49

please give the URL for this Jessica Simpson thing!

oscar 10 Jul 2004, 09:08

baua's right - it does work. Experiment with a few different clients (there are loads of them). If you're using a mac another good one is Azureus.

baua 10 Jul 2004, 07:55

it works... maybe u suck!?

C_R_A_P 10 Jul 2004, 07:30

NONE OF THIS SHIT WORKS!!!!!!!!!!!

D-W-V 10 Jul 2004, 02:34

This is the client I used:

http://bitconjurer.org/BitTorrent/download.html (there's versions for Windoze, Mac OS X, and Debian)

And, um, I swear the search on "newlyweds" found the file when I used it a couple days ao, but it ain't there now. This should link to the torrent:

http://66.90.75.92/suprnova//torrents/2112/newlyweds.nick.and.jessica.s03e04.xvid-tbs.torrent

 09 Jul 2004, 19:21

For whoever cannot download or find the file:

1) Search for nick and jessica, not for newlyweds. I don't know why, but only in that way you will be able to find the file.

2) The file you will find is only 14 KB and it is called a bittorrent file. You will have to use a bittorrent client in order to download the episode. One good bittorrent client is Azureus, but you will also need Java Runtime Environment for that. Other good clients are BitSpirit, ABC, TorrentStorm and many others.

When you have installed one of the above, just use the operation "open torrent" or something like that and the episode will start downloading, just if you were using Kazaa or any other file-sharing program. When it ends it will go to "seeding mode". Just choose "stop" and "remove torrent" to end it.

oscar 09 Jul 2004, 17:37

not sure David, but given your supreme web-meister skills, it would be worth downloading all the stuff to get it as bittorrent - it's all free.

david 09 Jul 2004, 17:12

when does this episode of newlyweds get shown in the uk??? i wanna see it soooooo bad

oscar 09 Jul 2004, 08:06

One other thing which might be useful for other Mac users. I couldn't get the .avi to play using QuickTime (even the latest version...and with QuickTimePro upgrade).

Instead, it opened up instantly with a very cool (free) download called MPlayer OSX 2. You can find it here:

http://mplayerosx.sourceforge.net/

oscar 09 Jul 2004, 07:48

Great, great, great download. Jessica's friend Casey is the one with quite weak glasses. Jessica's glasses are a completely different story: very small hi-index lenses which still look pretty strong and have significant cut in. So yes - I agree with those that were saying that her prescription was at least -6 or so. Such a shame it isn't any more...

By the way, for those with a decent player, the picture quality is very good - so it's worth the long download time if you want to see the programme.

oscar 09 Jul 2004, 05:05

As for the software needed to read it, for the mac there is a thing called BitTorrent_OSX_3.4.2. It's a free download.

Jes Fan 08 Jul 2004, 19:10

Look closely at the different shots of Jessica. The shot where she is reading the Lasik brochure, she has on weaker glasses!!! Maybe in -3 range. Other shots, her glasses are DEFINITELY stronger, maybe -7 or -8. Only 2 options - these are reading glasses, OR, she was posing with lower power lenses so she wouldn't look so blind!

visitor 08 Jul 2004, 17:07

I would guess that Jessica's script was in the range of -7 or -8 from the looks of them and from the eye exam they had her do. She was so cute and vulnerable when she couldn't even see the big E and count fingers until they were about three ft away. I was surprised at how much she was going without her glasses on the way to and just prior to the surgery. It was a lot of fun being a fly on wall during her exam. I was fantasizing a little about being able to watch some of my other favorite GWG celebrities during their exams, and finding out what only they and their optomotrists know about their strong prescriptions.

Guido 08 Jul 2004, 11:18

Jessica's script looked pretty substantial in the shots of her in the kitchen with her glasses. I would guess, no less than -5, maybe as high as -7/-8. The friends glasses were in the low range, and when she tried Jessica's sunglasses on in the car, she remarked that that is probably how she would see after the procedure.

 25 Jun 2004, 05:12

RGPs are easy to spot in hi res photos. They only cover part of the cornea. Soft lenses cover the whole cornea. I'm not into glasses that much but am more interested in women that wear hard contact lenses. I've spotted them in numerous pictures of various female celebrities. Kirstin Dunst,Geri Halliwell, Melanie Griffith, Jamie Lee Curtis, Sheryl Crow, Lindsay Lohan,etc...

LikeGlass 21 Jun 2004, 18:37

Regarding protected links like Anglefire:

1) Copy the link

2) Click on the link

3) When the new blocked window opens, past the link and hit enter.

Protected links redirect, in this case to http ://www.angelfire.lycos.com/doc/images/rloadblock.jpg

(Their version of FU) But once you are jumping from THEIR server, the link will open in that window.

ChrisB 17 Jun 2004, 15:29

Movielover the film 'Snake Eyes' with Nikolas Cage, Carla Gugini (spy kids) and Gary Sinse features Carla wearing quite strong glasses which she looses. There is a scene where the camera shows her strongly blurred vision.

Its a bit of a mess of a film as it didnt seem to know where it was going some of the time. It struck me that dePalma had intended to use more of the impact of her characters poor vision but forgot about it somewhere along the way.

Julian 15 Jun 2004, 15:22

Movie Lover 15 Jun 2004, 10:06

I know that there have been a number of films out there that show people in glasses, but I am trying to compile a list of the best films/tv shows where a person loses their glasses and it is demonstrated in the show that this person has really bad eyesight (blurry first person camera, they constantly stumble around, etc).

So far I can think of that I have seen on this board so far:

Adventures in Babysitting

Girl sits glasses down to rub eyes and a homeless lady comes along and steals her glasses. Camera shows how blurry her eyesight is without them on.

Papillion

Prisoner loses thick glasses while wrestling an alligator and later finds them. Camera shows how blurry his eyesight is, and he has difficulty doing anything without the glasses on.

A Dangerous Woman

Crazy lady needs her strong glasses or she loses it and gets spaced out.

Mr. Magoo

Always mistaking everything for something else because he cannot see two inches in front of his nose.

Any others that you can think of?

another beckinsale quote from an interview about van helsing the movie

Q: What's the most difficult thing you've had to do on this film so far?

BECKINSALE: It's always the really stupid thing. On Underworld, I had to do this incredibly difficult flip and it was really dangerous and scary and that was really no problem. The thing that flew over the mat was, someone had to throw me some car keys and I had to catch them and I don't see all that well without glasses on, and I haven't got very good hand-to-eye.

phoenix 17 May 2004, 06:36

I didn't know where to post this, but this seems to be the right place.

A few days ago I was watching this year's Eurovision Song Contest and I remembered about a Latvian singer that had won the contest about 2 years ago (maybe it was 2002). Her name is Marija Naumova (also known as Marie N). Some days after she had won the contest, I had seen her in a interview wearing some pretty minus glasses (I think they were purple plastic glasses).

So yesterday I started a little search on the Internet about her. I didn't find much about her, but I did find two yahoo groups.

http://launch.groups.yahoo.com/group/marija_naumova/

http://launch.groups.yahoo.com/group/marie_n/

I couldn't find any photos of her in glasses, but in the first group there is a message from someone who is mentioning that she used to wear pretty thick glasses and that she was pretty ugly. But as time passed by, she started becoming prettier and prettier until she stopped wearing glasses. Sigh! Finally he says, that during the Eurovision Song Contest that she won, she lost her contact lenses and almost went on stage bare-eyed!!! It's message number 125.

Does anyone has any photos of her wearing glasses, or knows anything about her?

Curt 27 Apr 2004, 07:14

bb2: What makes you think that actresses do not wear their own glasses in movies? Demi Moore has worn specs with her real Rx in them in "The Seventh Sign", "A Few Good Men", "Nothing But Trouble" and a couple others. Daryl Hannah wore glasses with her prescription in them in "Roxanne" and "The Gingerbread Man". Margot Kidder wore her real glasses in "Superman II" and "Amityville Horror". I could go on and on, but I won't. The point is, many actresses will wear their real glasses in movies rather than props. Prop glasses should be outlawed (like Jodie Foster's in "Contact" or Alicia Silverstone's in "True Crime).

Oscar 13 Apr 2004, 03:36

Myopeinhere - Katy Manning has been discussed quite a few times before on this forum - and yes, she was simply lovely as Jo Grant in Doctor Who. I can only recall one sighting of her in glasses - on an antiques programme from the early 1970s. They were indeed extremely strong (myodiscs - which they had to be in the huge frames that were fashionable at the time) but even so she kept taking them on and off. The only glasses pics on the web show her either in sunglasses or reading glasses which she obviously uses over contacts now. She was the absolute fantasy girl of my teenage years, and the discovery that she was a gwg with an extremely strong prescription just made her even lovelier. Round about 1970 (?) there was an interview with her in the Radio Times in which she spoke about her eyesight and how (truly) bad it was - wonder if anyone has found that. But still no glasses pic. Ah, the memories...

myhopeinhere 13 Apr 2004, 01:45

Tod 10 Apr 2004, 12:04

I also one eye that requires a toric lens and I can tell the difference. when the light hits it right it destorts thr look of my cornea un like the spherical lens on my other eye.

I saw a life size photp of Angelina in Block Buster. I could even see the likeness of contact lenses on her eyes.

AJ talked about her having trouble wearing contacts when in Cambodia (I think it was) due to all the rain they were having but she said it was better than wearing glasses in the rain.

AJ also once talked about how her brother and his friends used to make fun of her that she had to wear glasses and at the time braces. That's when her mother took her to get contacts. I think she was about eleven y/o.

Tod 22 Mar 2004, 13:49

Check out a 1975 TV movie called 'Katherine'

starring Sissy Spacek and Henry Winkler.

She starts out at collage wearing contact lenses but then she begins wearing glasses and becomes a political radical on campus.During one scene she is in bed with Winkler and she remarks she can't see who just came into the dorm because she has her glasses off. Later in the film there is a riot on campus and she is knocked to the ground and her glasses come off. She frantically feels around for her missing glasses but can't find them. The camera then shows her vision as a heavy blur as she flees the scene.

Dan 13 Mar 2004, 11:00

You're right Angie. To read a teleprompter you need good eyes. If I take off my -1.00 glasses I can't read it without squinting noticeably.

angie 13 Mar 2004, 09:28

MVIII: i've never seen a cue card with letters as large as the top E of an eye chart, and the letters on telepompters (which is what they use at the oscars) are often smaller. additionally, presenters stand much farther away from the teleprompter than we do from the eye chart during an exam...so it's definitely plausible that she would need her glasses to read properly.

Electra 13 Mar 2004, 07:43

MVIII: I guess I just don't share your cynicism of her statements. I've done plenty of second-guessing of people's behaviour in my time (you better believe it) regarding their glasses, but if a lady says she wore her glasses to see, I'm not going to contradict her.

But, on your other remark, yes, I thought they were the ugliest specs I've seen in years, and a good enough reason for her to take them off when she'd finished reading!

MVIII 13 Mar 2004, 06:44

Electra

Have you ever seen a "cue card?" The letters are at least the size of the largest letter on the top of an eye test chart. Most people who need visual help in the lower ranges could easily read them with out glasses.

Ms. Tyler put her glasses back on two, three, or possibly four times when she presented those songs. If she needed them, I doubt they would have come off her face even once.

Her hair style was a dramatic throwback to the 50's, and not all that easy to swallow. And, her cateye frames matched. Frankly, I don't think she had the courage to tell the truth; that the glasses were simply a tool to further accentuate her look, and at the same time take our focus away from her hair. A balancing act of sorts. Of course the glasses could well have come before the hair if she's one of us.

The women in the room that night thought she was the leading candidate for the Worst Dressed Award. I didn't share that opinion.

Electra 13 Mar 2004, 05:26

MVII well, if Liv herself said she needed them, that's good enough isn't it? And haven't you noticed that these days it often isn't possible to detect any strength in a lower strength lens unless you are actually WITH the person? If you have enough close-up photos eventually you might find one at the "right" angle to give it away, but this is not a study for the faint of heart. The file on my computer marked "Johnny Depp" contains 410 photos and I still haven't pegged him.

MVIII 12 Mar 2004, 17:15

Recently I strained my eyes trying to see if Liv Tyler had any correction in those retro frames she was wearing. I didn't detect even a hint of noticable minification, or magnification as she was putting them on. Perhaps she's one of us.

In any case, I'll bet she could have given Maggie Gyllenhaal some competition when they were doing auditions for part of Lee Holloway in "Secretary."

Electra 10 Mar 2004, 13:08

Liv was interviewed in "People" so I thought I'd share it with you (typed exactly as printed):

Was Liv Tyler going for a sexy secretary look with those vintage-inspired glasses, or is she just a closet geek? The actress who fiddled with a pair of Selima Optique frames while introducing some of the Best Song nominees, says her specs were strictly utilitarian and not a retro fashion statement. "The last time I presented at the Oscars I couldn't see the monitor," says Tyler. "But when I went to the SAG awards the other day, I couldn't see a thing! I tried to buy contacts but one of them didn't fit. I didn't have time to get [new glasses], so I had to weat these."

I would guess Megan Mullally at -3 to -4.

Specs4Me 01 Mar 2004, 13:40

I believe that Renee Zellweger is very myopic and was wearing contacts. My guess is that she wears hard (Gas Permeable) lenses which cause her to squint like that. If she is as myopic as I think she is, she would not have been able to read the notes that she had in her hand without putting the paper about 2 or 3 inches from her eyes.

I could be wrong and would like to hear from someone who has better information.

Dan 01 Mar 2004, 13:22

Not really, have you ever read a teleprompter. It's actually quite tricky to read, you need perfect vision to do it, the slightest bit of imperfection makes it very difficult. I'd rather drive without my specs than try to read a teleprompter. I'm -1.00.

Liver 01 Mar 2004, 12:19

The most interesting thing about Liv Tyler wearing glasses is that she didn't wear them at all prior to coming on stage, and then when she went back to her seat after her presentation she never wore them again. Obviously everything was bathed in blur on stage, but she didn't seem to care.

ReFractor 17 Feb 2004, 16:56

Just found out that Amber Benson, who played Tara on Buffy the Vampire Slayer, wore glasses as a kid. This quote was taken from a speech she gave in 2002:

"...just like when I was a kid, I was taken outside of my head. It's tough. I was a little tiny thing with big plastic glasses that apparently I picked out for myself; my mom says I did. I got called "four eyes"; I got made fun of. I would escape. I'd go see a movie. I'd read a book. It saved me. It kept me from losing my mind."

ReFractor 17 Feb 2004, 16:41

"On May 22, 2003 The Discovery Fund For Eye Research is launching its 3rd annual "Seeing the Stars," celebrity charity eyewear and memorabilia auction on eBay. Melissa Joan Hart has generously donated her glasses and a signed photo with certificate of authenticity for auction to benefit the Discovery Fund's medical research and patient education programs for Macular Degeneration, Keratoconus, Diabetic Retinopathy and Ocular Herpes."

Hmmmm

I've never seen MJH in glasses. Might be worth investigating.

A cosmic moment for Eddy yesterday. One of Eddy's constant companions in his twilight years is Fran Drescher in her guise as the Nanny. Thanks to cable TV you can be surrounded by crap ALL the time. But what an inspiration, what charm, what beauty. Not even Mr Viagra can stir as much of the little that is left of the Eddyorial spirit as can a mere glance of the lovely Fran.

So you can imagine that it was with more than a little excitement that, in the midst of a bio of her, Eddy caught a glimpse, but a real one, of her in the 80's wearing some lovely round 80s style glasses with some serious cut-in.

Jon 21 Jan 2004, 00:36

Hey all... Just had the misfortune to see a terrible movie... "Alex and Emma." The only potentially positive thing was that Kate Hudson, who plays an attractive young stenographer (Emma) has a pair of glasses hanging around her neck literally throughout the entire movie. But (and here's the thing)... She NEVER puts them on - not even once. As it became apparent how bad the movie was, I was looking forward to seeing her do the stenography with the glasses on. As you know, in these Hollywood films, a glasses-wearing character puts them on at least once near the beginning of the film and then (as if by magic) doesn't need them anymore. But this time, they were uselessly just hanging around her neck... and she was doing the stenography for about 90% of the movie (presumably what she needed them for). Sheesh!!! As fellow glasses-lovers, don't you hate when films do that?

Batman 14 Jan 2004, 08:23

To me, this forum should be about any female public figure in the world of entertainment. That would take in actresses, reporters, celebrities, etc. The common link is that all are female, and all are in the public sphere.

This means that these women have voluntarily given up a portion of their right of privacy. Because of this, I feel justified in viewing and sharing pictures of these women.

And while the web may also be considered a media outlet, sometimes girls get their pictures posted by spiteful ex-boyfriends or by some other involuntary means, and often they don't know their pictures are even out there to see.

This is why I feel that this forum should only contain links to females in the public sphere, and not to those on the web.

Angie - My assumption that Stephanie March's glasses are legitimate is based solely on observation. Close-ups seem to show a small amount of "cut-in" and her lenses,when seen from the side offer some distortion. The type of correction and it's strength are best left to those on this site with far greater expertise than I have.

david 25 Jul 2003, 14:44

i just typed in 'kate beckinsale glasses' on google.com and one of the sites it came up with said that she had damaged her eyesight through anorexia and now needs glasses. i am not sure how true this is but it was a kate beckinsale website so it should be quite reliable

lentifan 24 Jul 2003, 15:52

I think I read somewhere once that there is a condition called 'malignant myopia' in which, as well as progressive high myopia there are other symptoms including weight loss and general ill health. This was probably quite an old source and may be quite out of date, but it could it be confused with our rather more modern condition of anorexia (by the press anyway, who rarely get anything right)?

Or it may of course be completely irrelevant.

Alan 24 Jul 2003, 12:45

I don't know how the anorexia/eye-trouble link works either, but I have heard it in some other article I read or something, besides the Beckinsale story.

I also knew someone in college who was very malnourished because of anorexia and I never knew she wore contacts at the time, but I saw her recently (5 years hence) and she was wearing very strong glasses, maybe -15 (and had gotten much healthier weight-wise). I have no idea if the anorexia impacted her eyesight. I would expect that if there were a connection between anorexia and eyesight, there would be a single typical problem that afflicts people - not nearsightedness in one case and whatever Kate's problem is (presbyopia?) in another case. A link with myopia doesn't seem all that likely to me, since myopia is arguably not indicative of poor *health* in the eye. But that definitely doesn't prove it's impossible.

Guido 23 Jul 2003, 19:07

Gee, if that were the case, you know, anorexia = stronger glasses, there will be a lot of emaciated people on this board.

MacKenna 23 Jul 2003, 18:04

loonyettes 24 May 2003, 11:51

This won't mean much if you live outside the UK, but anyway ...

Melanie Sykes covered the spectacle wearers of the year award about five years back for Richard and Judy when it was on in the morning. Judy was ill (for at least a year) and Richard's co-presenter was Jenny someone or another - she was in 'No Limits' in the 1980s. Anyway, Jenny don't-know-her-surname wore big black framed glasses for the whole show. As did Melanie Sykes. It was fantastic.

More recently, the woman in the booth on the morning show, The Wright Stuff at 11.00 AM on Channel 5, wore great plus lenses recently, when the show celebrated this years spectacle wearers of the year awards. Another member of the team moaned about having to wear glasses - 'I hate them' she moaned, but she looked exquisite.

Lastly, I remember Liz Hurley wearing large framed brown plastic glasses at a dinner a couple of years back trying to win the same awards.

Furtive 19 Apr 2003, 18:28

I read an article about Tina Fey that said that she usually wears contacts and that the glasses are actually in her prescription and that she needs them in order to read the cue cards , but they are a "prop" in the sense that they are property of Saturday Night Live. It said that one week she didn't wear the glasses while doing the "Weekend Update" - because she had her contacts in because she was doing another, glasses-less, scene right afterward - and they got a lot of emails from disappointed fans saying "bring back the glasses." So now they always have her wear them for the Weekend Update.

SC 11 Apr 2003, 02:50

Very annoyed with myself not to be able to report more.......this morning on Biography Channel there was an hour long interview with Debra Winger on "Inside the actors Studio". As we know she appeared with very strong glasses in the film A Dangerous Woman and I know there were discussions if the glasses were her own RX. Unfortunately the show had started by the time I flicked to the channel and as it was 8 o'clock I was also getting ready for work so had to keep popping in and out. The bit I caught that was interesting was when she spoke about an accident where she fell off the back of a truck and suffered a head injury. She said that the accident made her vision worse, then laughed with tongue in cheek saying well worse than the little I had. This meant I thought that prior to this she must have spoken or had a pic shown of her in glasses.

Later when a Dangerous Woman was mentioned the interviewer said many actresses wouldn't have taken on this role and she said oh, cos of the glasses you mean. I wish I had caught all the interview.

It was on Sky TV - I am sure it will be repeated again-perhaps today even so will look out for it.

Val 08 Apr 2003, 04:43

An article about Sandra Bullock : http://www.aclasscelebs.com/sandrab/article.htm

Bullock likes being nearsighted. Without glasses, she doesn't have to deal with the world at large. "It's great," she says. "I see only what's in front of me. I don't see people pointing or being mean." With the glasses on, "you can hide. It's a great barrier. Like, `Now I can do anything"

Spec Watcher 11 Mar 2003, 14:22

Yes, the 4 Days of our Lives GWG's are my favorites too. Like I said before, they rarely if ever wear glasses in public. So there are not that many on the web. Chloe wore glasses all the time in her first 2 years and never wears them now. The actress that plays Chloe (Nadia Bjorlin) says that her vision is perfect in an interview. Lately, Sami wears glasses on the most frequent basis now. The actress that plays Sami wears glasses in real life. I have seen Belle wear glasses twice. I believe that they are real with a medium strength plus lens. Mimi just started to wear glasses.

Being a great fan of Frances McDormand I couldn't help checking out her new flick entitled "Laurel Canyon" which is all about the family of a somewhat decadent lady record producer living in Los Angeles.

One of the side benefits was the visually delightful Kate Beckinside who wore some delightful specs through part of the picture. They appeared to be in the +2 range, and I thought there might have been a bit of progressive add, but I couldn't tell for sure. One thing I do know is, I wanted to pull her down off the screen, and have her just for myself. Ummm! During the time the glasses adorned her face her character was decidedly librarianesque, and that merrits another Ummm!

Vidge 22 Feb 2003, 16:26

a 1987 two part TV movie called 'Student Exchange' Starring Viveka Davis. she plays a unpopular, nerdy, glasses wearing Carol Whitcomb who gets herself contact lenses and a new hair style to pose as French exchange student Simone Swaare in order to become a "hot item" at her high school. Which she does. In one scene, she tries to act discretely as she loses a contact lens while being confronted by a group of the "in" girls who feel she is cutting into their popularity.

Has anyone seen this film?

Eddy 15 Feb 2003, 18:25

Just went to see "8 Femmes". Good fun but don't let anyone fool you that it's anything but a farce with a few musical numbers thrown in. Agatha Christie meets Baz Luhrman meets Harold Pinter meets "Noises Off". On the gwg front, Isabel Huppert plays a middle aged spinster with great glasses vintage 1956 (Ah, memories) even though they're plano and she takes them off when she magically turns into a sex-strumpf. And if you look closely at the delectable Virginie Le Doyen's close-ups, you can see the edge of her contacts. All in all an enjoyable piece of fluff if just a tad too long for the Eddyorial taste.

Guest 15 Feb 2003, 07:00

Do not forget "A Dangerous Woman", wherein Deborah Winger portrays a mildly mentall challenged young lady with rather high myopia. One of the scenes in the flic is shot through her glasses while the specs are sitting on a table. Very interesting effect. She wears glasses throughout the movie. There was some discussion on this board a while back as to the veracity of the prescription for the actress. I never heard/saw the issue resolved.

Vidge 15 Feb 2003, 05:35

There was this made for TV movie back in the early eighties, the title of which escapes me. Its about this nerdy girl and a male friend who decide to pose as exchange students at their own high school to become popular, which they do. The girl gets herself contact lenses and a new hair style ect. and poses as a French exchange student. The boy, which the film focuses less on, poses as an Italian exchange student.

At one point in the movie the girl loses one of her contact lenses and her cover is almost blown. Also in scenes where she is at home batteling it out with her parents and younger sister she has on her glasses.

I just wish I could remember the name of this movie....anyone!

Brock,

I saw "El Desprecio" as a serial on Latin TV in Canada for a long interval -

Maricarmen Reegueiro wore thick frames initially, but not thick lenses. However, she made up for it with all sorts of good acting and her natural beauty. There were all sorts of wonderful closeups of her in her glasses, too. I wish I had some tape, and a way of making vidcaps. I couldn't understand the plot either, but it became weirder and weirder, from what little I could understand. She still acts, I believe, and is still beautiful!

Brock 06 Jan 2003, 00:35

There is a Spanish language telenovela called "El Desprecio". I glimpsed a snippet several years ago when I happened to be in the southwestern U. S. I speak no Spanish, so I was at a loss to pursue the arresting image of a young woman passenger in a car, struggling repeatedly to adjust a pair of very thick-lensed glasses and at the same time seemingly struggling to overcome an attack of stuttering. (The latter was very hard to discern for certain. The scene was very short, and my lack of Spanish did not help.)

However, I never forgot the name of the telenovela. Tonight, after reading Wanderer's post, I was reminded of it and found the following two URL's. One is a short plot summary (in English, Spanish, and Russian). The other is a collage of images of MariaCarmen Regueiro in her role as Clara Ines. I tried to save the pictures as JPEG files, but my computer says there is an error and won't let me do this - though I have often done so in the past.

Despite my illiteracy in Spanish, I wish I could find a video of this entire film so as to look for more images of a bespectacled Clara Ines.

Sorry for the length of this post.

http://escena.ya.com/mcreg/regueiro/eldesprecio.htm??

http://www.vencor.narod.ru/films/eldespr.htm

wanderer 05 Jan 2003, 19:49

I rented the Adam Sandler movie, _Little Nicky_, and Sandler's love interest (played by Patricia Arquette) wears some frumpy-looking pinkish plastic/metal combination frames in her scenes.

In one scene, Sandler compliments Arquette on her glasses and Arquette replies that her father is an optometrist!

The DVD includes a documentary in which the costume designer mentions that they gave Arquette "very outdated glasses" to add to the quirkiness of her character.

Oscar 29 Dec 2002, 08:44

Personally I can watch Virginie Ledoyen all day...and for some of the Christmas break that's just what I have been doing. I can't think of a more beautiful actress with or without glasses. Other admirers of the exceptionally lovely actress, who is also exceptionally talented, might be interested to know about the DVD releases of some of her films. In the versions available in France (or from France on the web) the "Making of" bonus sections of "8 femmes" and "Jeanne et le garçon formidable" both feature brief moments of Virginie in her glasses (minus 5 or so). There's a particularly nice shot (very brief, but still delectable) of her in small round specs studying the script in "Jeanne..." during the shooting of the scene in Père Lachaise cemetery. And the rehearsals for "8 femmes" often show her wearing larger, squarish plastic frames.

Knowing that she is significantly myopic also explains her tendency to squint slightly at the camera during interviews (of which there are great examples on both these DVDs, neither with her specs, alas). Ah!

A contact-wearing OO perhaps?

CONTACT LENS SPOTTERS GUIDE 10 Nov 2002, 04:42

To be able to spot contact lens wearers, you must first know something about CL's. Soft lenses are larger in diameter than the iris. You need to look for the outer rim of this lens on the patent's (that's what corrective lens wearers are) scallia or white of the eye. Lens wearers blink more often. Some nearsighted wearers have larger than normal eyes. You may also notice a gleem in their eyes. New wearers may turn their head more to see things to the side as if they were still wearing glasses. They more than likely squint when out in bright sunlight or may need sunglasses. But the best indicator is in the right lighting and angle of view. Overhead floresent lighting is best. And you can always ask the person ,too.

SZ6 09 Nov 2002, 19:15

Lens guy 06 Nov 2002, 04:07

I always found that it's not too hard to spot contact lenses. There's just a certain look they have in their eyes for starters. RGP wearers usually have a funny blink. I find it easier to spot RGPs than soft lenses, especially when looking from the side. I use a mouse that allows me to zoom in on photos. After looking at photos on Rex Features, Corbis, and various online galleries, I've spotted a lot of folks that I'm pretty sure are contact lens wearers. Melanie Griffith, Reba Mcentire, Suzanne Shaw, Amy Irving, Tara Reid, Connie Selleca, Ellen Barkin, Geri Halliwell, Sheryl Crow, and Samantha Fox. I'm pretty sure that they wear RGP lenses. Anyway, just my $.02 worth.

Portia 05 Nov 2002, 22:45

Dweeb, if you want to see contact lenses, just look. I have found them exciting to see since I was in fifth grade and saw CL's on my music teacher, Mrs. Keehn. Been a a keen observer ever since.

I can always spot them given a close enough look at the right angle.

Don't ask how long ago it was that I was in the fifth grade. Suffice it to say that contact lenses were an unusual and luxurious phenomenon at that time and in that place.

dweeb 04 Nov 2002, 17:48

you are all so skilled. how the hell do you tell if someone is wearing contacts?! a ton of my friends wear them and i can't see them unless i'm about 3 inches from their faces which does not occur very frequently i can tell you! anyway i am much in awe of these capabilities and wonder whether you'd be willing to share you secrets?

merci

KYGL 29 Oct 2002, 11:40

GlassesOnTV, I agree about Chyler Leigh on Girls Club. I just sat and drooled the whole show!!!

And Alan, what made Becker so great was that Shawnee Smith's character showed up one day wearing glasses, and her boss said something like "I didn't know you needed glasses," to which she replied "Oh, I don't. I'm just wearing them because it's the thing to do." And then she showed how she could look smart, busy, and even sexy wearing them. Then in the next scene, she wasn't wearing them. Her boss asked what happened to the glasses. She said she glasses are so yesterday, and everybody's having laser surgery. Of course her boss reminded her that she didn't need surgery, and she said "I know, I had fake surgery!" or something like that.

I can't remember the exact dialogue between Shawnee and the office manager, but it was the funniest part of the show!

I am really impressed with the amount of time glasses wearers are being presented on TV. (Finally!) Many, many commercials have bespectacled actresses in them too.

Alan 24 Oct 2002, 09:31

Marsilli,

Film producers/directors do seem to be incredibly silly in this regard. I mean, most adult actresses are college graduates (went to film school) and therefore most of them are probably nearsighted. So how many times has it happened that an actress is cast to wear glasses (to "look nerdy," or whatever)...and so she goes in wearing her -4 contacts and the costume people giver her some plano glasses to wear over the top. Jeesh. How is it that a $30 million movie budget can't afford a decent presentation of wearing glasses.

On the other hand, let this be a lesson to people who are nervous about whether their glasses will seem 'real' to other people. It seems that most people just don't think about it at all.

Alan 22 Oct 2002, 09:09

GGM - I think you're right. Glasses are slowly getting "there" in the fashion world. The new plastic designs are definitely different -- they're bold, but they also "work" in the way other very popular fashions do, I think. In my opinion (contrary to a lot of long-time glasses lovers), glasses styles have improved steadily for the past 15 years or so and are REALLY excellent now.

Glasses Going Mainstream? 22 Oct 2002, 08:51

Do you think glasses (finally!!) are going mainstream and becoming desirable, even on TV? Seems to be some promising signs lately.

Cases in point:

"GIRL'S CLUB" ABC SUN EVE'S

I too watched "Girl's Club" on the Fox network. The name of the bespectacled actress on the show is Chyler Lee. A quick check on the internet showed several pics with her glasses on.

She wore very attractive black plastic frames, slightly cateye in shape, with Rx lenses, at least 1/2 of the show and was exquisite to say the least.

The previews for next week's show not only showed Chyler wearing glasses, but one of the other young ladies on the show was bespectacled as she sat at a computer.

During this show there was a commercial for Lowe's home store and one of the models in it was wearing glasses. An extra plus.

"LIFE WITH BONNIE" ABC TUES EVE'S

The ultimate Glasses show! Bonnie Hunt, who is a really cute blonde, wears black plastic glasses about 90% of the time in the show. It is an entertaining show also and well worth watching.

I think I am seeing a trend here.

A key factor here seems to be the black plastic frames, which in my humble opinion, are the ultimate in female eyewear. Wire frames have become so boring after so many yrs. Perhaps the newness of the dark plastic frames has kindled some interest in eyewear.

The OGL 22 Oct 2002, 07:00

From personal experience, I can tell you that law school is a fertile ground for myopia. Back in my day we had our noses stuck in books almost 24/7 and a lot of my classmates came in without glasses and left with a minus correction. Up until a year ago I employed law clerks, two of them were already myopes and the third showed up one day wearing -.75 sph -.50 cyl OU and I know that's her exact scrip because she got them at the chain store where I worked and I checked on the computer (it wasn't at our exact store, it was our sister store across town so I didn't know until after the fact). Anyway, I asked her the usual questions and learned that in one of the larger classes she couldn't see the overhead projector images, her classmate sitting next to her uttered those immortal words "here, try my glasses" and when she recovered from the shock called for an eye appointment. Unfortunately, I won't be able to watch that show because Mrs. OGL would certainly think something was awry if I watched anything but football on a Monday night!

Caterina 22 Oct 2002, 06:48

Yes, that's the one who wore them.

I could definitely see how I would be actually eager to wear my glasses to work if I were in a situation where a more serious, older, corporate image would be desirable. Such as a law firm.

Alan 22 Oct 2002, 06:44

Thanks, Caterina. I saw a little bit of that show last night. The one who "might be a closet homophobe" wore glasses some of the time, right?

I wonder how common it is for young women in law to "choose" to wear glasses for professional reasons. It certainly strikes me as a good idea, since glasses add to a 'professional' image and that's often useful in law, I think.

Caterina 22 Oct 2002, 06:38

For those who live in the US and would be interested: There's a show on the Fox network Monday nights called Girls' Club. I find that even though they don't DO anything for me, I now notice glasses a lot more. Anyway, it's about these young female lawyers, and one of them seems to wear real glasses a lot. She has cut-ins. I've really appreciated the responses to my posts about my insecurities and just thought I would attempt to "give back."

The OGL 15 Oct 2002, 07:30

In the October 7th issue of Us Weekly magazine, there's an in-depth story on Reese Witherspoon and on page 51 a picture of her captioned "Witherspoon (right, as a bespectacled seventh grader with a classmate)has said she sucked her thumb until age 11." It's impossible to tell for sure because her hair is over the one lens that would be a telltale, but I'm guessing she's a low myope/astigmat and if so unless she's had Lousik she's still is such only more so and there may be hope. If my math is right she was about 12 when the photo was taken so the frames are of the early eighties vintage and definitely of a piece of that era. They are large, probably around a 52 and perfectly round dark tortoise with a flaring silver bridge. As I expect to be sending a package from my collection to one of our webmaster/poster friends will include that pic and see if it can be used. Unfortunately, it's small.

Plastics Lover 09 Oct 2002, 19:48

"Life With Bonnie" I too caught this entertaining new series last night. Bonnie Hunt is a very talented actress and comedienne indeed.

She wore Black Plastic frames, with real Rx lenses, for probably 1/2 of the show. Just looked great.

Am I the only one that thinks this? Isn't the ultimate glasses experience a Blond in Black Plastic Frames? I sure think so. Nothing better.

Lot of plastic frames out there lately in TV land. Cindy Crawford on "According to Jim" last night was wearing heavier dark plastic frames for a short period on this show and had them in her hand fiddling with them for rest of time. Appeared to be real lenses.

"Sami" a cute blond on "Days of our Lives" Soap Opera has often been wearing dark tortoise shell frames on camera. Real lenses. Lot of close ups.

Saw Kirstie Alley in a Pier One ad today wearing dark plastic frames too.

Katie Couric often wears dark plastic frames on the Today show.

Plastic frames sure make the wire frames look dated don't they? I hardly even look at a GWG in metal frames anymore. Plastic frames are just so much sexier!!

The OGL 09 Oct 2002, 09:39

PFA: thanx for confirming what I presumed, although I've never seen either of the daughters with them on. The photo brought back a warm fuzzy,from one of my very first encounters with a celeb wearing glasses (at least in print) courtesy of my mother's Good Housekeeping magazine when I was about 14 or so. They did a big story on her, and there was a small photo where you could see she was wearing them but just barely. A friend was quoted as saying Grace was "extremely nearsighted, couldn't see a thing without them, but wouldn't wear them". The friend also said, and these words in the vernacular of the day have stuck in my mind all these years, "she has the most wonderful technique for freezing a wolf, she would just reach into her purse and take out these big, thick, horn rim glasses and put them on". In today's language that would be getting rid of a creep who was hitting on her.

Last night on the ABC network was watching "Life With Bonnie", a comedy about a TV talk show hostess, and at the first the lead was wearing glasses which I thought maybe were a prop. But she wore them throughout the whole show even at home, at a party, etc. and there were many good closeups. They were a low plus, maybe +1.50 or so, and probably with a little cyl in a rectangular black plastic frame with a high bridge and high brow line, antireflective lenses of course. And, Peter, she's BLONDE! It was a tremendous effect, both for us 00's but really made her character effective. The only thing that ruined it was at the end, she was romantically slow dancing with her hubby and he reached up, took them off her, and put them in his coat pocket. How little they know.......
