Alan 29 Sep 2002, 06:19

I saw The Tuxedo Friday night. There was one instant where I thought the glasses might be prescription, but I think they were actually planos...once again, movies can spend millions of dollars on insanely complicated effects, but they can't make glasses look real.

I am not completely sure why she "needs" the glasses in the movie. Hewitt never puts the glasses on or takes them off within a scene, I don't think, so it could be that she's switching between contacts and glasses. She's supposed to be sort of nerdy (not very convincingly played in that regard, for better or worse), which would be associated with myopia more than anything. But I do think there was a scene or two where she had the glasses clipped on her shirt or dress or something...If I'm not imagining that, then she was just going bare-eyed in these scenes with somewhat compromised vision (also not demonstrated in any way) Maybe astigmatism, low-minus...conceivably plus. But they aren't used to provide any sort of vision-related situations; they're just used as a device to try (and fail utterly) to give Hewitt's character the "nerdy" appearance.

Hewitt's glasses are nice plastic frames of the shape that seems to be really popular right now -- rectangular but taller on the outside and narrower on the inside. Personally I think it's a lousy shape...it looks OK on someone as beautiful as Hewitt, but it doesn't help someone's appearance like a good shape can (IMHO).

Anyway, the movie is somewhat entertaining. I think Hewitt was really funny and engaging (despite mediocre directing). But it's no masterpiece. For one thing, it's painful to watch Jackie Chan have to hold back on his stunt performances because he plays a 'normal' guy in the movie. Plus he's a lot better at martial arts than he is at dramatic acting.

GWg's Rule! 28 Sep 2002, 19:07

 28 Sep 2002, 18:27

does anyone remember this forgetable film: "the Girl I Want" aka "Teen Bimbos"

(1989)

Two bimbos convince a nerdy girl into giving up wearing glasses and start teasing her hair and wearing trampy clothes in order to become popular with guys. Throughout the film she stumbles around in a blur and occasionally sneaks peeks of things by holding her glasses to her face only to be scolded by the two bimbos and then she cant see to reconize the guy who she likes and secretly likes her.

Sopranos Season Premiere 9.15.2002

The OGL 14 Sep 2002, 11:48

Who is Aly Landry? Any pix available? Anyway, as I posted elsewhere earlier, I have fitted post lasik customers almost on a daily basis, and monovision is pretty rare. whether you've gone mono or not, additional low minus is very often the norm. I remember one lovely 29 year old who'd gone from somewhere around -4.50 to what she thought (and probably was at the time) was plano. Two years later the symptoms surfaced, I fitted her with OD -.50 sph -.50 cyl and OS -.50 sph -.75 cyl and she had the usual reaction of a first time low minus wearer. We laughed when I suggested and she admitted that this was probably the same as her very first correction when she was in 3d grade!

S-type 14 Sep 2002, 05:29

Aly Landry had Lasik but on one eye only. (right one I think) I guess its because she can't wear CL's and she is pushing 40 and would otherwise soon be need reading glasses. It seems from TV she can get by with her permenet monovision at most times. But on that dare devil show she was on she had to put on eyeglasses for one event that involved distance seeing. So I guess she still needs glasses for driving, certainly for night driving and watching TV and movies. She is not much better off like this. If I were her I would get the other eye done and go with the readers.

One to look out for. The lovely Carla Gugino appears in Spy Kids 2 as the mum of the two spy kids, with Antonio Banderas as the dad.

Both wear glasses in an extended scene in the middle of the film, as a sign of their 'maturity' and presbyopia. Each to his and her own of course, but the older Carla looks just as sexy as the younger Carla in Snake Eyes.

(Oh Joy, my kids enjoyed the movie so much they took me to see it twice!!)

On a less positive note, Disney have recently released "Princes Diaries" on DVD. The heroine, the girl who gets turned into a princess wears some nice black plastic framed glasses . But then the 'image consultant' breaks her glasses in front of her face and says - it's contact lenses from now on" .

quite the wrong message.

S-type 13 Sep 2002, 07:55

Yes there are many shows where the character wears glasses and so does the actor in real life. On some days of filming the actor prefers to wear contacts and planos are employed. At other times when not, realRx lenses are installed in the frames so the actor can see. The show 'Wonder Woman' with the nearsighted actress/ contact lens spokes person Lynda Carter is a prime example.

The OGL 13 Sep 2002, 07:36

And how about this one: in the old "Life Goes On" series, Kelly Martin often wore glasses (as she does in real life) but sometimes they were plano and some times you could see the minus. In some cases, the plano and the minus were the same frames. And in the current hit Left Wing, er, excuse me, that's West Wing, Allison Janney plays the White House Press Secretary with a pair of small plastic frames that she wears down on her nose almost like half eyes. The problem is, they're for real minus lenses, but she reads through them and then looks over the top for distance. Get real, Hollywood, maybe they should hire one of us as a consultant 8<)

gWgS 13 Sep 2002, 07:17

Fantastic point S-Type:-

I've got a large collection of gwg flicks, ranging from the early days of Batman up to modern day flicks like America's Sweethearts, in enarly all the films i have seen that feature a gwg they only wear them for a few scenes, or take them off for a minute and don't squint or anything.

I haven't watched any for a couple of weeks so can't give detaileds examples, but Kim Basinger everyone knows where's spex in real spex, and in the film where she gets dressed up to go out she doesn't wear them, and when she's trapped with Joker at the end she doesn't them, (they get broken i think) - what is up with this?

It's the same with TV, you'll be watching Cybill where she's looking a treat wearing some nice heavy frames with thick lenses for the opening scenes, and then for the next 25 mins isn't?

Haven't any of these directors heard of what they call in the film biz "continuity editing"??

GwGs

S-type 13 Sep 2002, 06:50

I always wondered what the deal is. You watch some movie and in one scene the actor / actress has glasses on and its unrelated to anything in thr scene ie: reading, ect. or any other scene or plot through the film. In all other scenes they have no glasses on. Like what's up with this? Are the directors brain dead to this? Or do they want the audience to think the character wears contact lenses most days even though has nothing to do with the story line of the film. What gives?

The OGL 29 Aug 2002, 18:33

GWGs: if they're the ones I thinking of, they were in 1981, sticks in my mind it was August both don't hold me to the month. There was a Playboy licensed frame made in those days, I am the proud owner of three of them, they're fairly large squarish ones with a moderately dropped temple and the Playboy bunny logo on the temple where it joins the frame front. Two of mine have never been rx'd, and the third has an upper medium minus #3 brown bifocal sunlens in it. Over the years there have been lots of photos of GWGs in the magazine, particularly their "back to college" issues, but always featuring prop dark bookish frames with plano lenses.

Rimshot 04 Aug 2002, 00:34

Howdy from the Sheraton,

Oscar: How about a pic of Rebecca Cooke.

Forget the Greek Wedding if youre looking for thick minus lenses and more. It could have been a great opportunity to track on film the development of her failing vision since early childhood. Then, how she rid the specs for contacts to insure a better future (this much is in true Hollywood form). But since all that wasnt the focus of the show she got planos and a hefty Greek bod. Meanwhile I was gagging on after 65 perfume and polite theater laughs . . . My pic of the week would be Terms of Endearment (Blockbuster). . . Deborah Winger (The Other Woman). I could have picked it up used at my fav out of town record store but opted to appreciate an image of her wearing specs on the jacket cover . Its been years but I recall an infrequent hefty minus. Talk about reality show . . . Terms was made about 20 years ago- The Other, mid 90s? Im sure Winger had at least one or two good increases within that time period. In the last scene of the later film, family and kids visit her at the care center . . . a young mother wearing wire frames and thick lenses . . . looking lovely . . .

BTW Me Myself and Irene . . . currently on HBO . . .Renees character looks at the jet from the car while wearing specs fitted with a telescopic lens. Ouch! Their appearance is so quick and unexpected that it should count as an extraordinary Sighting.

Lazysiow 29 Jul 2002, 12:04

Lol this sort of isnt about actresses either but I recently found an anime (japanese animation) series called "G-On Riders" and it's about young schoolgirls (what else? :D) who possess the power to SAVE THE WORLD!! from alien invasion. This power is the love, strength and PMS in a young girls heart all rolled into one which can only be harnessed by the G-On invention, which are... a pair of glasses specially made for each girl. This power manifests itself in the form of a sword which represents the girl in some way.

It's a silly show :) but they fight giant pokemon things in order to defend the earth from the 'space aliens' who always attack the same high school in Japan go figure :D All the girls in the school are GwG's and theres hardly any shots that don't feature a piece of eyewear, there are a few shots of them cleaning their glasses, blowing into them to clean too.

The I dont think the show would really appeal to fetishists, its just about silly cute girls in their glasses with some perversion in between :) If anyone wants they can email me at lazysiow@excite.com and I can give you FTP details of how to get it, you will need the Divx codec of course.

Curt 14 May 2002, 06:22

I realize that the doctored photos are just that, and that one still doesn't get to see the lovely effect of cut-ins, etc. As someone (I think it was Fathom) pointed out, this is more to answer a creative "What if?" question, to get the imagination going. It would seem that you also feel that the Stories threads would be of little interest to most members on this board, because obviously most of those are not about real people wearing real glasses...fictional characters are certainly less real than ELizabeth Taylor and Audrey Hepburn.

If you are saying that, on this particular thread, one expects 100% genuine sightings of actresses with real glasses on, I will be happy to change my postings to another thread, if you can suggest a more appropriate one. Otherwise I will continue to post here, and you can just not look at the photos.

Don't worry about tact or hurting my feelings. I didn't do this project for any other reason except to put my favorite actresses in glasses to see what it would be like, and then I put it on the internet and if anyone else wants to see it, fine. My statistics indicate that some people are enjoying, and that since I posted yesterday, either 12 people have come and looked at every single photo, or more people have come and looked at some. That's more than sufficient traffic for me.

I'm probably never going to put anything up there except 50s and 60s movie actresses, for my own purposes, but if anybody else has a celeb, male or female, that they want this done to, just let me know and I'll be happy to put it up.

Satin Doll

Russell 13 May 2002, 10:54

Curt 13 May 2002, 10:18

SatinDoll: Let me be as tactful as I can about this...I'm glad that you take an interest in glasses. But what you are doing probably doesn't interest most of us here. We are interested in REAL people wearing REAL eyeglasses, not taking Photoshop or some other program and artificially placing glasses onto a picture of someone who was not originally wearing them. I mean, what purpose does it serve??? In most cases, the doctoring of the photo looks obvious, or like the 1990's frames on a 1940's picture of Liz Taylor. Photo manipulation can be lots of fun, but at least from my perspective, I would rather see someone in their real prescription glasses - If they don't wear glasses, bummer! But adding glasses to their picture doesn't change the fact that they don't wear glasses. I obviously can't speak for everyone here, but these kind of doctored photos are boring to me anyway...

Portia 10 May 2002, 23:12

I am always seeing new things in old movies. Faye Dunaway in The Thomas Crown Affair (1968) does a scene in which she is studying a photograph of Thomas Crown (Steve McQueen). She is photographed horn-rimmed half glasses with plus lenses, which she then takes off and moves closer to the photograph, using them as one would a magnifying glass. There is then a close in shot of the photograph as seen through these glasses.

Miss Dunaway was 27 years old when this movie was released. She is not playing an older character, nor do these glasses appear in any other scene in the film. There are, however, a very nice array of period sunglasses worn by the star and various other glasses worn by the minor characters.

Fathom 10 May 2002, 19:17

GWGs - not being from the U.S., asking about Congress is very understandable (I'm from Canada myself, where it's not the term we use either...). Technically, Congress refers to both the upper and lower house of the U.S. legislature. But most people use "Congress" in the vernacular to mean only the lower house (House of Representatives) and use "Senate" for the upper house.

If anyone would like to send me any pics for me to do this with, email them to satinedoll@hotmail.com and I'll be happy to. I need them to be in color and decent quality, or the program just will not work. Also, the program cannot angle the glasses, so the subject has to be looking straight on to the camera. If the head is turned just slightly it can work, but it takes a lot of effort and I can't promise it will work.

What if a particular model can't wear contacts? I personally would love to see more models sporting specs. Bob 23 Mar 2002, 15:01

I just saw the new movie Sorority Boys. First off, this is a bad movie, that's probably not worth your time. But, on the good side, the lead female character, played by Melissa Sagemiller, wears really cute black frame glasses all through the movie. She even wears them at the end when she and lead guy get together and everybody lives happily everafter. I think there are probably two reasons she wears glasses, one good and one bad. The good reason is that her needing glasses explains why when she's in the shower (and not wearing glasses) she can't tell that the guy pretending to be a girl is really a guy. The other reason kind of goes back to the usual stereotype we see in movies. She is the president of the ugly girl sorority. Since this actress is really beautiful, I suppose the only reason the script writers could justify her being in the ugly girl sorority is to have her wearing glasses. But it didn't work. With the glasses, or without, she was better looking than the girls in the rival pretty girls sorority. But after all that, unless you just want to go to see the girl wearing glasses, I'd wait until this movie comes out on video.

Hi All,

I didn't post that message, it was an imposter!!

I've apologised time and again for those popups, but there is nothing more I can do - if you want free webspace you have to take what goes with it - believe me I tried loads of hosts b4 Gizba and they all had reasons why I didn't use them.

I've provided a link to the popup killer that I use on the main menu, and thats as much as I can do.

Spaceports - my other ISP - doesn't have popups so I am using that more but their server can be slow in the evenings which is when I generally upload the files, so I'm having to do it sneakily @ work now!!!

http://www.GwGs.co.uk/index2.htm

GwGs 27 Feb 2002, 12:36

Hi Curt,

Let me say that none of those popus are mine, I hate the things, and that's why I provided the link to download the pop up stopper.

I am using Version 2.2, and it stops every window, even when I try to open a new window it won't let me unless I hold down the shift key when clicking on a link.

I am starting to use Spaceports more, as they don't have any popups - but their server can be slow when trying to upload stuff, and usually stalls if i use it in the evening and although they say they give you unlimited space, they only give you 20MB to start off with, and trying to get more is like trying to get blood out of a stone.

Trying to find free webspace without advertising is hard, and when I don't make any money out of the site, I can't afford to buy webspace.

Upgrade to Version 2.6 which is at: http://www.popupstopper.net/product_downloads.html - that is their latest one, and should work.

Thanks.

spexalot 26 Feb 2002, 10:04

Her hair style was called the Hamill wedge. Her skating technique was called the Hamill Camel. In an interview on the Phil Donnahue show, she fielded questions from the audiance. One woman asked her Dorothy to remove her eyeglasses which she wore on the show. Dorothy did so and exclaimed "now I can't see you"

spexalot 26 Feb 2002, 09:28

yeah, I remember interviews of her at the time. She couldn't wear her contacts on the ice rink because of the ammonia released by the ice had bothered her eyes when wearing lenses. she practiced wearing glasses but when it became show time she went out there bare-eyed. And she said her memory of winning was just a big blur.

Oscar 26 Feb 2002, 09:08

Yes indeed. Large frames with the sort of plastic used for lenses in the 70s would mean quite thick edges for a minus 4. She's extremely pretty without them, of course, but the specs would really do it.

GwGs 26 Feb 2002, 08:48

Wurm 26 Feb 2002, 08:30

"Hamill set off another fashion trend in the 1970s -- glasses with oversized frames. Nicknamed "Squint" because of her bad eyesight, her huge glasses were first bought in the summer of 1971. Coach Carlo Fassi discovered her eyesight problem and told the optician to make the biggest frames possible so Hamill could see out of the corners while doing figures."

from http://espn.go.com/classic/s/add_hamill_dorothy.html

Hamill also briefly had her own line of frames (oversized, of course).

spexalot 26 Feb 2002, 06:09

Dorothy Hamill won the gold in the 1976 olympics. Her famous hair cut was called the Hamill ....something or other, I don't remember. But it seems every other girl in that era was getting that cut. She also wore large frame eyeglasses of about -3.50 to -4.00. And then she started doing commercials for Bauch & Lomb soft contact lenses which she started wearing.

spexalot 26 Feb 2002, 06:00

Yes, Dorothy Hammill. A cute myopic, rich DEB. from Connecticut. Who could really skate. She Married one of Dean Martin's sons. Today she is doing TV commericals for arthritus medication. She has "lost" the glasses though. I don't know if she wears contacts now or has had LASIK surgery.

Curt 22 Feb 2002, 06:12

JT: I often just comes from years of lenswatching. With friends, I would make a mental note as to what I thought their prescription was, and then later ask them to see how close I was. I used to be a lot easier; high index lenses have made guessing minus prescriptions much more difficult. You used to be able to make a bit of a guess from the thickness of the edge of the lens, but, like I said, with high index lenses, all bets are off. I recently guessed a friends Rx to within 0.25 !

OK, OLD MOVIE, but what a misuse of a lens! FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE starring James Bond aka Sean Connery...the nasty female Russian Spymaster put on these incredible -26 specs for reading a few lines, and then took them off to speak with her protege.

So how dumb do they think we are? There is no way anyone wearing such specs would take them off for a second, particularly to read. These terific nearighted items were used as though they were a sort of plus glasses available at any supermarket.

Thye are the thickest ones yet I have seen on the screen. Too bad they could not have ben used properly!

Does anyone else know this (glasses wrongly used) movie?

I fnd it irritating that sych wonderful high-minus glasses have been so ill-used. The movie-goers amongst us, please tell me that this is not the way it is oridinarily done.....

Curt 31 Jan 2002, 12:28

Alan: The actress you are referring to in the Medicine Man is Lorraine Bracco, now on the Sopranos. I believe on Lenslover's site (Smudge Report) there is a short essay on women wearing glasses in movies - titles the Good, the Bad and the Ugly if I remember correctly. Medicine Man was listed under the "Bad" for just the reasons you mentioned Even though Lorraine is nearsighted and her glasses have an obvious - prescription, she puts them on to look at the computer, read, etc. I like the movie, but the OO in me was bugged by her use of glasses. "Roxanne", with Daryl Hannah (one of my absolute favorite actresses), on the other hand, is, for lack of a better term, optically correct. Daryl is a hyperope in real life, and wears her + lenses whenever she reads loveletters, etc. She does, however, slip on her + lenses (around her neck on a chain) when she and Steve Martin are moving her telescope up a long set of steps --- anyone remember that scene?

Dave 30 Jan 2002, 23:04

This week-end I watched the movie "Almost An Angel" co-starring Linda Kozlowski. She wore low minus glasses in most of the scenes. A must see for GWG fans.

Guest 30 Jan 2002, 18:59

In "You've Got Mail", Jean Stapleton (a.k.a. Edith Bunker) wore obvious minus glasses for reading. She portrayed a bookshop employee, Meg Ryan being the employer.

Alan 30 Jan 2002, 12:30

Teachkids and Spexalot,

What an actress wears in a movie isn't much indication of what they do in real life, I don't think. I remember an actress in some movie quite a while ago -- The Medicine Man, or something like that, maybe -- who would put glasses on for reading in the movie, but not for other things...yet the glasses had a fairly strong minus prescription...strong enough that I'm surprised she could act both with and without them. (Maybe she removed some contacts in between takes when she put the glasses on...I don't know.) It was pretty funny. Anyway, I'm (almost) sure they were her real glasses, but the script called for her "looking smart" by putting on "reading" glasses, so that's what she did. Most of the world seems to have no sense of how different prescriptions look...maybe some vague notion of whether or not glasses are strong, but that's about it.

Point being -- Meg Ryan could wear weak minus glasses in real life and put glasses on in movies in order to give some kind of impression the director is looking for that doesn't really make sense for the actress' real Rx. And most actors and actresses probably wear contacts anyway, aside from the ones who have had Lasik.

Alan

Curt 22 Jan 2002, 12:05

GwGs: As I said to someone else earlier, photos taken from directly in front of a person (like the Cindy Crawford pix) make it very hard to guess prescriptions. There is no way to see the degree of magnification or minification through the corner of the lens, or the # of concentric rings for minus Rxs. Her eyes look a little bigger through the glasses, so they may be + lenses, but it is really hard to tell. Wish there were more pix of her wearing specs

teachkids 21 Jan 2002, 21:24

any idea of Jennifer Anniston's rx???

GwGs.

Daventhalas aka Ray 03 Jan 2002, 12:42

I saw a movie over the holidays that really disguested me. In the "Princess Diaries" a movie designed to be a self-esteem boost to girls and young women, there is a scene where where they are giving the girl a make-over and the scene goes something like this.

Stylist: Looking at her in her glasses, "Do you ever wear contact lenses?"

Girl: "Yes, but I really prefer to wear glass-"

At this point the guy takes her glasses off face, snaps them in half and tells her that she has know choice but to wear contacts now.

That scene almost made me sick. Here is one of those rare women who comfortable as is and someone is trying to take that confidence away from her. She also had long super curly, another thing I really like, and they cut all that off saying it was the worst hair he'd ever seen. This movie takes the "girl loses glasses and become a babe" thing way too far. I have a six year old daughter who wears glasses and will have to for life and I do not want her to see this movie ever.

Curt 19 Dec 2001, 13:30

jj: When pictures are taken from directly in front of someone's face (like the link you posted), it is almost impossible to guess the Rx. The only way (that I know of) to make a semi-accurate guess is to see how many concentric rings there are in the lens from an angle, or to see how much minification (for minus lenses) or magnification (for plus lenses) you can see through the corner of the lens. This has also been a problem with every picture I have seen of Katie Holmes --- they are done straight on or at such an angle that you can't actually see through the lens of her specs. Darn!

But as far as GWGs are concerned it is one of the best GWG movies ever.

beautiful in her glasses. I just melted in my seat.

I wonder if she wears glasses in real life. I've seldom seem a babe look so hot in specs.

If anybody out there has cable TV, there is a channel called TechTV. There is an absolutely hot babe on a weekly daytime show called Tech Live. Her names is Erica Hill. She is already a very prettty babe without glasses. But some days she wears some very nice looking brown plastic framed glasses. She is well worth checking out. What a babe.

I just love GWGs. I never go anywhere without looking for sexy GWGs

Alan 26 Nov 2001, 17:47

Angie 26 Nov 2001, 12:04

Alan 20 Nov 2001, 12:44

Wurm,

Yes, they say "I" look ugly in them, but do they say "she" (the girl with the really cool glasses across the room) looks ugly in glasses? I was talking to one of my friends recently, and I asked her whether she thinks I look better with glasses or without...she said "with". I was actually a little disturbed, because she seemed very certain about it, and it almost made me feel like I would be putting myself at a disadvantage 'attractiveness-wise' if I didn't wear my glasses. But dispite her positive view of *my* glasses, she insists that she "doesn't look good in glasses". (She doesn't have to wear any, either, so I guess her basis is only other people's glasses she has tried on, which presumably didn't fit her face that well. But she might be getting a little nearsighted...so maybe she'll have to really find out.)

I just think there is a weird double standard between how people view others in glasses verses how they view themselves.

I'm curious what the reaction will be to Sidewalks of New York, where Heather Graham appears to wear glasses in most of the movie.

Alan

Curt 20 Nov 2001, 05:18

Wurm: I meant it only partially in jest. There is an attitude in Hollywood and in other areas where the "beautiful people" are that glasses are not attractive. This is hardly a revolation - it has been talked about for years. Among the group of people who post here, it is certainly not the case...but I truely believe that the general attitude (in the US anyway) is that a person is less attractive with glasses than without. I don't believe it, but I hear it from women time and time again that I discuss glasses with. They always say "Oh, I look ugly in them!"...

Wurm 19 Nov 2001, 16:04

I suspect Curt's comment was made with tongue planted firmly in cheek.

However, with more and more people comfortable with wearing glasses these days, I hope that will translate to more sightings of celebs in glasses.

As much as I like dramatic eyewear styles, the current retro specs have probably helped get more people out wearing their glasses without thinking twice about it. I think people find one or the other among small round, small oval and rectangular frames quite wearable. There isn't a strong bias for wire, plastic or rimless either and that may also be helping.

Alan 19 Nov 2001, 15:13

"being one the most beautiful women in the US, she has an image to uphold."

That would be just about the most dreadful possible reason not to wear glasses. I know the belief that glasses can look great goes far beyond optic obsessives. But it's almost like models and body image -- very few people actually find their version of the ideal body type to be 5 foot, 10 inches and 110 pounds, yet so many women think that is how they are 'supposed' to be.
